PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The proposed cuts in funding to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will have serious effects on the viability of many family chemists leading to increased charges and reduction in services and availability of medicines to the community.
We therefore call on the Federal Government to reject the findings of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal and maintain the level of funding existing prior to the Tribunal's findings.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Company Tax Collection Systems
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's Budget decision to change the company tax collection system will be a crippling blow to many small businesses, already suffering as a direct result of the Hawke Government's high interest rate policy.
The earlier remittance of company tax payments to the Government will substantially reduce the cash-flow position of thousands of small businesses.

Many small businesses will be driven under as a result of the Government's decision-unable to find funds for both tax commitments and new stock, only able to borrow at record high interest rates and unable to claim any tax relief on such borrowings to meet their tax commitment.
The Government's proposed changes to the company tax collection system has only been introduced as a greedy grab for more tax revenue.

The small business community would prefer the Government to completely abandon the proposal rather than make only minor alterations to the original Budget decision, which are not likely to alleviate the situation to any significant extent.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament.
The petition of citizens of Australia points out:

that all State governments, States Attorneys-General, most women's groups and the majority of men in Australia, including significant numbers of Members of Parliament, are totally opposed to the importation and distribution of `X' and excessively violent `R'-rated video pornography in Australia;
that most `X'-rated material available in Australia is imported;
that the Federal Government, by its Customs power under the Constitution, and not the ACT Government, is solely responsible for controlling the importation of this pornographic material;
that by continuing to allow the importation of such pornographic material, the Federal Government is neglecting its responsibility to the women, children and families of Australia.
Your petitioners, therefore, request the Senate to:
1. Ban `X'-rated pornographic material at the point of entry into Australia.
2. Exclude from the `R'-rating all gratuitously violent material.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian National Botanic Gardens, Education Unit: Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's decision to abolish the Education Unit of the National Botanic Gardens is a betrayal of the Federal Government's professed commitment to conservation, protection and management of Australia's unique flora.

The Education Unit fulfilled an important role in increasing the knowledge, appreciation and enjoyment of Australia's plant heritage of visitors to the National Botanic Gardens, including many school children.

Therefore your petitioners request that the Senate require the Government to recognise the importance of the work carried out by the Education Unit and reverse its decision to withdraw funding for the Unit.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Abortion Funding Abolition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That in 1988-89 the Federal Government paid $6.9 million from taxpayers' funds for 64,788 abortions under Medicare Items 6469 and 274/275 alone.
That in the same year Federal Government grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State public hospitals.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by supporting the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1989 and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Alston (from 1,202 citizens) and Button (from 951 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare Schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare Schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare Schedule.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Will the Minister confirm the correctness of the statement by New South Wales Labour Council officers that `productivity increases have not been forthcoming under the accord and therefore real wage growth is impossible under the current system'?
—I am asked to give an opinion about a document which has been repudiated by the--
—No; that is not what you were asked.
—Yes, it was. The honourable senator is asking me to confirm the concept or the accuracy of the document.
—The correctness of the statement.

—I can probably confirm the accuracy of the document by saying that it came from a very junior officer in the Labour Council in New South Wales and was repudiated by the Secretary of the Labour Council in New South Wales. Of course, Senator Chaney has been raising this question of productivity a lot recently. No doubt he will raise it again in the course of the matter of public importance to be debated later today. But in so far as any improvements in the productivity situation if an alternative government were to be elected are concerned, the answer is, `Who knows?'.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I can understand the agitated state of the Leader of the Government, but he might have listened to the question that was asked and addressed himself to it. It simply asks him whether he could confirm the correctness of one of the statements that appears in the document to which he referred, with some excitement, and that statement was simply this:

QUESTION.PARA: Productivity increases have not been forthcoming under the accord and therefore real wage growth is impossible under the current system.

I remind the Minister that in a Question Time last week I gave him some of the most recent figures published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics which relate to declining unit productivity over the last two measured quarters. I ask: Does he, as a matter of fact, agree that productivity improvement is essential to increasing real wages in Australia? Is it a fact that productivity has declined or been stagnant under the accord?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney and I have had this discussion on numerous occasions. Senator Chaney continues to use a measure of productivity which hardly anybody else in this country is prepared to use.
—The Australian Bureau of Statistics.

—No, not the Australian Bureau of Statistics. For example, the Business Council of Australia-which Senator Chaney might like to quote on this issue from time to time-put out a paper on the measurement of productivity a couple of years ago which stated:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . a clear understanding of the concept of productivity is essential if misinterpretations or misrepresentations are to be avoided.
Further, it said:

. . . production of goods and services is unequivocally a joint co-operative process. It cannot be said that equipment, or labour, or managerial skill by itself has a distinct productive contribution.

Therefore, any proper measure of productivity must show the relationship between output and all the inputs into the production process. This total factor productivity is the preferred measure of the BCA.

The paper goes on to elaborate on that. But Senator Chaney will hear a bit more about this during the matter of public importance debate. It is ridiculous for Senator Chaney to say that there has been no productivity increase in this country during the period of the accord. There are plenty of examples where firms have achieved enormous productivity increases-and Senator Chaney knows about them-and they did so in spite of the system which Senator Chaney continually criticises. It is true that real wage growth has not taken place. Only in one year in the history of the accord has there been a real growth in average adult male wages. But there has been an enormous increase in employment and, as I said in the Senate last week, household disposable income has increased steadily under this Government. The only year in which it has not increased was the last year of the Fraser Government, when it went down by 2.5 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. After the resounding success of Labor in Queensland, can the Minister tell the Senate what implications there are in the election of a Labor government for the status of women in Queensland? In particular, what plans are being made for transferring the Queensland Women's Information Service?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President--
—What has this to do with the Federal Government?

—It has a great deal to do with the Federal Government. The absolutely stunning victory for Wayne Goss and his team is very important from the Federal Government's point of view because we will be able to work very closely with the new Queensland Government. It is a particularly historic occasion in terms of the numbers of women elected to the Queensland Parliament.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Knowles interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very important victory for women in Queensland. I think that even Senator Knowles would agree that it is quite unheard of for three Ministers to be forced out of government by three women candidates. This is the first time in Australian history that three Ministers have been forced out of office by women candidates. That indicates the strength of women candidates and the way in which they are moving into the political arena in this country today.

ANSWER.PARA: Furthermore, I think it would be inappropriate of me not to mention that, in addition to those three Ministers forced out by women candidates, Martin Tenni was also forced to resign. He was not even game to face the election. We call Dr Lesley Clark the crocodile killer because she forced Martin Tenni out long before the election was actually held. Senator Giles asks me what difference a Labor government will make in Queensland. Of course it will make an enormous difference to Queenslanders across so many fronts but it will make a particular difference in relation to women and it will make a particular difference in relation to status of women policies.

For three decades Queensland women have been ignored by the National Party and, indeed, by the Liberal Party because it has been too gutless to stand up to the National Party. Of course, we now see the results of the failure of the Queensland Liberal Party to stand up to the National Party. In terms of status of women policies, we will see Wayne Goss implementing his policy and opening new doors for women. These new policies will bring Queensland women into line with other States in terms of a whole range of initiatives: education, employment and training, women's health and a whole range of other initiatives that will give women a genuine place on the political agenda in Queensland.

Senator Giles asks me in particular what implications this will have for the Queensland Women's Information Service. As I am sure honourable senators will know, in both Tasmania and Queensland for a number of years, there have been no commitments for implementing status of women policies. Therefore, it was up to the Federal Government to introduce a policy to set up both the Queensland Women's Information Service and the Tasmanian Women's Information Service. With the election of a Labor Government in Tasmania earlier this year I have, with the Prime Minister, been undertaking discussions with the Premier of Tasmania and the Minister Assisting the Premier on the Status of Women, Fran Bladel, in order to ensure a smooth transfer of that service to State responsibility which of course is the normal practice in other States. We look forward to negotiating in a similar way with the new Premier of Queensland, Wayne Goss, and Anne Warner, who is expected to be the Minister assisting the Premier on the status of women. I look forward to a smooth transition so that that service, which has provided some excellent opportunities for Queensland women to gain information and access to ideas about Federal initiatives, can be transferred to Queensland. I see it being a very focal point of implementing Wayne Goss's new women's policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It follows his reply to a question from me when he suggested that I was using the wrong measure of productivity. He referred to the preference of the Business Council of Australia for total factor productivity as being the most relevant measure. I ask the Minister: Is it a fact that in the Economic Outlook published by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) in December 1988 in a table showing productivity trends in selected OECD countries-the Minister should know this as I have quoted it often enough in this place-total factor productivity for Australia for the period 1987 to 1990 is shown as minus 0.2 per cent per annum? I ask the Minister: If the total factor productivity, which is the measure that he supported through the mouth of the Business Council of Australia a few minutes ago, is showing a negative figure for Australia, what are the implications of that for wage and salary earners in Australia? Does it not mean that real wages cannot increase under those circumstances?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney cannot come in here day after day shifting his ground. On 29 November he quoted from an Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) publication.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chaney interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I invite Senator Chaney to listen to this. He asked me whether in the June quarter there was a reduction of 1.5 per cent in the gross domestic product per hour worked index. That is what he relied upon on 29 November. That measure is not a particularly reliable one, as the ABS itself says in one of its publications. That measure, on its own, cannot be used to draw any implications for the likely movement in real wages.

ANSWER.PARA: Today, Senator Chaney put words in my mouth saying that I supported the Business Council view relating to total factor productivity. I did not. I said that Senator Chaney ought to take account of the Business Council view, which is a much broader view of productivity than the one he put here last week. Like his Leader, Senator Chaney cannot keep recycling things from one week to another to try to prove the argument which is not acceptable to 80 per cent of the business community in this country. His success rate in selling this policy to the business community has been about 21 per cent. That figure will go down after his Leader's answer last week to a question about the implications of the wages system which an alternative government would introduce. Twice he said, `Who knows?'. That is the position of the Opposition in relation to these matters.

Senator Chaney has tried it every way. During the pilots strike and every industrial dispute he has recycled a different figure and asked, `Doesn't this prove a particular point?'. I ask Senator Chaney what he will do about enterprise productivity if he is ever elected to government. How will he measure productivity in terms of an enterprise? That is one of the questions he has to ask. What will the Opposition do about productivity at the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, which has had a 35 per cent increase in a year? Will the Opposition allow a 35 per cent wage increase for BHP? These are the sorts of questions the honourable senator should address his mind to instead of recycling different sets of figures every week.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am not allowed to answer the questions that the Minister asks me in this place. Rather than have him asking me questions in his reply, I ask him: Since he conceded in his earlier answer that real wages have fallen under the accord in almost every year of this Government and are likely to fall again this year, does he believe that that has anything to do with the actual productivity of industry in Australia; or is he saying that productivity is irrelevant to the fact that Australian wage and salary earners are having less in their pay packets year by year under this Government?

—I am not saying that productivity is irrelevant to anything. Productivity, as Senator Chaney knows, is very important. I have answered questions in relation to productivity in the Senate day after day. The fact of the matter is that real wages have fallen as a result of the implementation of the centralised wage fixing system. That is true.
—You are quite right; it is for that reason.

—Senator Stone should not get excited. I thought he would be the last person to get excited today. The fact is that that is a result of implementation of government policy, from which we do not run away. Honourable senators opposite run away from it. Week after week they come in here and suggest that living standards have fallen because real wages have fallen. That is not the appropriate measure because disposable household incomes in Australia have increased in every year since the year in which the Liberal and National parties went out of office when they went down by 2.5 per cent. They are the things that honourable senators opposite have to face up to. It is no good yelling at me.

—Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade inform the Senate whether the attempted coup against the Aquino Government in the Philippines has been completely and successfully put down? Can the Minister give details of the military assistance provided to the Aquino Government by the United States Government? Was the assistance requested by the Aquino Government? Does the Australian Government support the provision of such military assistance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The attempted coup against President Aquino launched by the right wing RAM or Reform of the Armed Forces Movement, early on 1 December, has been suppressed although mopping up operations, so described, are likely to continue for some time. Loss of life among the military and civilian population and damage to property have been considerable. Rebel elements are dispersing or surrendering, but some units are still occupying key buildings in the Makati business district where, incidentally, the Australian Embassy is located. The motives of the coup attempt, the sixth since President Aquino came to power in 1986, do remain somewhat confused but clearly reflect tensions within the armed forces over political developments in the Philippines and the subordination, so claimed, of the military to civilian democratic rule.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government was among the first to offer its strong support to President Aquino in resisting the illegal attempt by renegade military elements to seize power and to overthrow the democratically elected Government of the Philippines. We welcome the restoration of the authority of the properly constituted Government of the Philippines. We note that the Government of President Aquino does face difficult challenges in meeting popular expectations for economic progress and social reform in a society where poverty and inequality continue to be major problems. It will be vital for the international community to continue to work constructively with the Philippines Government to meet the challenges of poverty and economic development. The Australian Government will, for its part, extend its full support and encouragement to Mrs Aquino in her efforts to improve the welfare of her people, as Mr Hawke made very clear in his public statements on the issue over the weekend.

So far as the safety of Australians is concerned, as far as the Government is aware, all Australian nationals and Embassy personnel in the Philippines are reported safe. The Embassy staff and dependants spent the night of last Saturday, 2 December, in the Embassy as the best means, so evaluated, of ensuring their personal safety. They are now, I understand, dispersed in hotels around the Manila area. I should like very warmly to commend the Ambassador and his staff for their very professional conduct and personal courage during what has been obviously a difficult time for them.

So far as the United States involvement in this matter is concerned, the nature of that involvement has been widely reported. It has extended simply to air cover, air support, without which the position of the Government troops would have been made very much more difficult and the success of the coup attempt would have been very much more likely. That United States military support was offered in response to a direct request from President Aquino, the democratically elected leader of the Philippines. I think the language of the Prime Minister in his statement over the weekend speaks for itself when he said:
I welcome and endorse the positive and speedy response by President Bush to the request for assistance from President Aquino.
United States action to help counter the illegal attempt to overthrow the freely-elected government of the Philippines is playing an important part in enabling it to reassert its authority.
At the end of a year in which democracy has triumphed through `people power' in large parts of eastern Europe, it would be a tragedy if Philippines democracy fell to force of rebel arms.
President Aquino has Australia's full support for her efforts to restore the authority of the duly elected and properly constituted government of the Philippines.
They were the words of the Prime Minister and I, of course, endorse them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security by reminding him that some years ago, following intensive lobbying by the Australian Democrats, members of the Jewish community and others, the Government agreed to an amendment in this place to the social security legislation regarding the status of restitution payments made to Germans now living in Australia and who had been the victims of Nazi persecution during World War II. Is the Minister aware that Australian residents from other European countries, specifically those who came from the Austrian and Dutch populations, who were also subject to similar persecutions by the Nazis during World War II, are not covered by the amended legislation? What steps will the Government take to close off this anomaly in the Social Security Act in order to exclude restitution payments made to those people from the income test?

—Senator Haines is right in that a little while ago in this Parliament we did amend the legislation to ensure that payments made by the Federal Republic of Germany to persons who suffered from, and received compensation for, Nazi persecution during World War II would not be included as income for the purpose of testing Australian social security pensions and benefits. There have been discussions in this place and outside it on the question of whether payments made by the Austrian Government should also be treated in the same light and be excluded as income for the assessment of social security benefits of this category. The Government has been giving some attention to this particular question. In fact, last week there was a meeting of officials representing both Australia and Austria. That meeting was part of a general process of trying to achieve a social security agreement between this country and Austria to cover social security issues. As part of that agreement the Australian Government became satisfied that the payments paid by the Austrian Government, by way of its compensation for Nazi persecution during World War II, were conclusively enough verified as being payments very similar in character to those restitution payments made by the Federal Republic of Germany. As we noted, those payments are already disregarded for the purposes of assessing income. The Government has therefore decided that, as from today, payments made by the Austrian Government as compensation in this area will not affect entitlement to Australian income tested social security pensions and benefits. We see this as a logical extension of the move made a couple of years ago through this Parliament in terms of German restitution payments. We also see this as another step in the process of achieving a general social security agreement between Australia and Austria. Hopefully we will be able to achieve that by 1992. In the meantime, pensions paid to those receiving payments from the Austrian Government as compensation for Nazi persecution will not affect their entitlement to Australian pensions and benefits.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister, or the Government, aware of whether any other government is currently paying restitution payments to its nationals? I have had some letters from members of the Dutch community living in Australia and I wonder whether the Government is undertaking any negotiations with any other European government whose residents may have been affected?

—In all of the discussions I have had the sole country in question has been Austria. I have had no notice-I am not sure whether the Minister for Social Security has-of other countries. I will find out and let the Senate know.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Have comments about interest rates made in the course of the recent Queensland State election campaign had any detrimental effect on the effectiveness of monetary policy?

—I do not think so. I presume Senator Jones's question refers to the comments made by, among others, Senator Stone during the Queensland election campaign in which Senator Stone said that the Opposition had no magic wand solutions for the high interest rate problem, regardless of whether that problem is a political or economic problem, or both. In saying that, Senator Stone was telling the truth. Dr Hewson said something very similar. Therefore, I do not regard it as having damaged the effectiveness of monetary policy or of anything worthwhile. Indeed, I would regard it as a plus. Some people were rather surprised when Senator Stone said that. But the people who were surprised by his statement do not realise that inside that cynical shell of a National Party politician always lurks a Treasury Secretary desperately trying to get out. On this occasion the Treasury Secretary got out. Whatever Senator Stone's intentions are, in saying what he did, I leave for others to judge. However, I believe that Senator Stone knows as well as anybody else that corrupt governments should be booted out of office and last Saturday one was.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and Minister for Industrial Relations. Does the Minister agree that the push by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) for the creation of fewer but much bigger unions could produce a union structure either contrary to, or having minimal effect on, the desirability of bringing a greater enterprise focus to industrial relations? I ask him whether he agrees with the view in the New South Wales Labour Council paper that a reduction in the average number of unions per enterprise from 4.7 to 4.5, which is the estimate of the Business Council of Australia of the result of the ACTU plan, will have very little impact on micro-economic efficiency and that, to quote the Labour Council paper:

QUESTION.PARA: Single enterprise agreements seem to be a more appropriate method of dealing with these issues. The size of the union is not important.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already suggested, in answers to questions put to me by Senator Chaney and others, that the document to which the honourable senator refers has no credibility as a document of the New South Wales Labour Council and I repeat that point. Having said that, I am asked to express a view about it. Of course, a sensible view, in terms of the reorganisation of organisations of employees or unions, I think will lead inevitably to industrial unions being formed rather than a mix of craft and industrial unions as in some--
—Industry unions?

—I mean industrial unions-unions organised on an industry basis-as distinct from craft unions. I believe that that is an inevitable and sensible result. I cannot pass comment on each proposal which has gone before the ACTU, although I think some of them do not reach very successfully towards that optimum result of industry-based unions. The question of enterprise unions is a totally different consideration. I do not agree with the reported remarks of the two junior Labour Council officials on that issue at all.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to a letter from David Hawker, the member for Wannon and Chairman of the Federal Liberal Rural Committee, published in the Wheatbelt Mercury on 29 November 1989?
—The what Mercury?
—In the letter Mr Hawker asserts that, in many cases, the capital gains tax acts as a death duty. Is this statement accurate?
—Yes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge the interjection that came from Senator Stone and, for the record, say that this time the Treasury Secretary did not get out.
—It was Messner.

—Oh, I am sorry, Well, there never was a Treasury Secretary inside that cynical exterior trying to get out in the first place. I think Senator Hill asked what the Mercury was or what Merredin was. Mr Hawker is a bit unfortunate because Merredin is almost my home town; therefore, I know quite a lot about it.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Puplick interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I will give Senator Puplick the benefit of that knowledge in a minute or two. It is correct that Mr Hawker has compared the capital gains tax with death duties. In doing so he displayed either a culpable conceptual ignorance of the nature of the taxes or an intention wilfully to misrepresent the facts. I will leave it to others to judge of which offence he was guilty. Of course, the plain fact is-and overlooking complications such as the fact that assets acquired before 19 September 1985 are not subject to the capital gains tax, as that is not terribly important in this context-that a capital gains tax is levied only if there has been a gain; only if the purchase price of an asset was less than the selling price, and in real terms to boot, and this is very important in this context; whereas death duties are levies on the net value of an asset, irrespective of whether it has appreciated or depreciated in price since the time it was acquired.

ANSWER.PARA: The other point, which in this context is particularly important-this is where my direct knowledge of the Merredin district comes into operation-is that, over the long term, the price of agricultural land in Australia does not appreciate in real terms unless it has some market demand for non-agricultural purposes; that is, land obviously adjoining capital cities, prime beach locations or possibly other waterside locations. Anybody who knows anything about the background of agriculture in Australia knows that agricultural land which has only an agricultural market value does not appreciate over the long term; it fluctuates from time to time. I very clearly recall farms in the Merredin district being sold in 1968 for $50 an acre. If we index that figure by the consumer price index, it is over $250 an acre or thereabouts. I know of no land in the Merredin district that has been sold for that price. So Mr Hawker, as well as being either conceptually ignorant or guilty of wilful misrepresentation, had the bad luck to send a letter in to this newspaper in an area which I know very well.

In this letter, Mr Hawker also mentions the National Farmers Federation. It is a fact that the National Farmers Federation, under the tutelage of the present Liberal Party candidate for Barker, Mr McLachlan, ran a very high profile campaign against both the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax. In so doing, Mr McLachlan portrayed the real interests of the people he purported to represent, because neither the capital gains tax nor the fringe benefits tax has had any significant impact on agriculture, and nor will it in the future, except for those very small areas of agricultural land for which there is a market demand not related to agricultural purposes.

Mr Hawker also put forward the usual Liberal Party drivel about incentives and the Liberal Party's desire to look after the little people. One person who is anything but a little person and who will gain a great deal from the Liberal Party's policy on capital gains taxation is the Liberal Party Federal President, who from his one cent share transactions or rorts alone stands to gain $18m-just from the one cent share rort if the Liberal policy is implemented. The Opposition's policy will provide incentives for people to set up more one cent share rorts for themselves and to `invest' in such things as the purchases of works of art. I remember a couple of weeks ago hearing Senator Button answer a question about this. It was a very good question and he gave a very good answer concerning a painting that Mr Alan Bond, another little person-a person about as small as Mr Elliott, or, I suppose, these days a bit smaller than Mr Elliott-had bought some years ago for $5m and sold for $19m. It just so happens that he bought it before September 1985 but, leaving that unimportant thing aside, Mr Bond picked up a capital gain of $14m. Anybody who wants to do that in the future, of course, will have an incentive to do the sort of thing that Mr Bond did. Where do these paintings come from? They come almost always from overseas. —I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade whether there is any truth in recent reports that Myanmar, formerly Burma, is secretly trying political dissidents and sentencing them to long prison terms, with national elections less than six months away. With diplomats now expressing concern about the fairness of the forthcoming voting and the continuing repression against opposition figures, does Australia have plans to send observers to Rangoon to report on the fairness of the elections?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are reports attributed to diplomats in Bangkok that the authorities in Myanmar are secretly trying political dissidents and sentencing them to long prison terms. Those reports accord broadly with information from other sources that the military regime has adopted severe repressive measures against its political opponents. In particular, as we all know, the leaders of the National League for Democracy, Aung San Suu Kyi and Tin U, have been held under house arrest since 20 July and thousands of other political activists have also been detained. According to figures released by the Myanmar authorities, no fewer than 100 people have been sentenced to death by military tribunals and civilian courts since July this year. I am not aware of any of those sentences having yet been carried out, but obviously that is a matter of profound concern.

ANSWER.PARA: I raised all these matters personally in New York on 4 October when I met the chairman of the Myanmar delegation to the United Nations General Assembly, Brigadier General Nyan Lynn, who is also a member of the ruling State Law and Order Restoration Council. I sought a lifting of restrictions on political activity, the release of Aung San Suu Kyi and other political prisoners in preparation for free and fair elections, and respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms of the people of Myanmar.

For Australia to send observers to the elections on the assumption that they are held in May next year as scheduled, it would, of course, be necessary for the Myanmar authorities to issue an invitation, or at least indicate a willingness to do that, which they have so far not done. Moreover, under the present circumstances, with the main opposition leaders under house arrest, there is a very serious question as to the value of sending observers to determine the fairness of the election process itself. An election process, however fairly conducted on the day, is hardly worth the name if in the campaign period leading up to it there is a process of stifling political dissent and inhibiting the fair and open conduct of political campaigning in the way that is presently occurring.

All these matters will be kept under close review by us. I would not like to foreclose the question of observers at this stage but at the moment the situation in Myanmar is profoundly disappointing, to say the least, and it is very important indeed that the Myanmar authorities take some rapid steps to open up the campaign process if they want the elections, if they are held next year, to have any shred of credibility in the international arena.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to the growing criticism of the Government's inaction in relation to Taiwan and resulting losses in economic opportunity. What are the obstacles to completing an agreement for direct air links? Is the Government prepared to offer investment protection to Taiwan in order that the China Steel Corporation proposal might be further progressed? What is the objection of the Government to an Australian bid to establish a horseracing industry in Taiwan which would include establishing a modern totalisator, racecourses, et cetera? Has the Government taken action regarding Taiwan cutting the Australian beef quota? If so, what has been agreed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the subject of the investment security issue, I have seen a number of press reports discussing the potential for Taiwan investment in Australia and the allegations that some potential investors are concerned that their investments may not be secure. The Australian Government obviously welcomes investment in Australia by Taiwan companies, which will be treated in the same way as investment from other sources. In recent weeks we have been considering this issue in detail and officials have proposed a number of options for consideration by the Government to lay to rest all fears on the part of investors from unrecognised entities such as Taiwan about the security of their investment in Australia. At this stage all I can say about that is that I expect that the Government will make a decision on this matter in the very near future. Whatever action is taken will be consistent with the position of successive governments that the People's Republic of China (PRC) is the sole legal government of China and that Taiwan is a province of that country. That is the framework that will continue to guide Government policy towards Taiwan.

ANSWER.PARA: So far as direct air links are concerned, we acknowledge that direct aviation links with Taiwan, and the increased tourism that might well be associated with that, could have economic benefits for Australia. We would very much like to see the establishment of a direct Australia-Taiwan air link. However, any consideration of that has to take place against the background of Australia's acceptance, as I have just said, of the PRC Government as the sole legal government of China and our acknowledgment of its claim that Taiwan is a province of China. Notwithstanding the increase in diplomatic activity from Taiwan which has obviously made its mark on the Opposition, the events since 4 June have not changed this situation.

So far as specific negotiations are concerned, Australia-Asia Airlines, which is a fully owned subsidiary of Qantas Airways Ltd, has been negotiating with Taiwan interests with a view to reaching agreement on commercial arrangements. In the absence of an official air services agreement, such arrangements could permit the introduction of non-scheduled services between Australia and Taiwan. Those commercial negotiations are continuing and are fully supported by the Australian Government. I understand that the principal obstacle to the commencement of flights is the insistence by Taiwan on reciprocity for China Airlines, the Taiwan flag carrier-a flag carrier of a very overt kind-and refusal to contemplate, so far anyway, the attractive package proposed by Australia-Asia Airlines.

The analogies that are constantly drawn between the airlines of other countries flying directly into the Republic of China are, in the briefing that I have seen, all misconceived to the extent that for one reason or another, with the exception of the Dutch airline, those arrangements pre-date the recognition arrangements which are currently in force. So there is no doubt but that an enormous significance would be attached to any fundamental change of position by Australia on the question of reciprocity or any of the other matters presently in issue. All I can say about this is what I have said in Estimates committees and on other public occasions, and that is that we are very conscious of the need to take advantage of the economic environment which undoubtedly is continuing to boom along in Taiwan. We are by no means oblivious or indifferent to that. We are doing the best we possibly can in a difficult and sensitive environment to move the issue forward.
The matter of the horseracing industry was the subject of some speculation, claim or comment in an article in this morning's Australian Financial Review. I have no further information about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —The beef quota?

—That is another issue again. If I can get any further information on that which is of any obvious utility to Senator Hill or anyone else, I will put it on the public record also as a supplementary answer.

—My question to the Minister for Resources refers to the national soil conservation program. Is it a fact that in the five years up to the 1988-89 financial year the program had spent $32m? Did the Prime Minister announce, in his environment statement of July, an increase in the program to $23.4m for the single year of 1989-90? Can the Minister advise the Senate what progress has so far been made under the program in this financial year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I can. It is true that in the five years to the end of 1988-89 the national soil conservation program had spent in total $32m on more than 400 conservation projects. It is also true that the Prime Minister, in his environment statement in July of this year, announced an allocation of $23.4m for 1989-90-a 140 per cent increase. Today I can announce that the first round of the project approvals under the national soil conservation program have been released for the year 1989-90. The advising body for allocation of those funds is the national Soil Conservation Advisory Committee. It has recommended to me-and I have announced-funding for 150 projects valued at $4.19m. Of that amount, $1.8m has been allocated to community land care groups-66 in total nationally, including five dune care groups in New South Wales. I interpolate here to say that the direction of this funding is aimed at supporting land care groups. We are looking-this is the major theme of the national soil conservation project-to start to change the attitudes of land holders to the management of the land that they have in their care and to develop local and/or regional catchment plans through land care groups in order to improve the sustainability of the land within that region. We recognise as well that technical infrastructure support is necessary-some funding has gone in that direction-together with the support that ordinarily comes from State agencies.

ANSWER.PARA: The national Soil Conservation Advisory Committee has also recognised the need for more training. There has been an allocation of over $300,000 under the public awareness education and training subprogram of the national soil conservation program. In total, 568 projects were applied for and funding totalling $24.2m sought. That indicates a massive upsurge in public interest. I believe that there is a very heartening trend towards the formation of land care groups. There is a recognition in rural and metropolitan Australia that this is indeed Australia's No. 1 environmental problem and that there is a need for ordinary Australians to work together to resolve it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I might add that I acknowledge Senator Brownhill's very positive role in this. This is the first of the two-stage release of this year's grants. In the next two weeks, I will announce a further round of funding and, if the Senate is still sitting, I will perhaps answer a question on that as well. But the next round of funding will be for research grants and they will be announced in about two weeks' time.

ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS
