TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I draw the Minister's attention to spending under the Attorney-General's portfolio on marriage education as distinct from marriage guidance. Is any consideration being given to including marriage education under adult education with the possibility of the extension of both its funds and its scope?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a question without notice from Senator Crowley on a matter which is of great concern to the Australian community and, of course, to senators. There is no doubt that it makes better sense to provide funds for education in relation to the bond of marriage and to try to prepare those Australians looking to that as their mode of relationship rather than to try to counsel them when the bond proves to be somewhat less than firm and strong as the marriage is subjected to those strains, storms and tempests which inevitably assault it. Therefore, for Senator Crowley to raise the question of marriage education is very apt. It is in the interests of all Australians that the bonds and the households which revolve around that relationship are sustained and maintained not only to serve the interests of the couple concerned in their own human development but also, if they are blessed with children, to enable those children to be raised in a household which experiences the strength, warmth and nurturing that can occur within the bounds of that very special human relationship.

ANSWER.PARA: All societies regard this relationship as extremely important. Whether it be by common law or by way of parliamentary intervention, our society is no exception to that general rule. In very recent times there has been some shift in portfolio funding of matters relating to marriage counselling to ensure that marriage education is given its proper due. Various organisations have been set up throughout Australia, sometimes under secular auspices and sometimes under the auspices of various religious organisations, to try to ensure that young Australians in particular are well prepared for entering into this relationship, sanctioned as it is by society, with all the responsibilities that accompany it. In relation to that, my area of responsibility includes responsibility for civil marriage celebrants. They have been concerned for some time that when Australians approach them about the arrangement of a ceremony they have not had the opportunity to give the couples material which would help them to prepare not only for the occasion but for the assumption of the status of a married couple in our society. I have been concerned to provide to marriage celebrants some material which they can then place in the hands of those couples who approach them.

Over the last several months the Attorney-General's Department has been working very hard to ensure that such a brochure is available to indicate to couples the sorts of education sessions which may be available in their community in order to help them prepare for this particular bond, which is so important. It is a fact that marriage within our society is under unusual strains and therefore we need to take every step to ensure that those bonds are maintained with a strength which will enable couples resiliently to face the various stages which occur during that marriage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your greatest contribution to a happy marriage is to stay single.

—As a bachelor I am not as well versed as some in this chamber in relation to the ways in which such a relationship can be sustained; but I believe that Senator Crowley has well drawn our attention to this particular factor in our society.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Accord, as recognised by the leaked New South Wales Labour Council paper, and the urgent need for the adoption of the Liberal and National Parties' Industrial Relations Policy to boost productivity as the only basis for higher real wages and a reduction in Australia's massive foreign debt burden.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a number of occasions during this session the Opposition has debated the accord and its failures and the Opposition's alternative approach. On most occasions we have had the same sort of response, usually from Senator Button but sometimes from some of Senator Button's acolytes. The response has been dismissive. The concerns which I think are felt in the community have evidently not been shared by Senator Button or by his colleagues. Many ex-Labor voters who listened to Senator Button during Question Time today-if any bothered to listen-would have heard him quibbling over which productivity measurement is relevant to the reality that he did not quibble about. He did not quibble about the fact that real wages in Australia have gone down under Labor and under the accord. He again took refuge in the defence: `It does not really matter that wages have declined because a lot more people have jobs and household disposable incomes have gone up'. There are a lot of Australians who feel very dissatisfied with the situation that household incomes have had to be maintained, that the continuance of the purchase of a house has to be saved by somebody entering the work force who may not want to enter the work force. There are a great variety of approaches in the Australian community. Some families want to be two-income families; some families would prefer to be one-income families. But under the Labor Party, there is no doubt that single-income families have been under enormous pressure.

SPEECH.PARA: That pressure has come about because of the decline in the value of average earnings in this country-not the average weekly earnings that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) tried to palm us off with, the only relevant figure being for the sole breadwinner or male earner; that is not the situation at all. If one looks at the average earnings around Australia, excluding only the farm sector as the accounts do, one finds a process of decline during the period of this Government and the accord. That process of income decline is accompanied by additional burdens, whether they are burdens of taxation or high interest rates, which have put a great number of people under enormous pressure. Whatever the attitude of Senator Button might be, there is a lot of interest in the Australian community in seeing something done about this. People want to see a situation where they can look forward to increased real earnings rather than the reverse.

I dismiss the quibble of the Leader of the Government about precisely which measure of productivity the Senate should be debating. He took refuge in his question and referred me to the preference of the Business Council of Australia for total factor productivity. I pointed out in a subsequent question that total factor productivity is shown by the figures which are, no doubt, supplied by his Government to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development to be in a continuing process of decline over the period 1987 through to the present time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Everywhere.

—It is not everywhere. That is not true, and I am happy to incorporate the table from which I am quoting, from the Economic Outlook of December 1988, which shows that it is not true that there is a decline everywhere. The figures for 1987-1990 show that the only other countries with declining total factor productivity are Denmark and Canada. Finland, Greece, Ireland, the Netherlands, Norway, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, and all of the other countries listed, show an increase. Therefore, the Minister's interjection is incorrect. I do not think the Minister, in his response, has denied the fact that the average earnings of Australians have declined. Let me again quote the figures from the Treasury Economic Round-up of October 1989 which show that in 1983-84 there was a decline of minus 2.5 per cent. There was a slight increase of 0.8 per cent the following year; a decline of 1.9 per cent the following year; a decline of 1.4 per cent in 1986-87. In 1987-88, there was another decline, and a 0.1 per cent increase in 1988-89. I make the point again that on the Budget figures it would appear very likely that there will be a further decline in the average weekly earnings of Australians during the current financial year.

SPEECH.PARA: The truth is that that is inevitable unless the businesses, the factories and the enterprises of Australia produce more per person employed. I refer to the economic commentary by David Potts in the Australian today:

But the most depressing thing of all is that, despite all the ballyhoo about the greatness of the Government's accord with the unions, productivity is falling. In the year to the September quarter, GDP per hours worked fell 0.9 per cent.
He goes on a little later to say:

It's all very well to say that the difference between the coming recession and previous ones is that there hasn't been a wages explosion-and even then you have to differentiate between the Australian norm and the standards of industrialised countries-but falling productivity is just as serious.
At this rate Australia will come out of the recession even less competitive than when it entered.

In the face of this continual criticism from the Opposition about the weakness of the economic fundamentals in this country and the devastating impact that is having in the cities, suburbs and towns of Australia, we get a dismissive approach from the Government, and an attitude that the criticism is partial, that it is solely political, and that the Opposition is not putting forward realistic alternatives.

It is in that context that the Opposition is delighted to have access to the report which officers of the New South Wales Labor Council wrote for the purposes of internal discussion within that Council-comments which have been dismissed today by Senator Button, who is at the table, as not being the views of the Labor Council. However, they represent the views of loyal servants of the Labor movement, prepared for the operations and consideration of that council. They are significant because they demonstrate the difference between the public lies which are told in this matter and the private truth which is admitted whenever one sits down and talks to these people sensibly.

Between now and the Federal election all people in the Labor movement-whether it is Senator Button, with his passing reputation for honesty, or his rougher colleagues, or the leaders of the trade union movement-will claim that the Opposition is confrontationist, that it is promoting a free-for-all in industrial relations, and that things are proceeding satisfactorily. Mr Kelty said the other day that Australia is a country which is on track when in fact the people of Australia and those making the claims know that that is not true.

In terms of the alleged confrontationist stance of the Opposition on industrial relations, I remind the Senate that when we issued our policy just a year ago-a rewrite of the policy that we had issued in 1986-a notable trade unionist, who no longer has a vested interest in trying to preach a public lie in the interests of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Charles Fitzgibbon, wrote as an independent columnist in the Australian Financial Review. Giving his judgment of the Opposition's approach to industrial relations, he said:

It is now generally accepted that productivity, especially in the manufacturing sector, is the key to balancing our society between its rural commodity, mining commodity and manufacturing roles, in making that sector internationally competitive; and that the best way of doing that is by forgetting the `them and us' concept and instead forging an overall unity at an enterprise level.
He went on to say:
Whether everyone in the community likes it or not, we are moving towards a more market-oriented system of wage determination.
Mr Fitzgibbon went on to say:
So, many of the matters covered in the policy document-
that is, the Liberal-National Party policy document-
are already under development-thus it will certainly be possible for the authors to refer to events and say, `There you are . . . we were right'.

In the document which appeared on the scene last Thursday night there was an analysis, which of itself is probably not perfect-it cannot be put forward as some sort of infallible guide to industrial relations-but it represents the labours of a number of employees of the Labor movement; a number of employees of the New South Wales Labor Council. It is interesting to see what their private assessment is because at the same time as the private assessment is being produced the New South Wales Labor Council is advertising in New South Wales in the confrontationist terms which are being promoted by Mr Kelty and parliamentary Labor Party spokesmen. Referring to the post-1987 election period, this is what the New South Wales Labor Council stated, through its officials, in the document:

Now, nearly three years later, the `bacon' has clearly not been brought home, interest rates are sitting at 17 per cent and there is little likelihood of an imminent fall, real incomes have fallen further, the foreign debt and trade deficit have worsened with no signs of an early recovery, unemployment is set to rise on the back of the growth recession we are now moving into, our international credit rating has been further cut, the government is clearly looking strained and tired . . .
The Council went on to say:
. . . most importantly, the Federal Opposition has finally got its act together . . .

The Council went on to point out that the Opposition is extremely serious about industrial relations. Indeed, it went on to say that there are so many people in the wings waiting to take my job that it is unlikely that I will hold it. My response to that part of the report is that one of the best things Australia has going for it at the moment is the total determination of the people on the opposition benches, and the people who will be occupying the government benches after the next election, to see reform of Australia's industrial relations system. The people mentioned in the report-whether it is Senator Stone, Dr Hewson or Mr Howard, or people coming into Parliament; I refer to Peter Costello and Ian McLachlan-will simply add to the determination which already exists in the parliamentary Opposition parties to see basic reform of industrial relations in this country. I for one welcome the absolute determination on the part of the Opposition to make this a central focus of its policy and a central focus for change in the way Australia is run. As the people of Australia know, it is in changing the way that we work and ensuring that we work together productively that we will solve our problems of declining living standards and increasing public debt. There is one thing in the report which I quibble with. It states:
As Chaney sees it, under the conservatives the aim will be for much lower wage outcomes than in recent years.

Our policy is for at last getting real wage increases in the economy based on increased productivity. What the accord has produced-I have already given the specific figures; not from the Liberal and National parties but from the national accounts-is declining real incomes for the Australian work force. The only way to reverse that is to have a productivity break-out. Our policy is about achieving that. The report goes on to state:
The trade union movement-must seriously and urgently reassess its strategy to face a new and potentially devastating environment.

It states that the whole approach has to be reconsidered. It talks about the dissatisfaction of workers with their unions because of declining living standards. The report states that workers are voting for change irrespective of the politics of the leadership team because they are concerned at the failures of the trade union movement. The report states, and this is relevant to the point that the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, keeps making in response to my pleas about lower wages being imposed on the Australian work force:
Many workers no doubt resent the fact that they or their spouses have to take second or part-time (often low paid) jobs to keep up with inflation and ballooning interest rates.

All honourable senators would know that there is resentment in significant sectors of the community because a significant number of women who have young children have been forced back into the work force for no other reason than the need to maintain a roof over the family's heads. That is not seen as a great triumph of the accord in the way that it seems to be seen as a triumph by Senator Button. I point out the passage in the report which completely reflects what the Opposition has been saying over and over again:
Productivity increases have not been forthcoming under the Accord and therefore real wage growth is impossible under the current system.

That is precisely the point that we have made over and over again. That is precisely why we need to focus industrial relations much more tightly on the enterprise so that productivity can be lifted. It is no good the Minister at the table continually quoting the isolated examples where there has been productivity improvement-for example, in the steel industry. The number of people employed in the steel industry has been halved. Of course there has been a lift in productivity. It was essential if the Australian steel industry was to survive.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a result of huge investment and government subsidies.

—That is right. I accept Senator Baume's interjection. The whole point is that that high profile improvement, that episodic example which can be given and repeated, sits very oddly against the overall statistics of declining productivity and real wages. What the officers had to say about it is instructive. They said:

SPEECH.PARA: The decline in real unit labour costs is regarded by many as a positive outcome of the Accord. In the short term, to the extent that it encourages new investment this is correct. However, the decline in real units labour costs has negative aspects . . .

The document talks about the reduction of pressure on employers to replace labour with capital. I say this to the Leader of the Government, the Senate and the business community: whilst we can point to a recovery of the profit share under the accord-and that is a positive thing-who believes that we will maintain an improved profit share on the basis of continuous declines in the wages of workers? Mr Acting Deputy President, you will take part in this debate later. I would be interested to hear whether you believe that an enhanced profit share, which is a proper objective of the Government and something to be welcomed, can be achieved permanently on the basis of permanent reductions in real wages. I think I know what your answer would be, Mr Acting Deputy President. Certainly I know what it would be in private. I am less sure what your answer would be in this debate.

The whole point about the report from the New South Wales Labour Council is that it analyses in great detail the basic failures of the accord; the basic failure of the trade union movement, and the Government itself, to come to grips with the fact that the trade union structure is inappropriate to Australia's needs; and the need to reverse some of the major elements of policy which have been pursued by both the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Government. In terms of trade union structure, this is stark. As is said on page 12 of this report:
The key point is that for the approach to be effective it requires smaller units, not larger ones.

This is following a discussion about the fact that Mr Kelty, supported by this Government, has advocated a series of very large unions. Yet those very large unions will not produce the workplace focus which is required if we are to get higher productivity in Australia.

What is it in practical terms that the Opposition is saying? What we are saying is that, in an honest debate, the common ground which has developed about the need for a greater enterprise focus would lead the Government to embrace many of the propositions which are being put forward by the Opposition. We in no way wish to step in the way of, or to impede, changes such as the second tier wage negotiations or award restructuring, which may lead to a more flexible, centralised wage fixing system. But we do say that there are opportunities to accelerate the pace of change and to provide the genuine freedom which will enable employers and employees to achieve decent results. We say, for example, that as well as having a more flexible award system and a system of registered agreements, both of which the Government would agree with, the position should be made even more flexible by also opening up the possibility of having agreements which are outside the system entirely.

We say that that would prevent the sort of sabotage of positive measures which we have seen in cases like the Castle Bacon case and the Sanctuary Cove case, where attempts by employers and employees to work together within the system have been held up for years by the use of the centralised system to try to prevent agreements being put into effect. We believe that the availability of voluntary agreements, giving employers and employees an additional element of choice, will provide a greater flexibility and a greater capacity to lift Australian productivity.

With respect to trade union structure, we say that it is clearly proven that the approach that has been adopted by Mr Kelty is simply inadequate. It has been demonstrated that the sorts of amalgamations that he has been promoting will not lead to to a reduction in the multiplicity of unions within workplaces, which is one of the major causes of inefficiency and one of the major impediments to a greater enterprise focus. All that we are saying is that it is possible to speed up a process-which otherwise could be adopted by pursuing some sort of industry or enterprise award; things which can be done under the present system-if we provide employees with a capacity to choose their representation in a way which is relevant to achieving a single enterprise bargaining unit.

In a recent speech by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) we heard him embracing the idea of having single enterprise bargaining units. What we say is that the practical amendments being proposed by the Opposition, which would give employees choice in this matter, would facilitate a process of change which the Government acknowledges is required and which I think the trade union movement is coming to acknowledge is required.

This is an area of Australian life, of the Australian economy, which we know will be highly politicised over the coming months. That is a tragedy for Australia because there is a growing understanding of what is required on all sides of politics. It is a pity that the Government is going to engage in what I would call ratbag politics to prevent sensible proposals for reform from being properly considered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is easy to try to box in a government by accusing it of ratbag politics before one has even started. Anybody who disagrees with Senator Chaney immediately falls into the ratbag category. There are some things I do not disagree with him about. I do not disagree with him about people being offered additional choice. I do not disagree with him about the necessity of lifting productivity. I do not disagree with him that it would be desirable to have industry or enterprise based unions in some circumstances, rather than a mixed conglomerate of craft unions. I say to him, as he said to me in his speech, that it is no good trotting out these three cases-the Dollar Sweets case, the Castle Bacon case and so on-every time he makes his speech and saying that I cannot trot out three cases on the other side where there have been enormous improvements in productivity. He trots out the same three cases every time; I am entitled to the same four. One cannot really start a debate by trying to exclude some of the grounds of the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I think I ought to make a point right at the beginning. In terms of this issue of productivity and so on in the workplace, it should be remembered that the trade union movement currently represents about 33 per cent of employees in the private sector in Australia. We always talk about this in terms of productivity and the gains which can be made in the productive sector of the economy and we tend to ignore the fact that trade unions are much more heavily involved in the government sector, both State and Federal, where productivity does not seem to be an issue which grips the popular imagination, or certainly that of the work force, quite as much as it does in the private sector. I think it is right that that should be so, but I think we should be absolutely sure about the facts in relation to the trade union movement's involvement.

I have said numerous times in this place that the accord has to be a flexible instrument, an instrument which expands from the edges, as it were. We have talked about the importance of certified agreements, and Senator Chaney talks about agreements outside the system. An agreement outside the system at Dollar Sweets is all right from my perspective, but I am not sure what an agreement outside the system would mean at the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd or in the car plants of this country. If the test is to be productivity of an agreement outside the system, as I said earlier, the wage increase at BHP should be 35 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what I said.

—I did not say that the honourable senator had said it. I said that, if the test is to be productivity outside the system, one would expect a wage increase at BHP of some 35 per cent. That would not be a good thing for BHP, I would expect. So if things happen outside the system we come back to the argument, which we have had again and again and which I do not think one can really resolve by our debating it here, that governments have to be concerned about aggregate wage outcomes. Wages policy is a very important instrument for governments in the current economy. I do not disagree with Senator Chaney about all the sorts of desirable goals he sees. The question is: How are they to be attained? What Senator Chaney is saying today is that we ought to go a bit faster. `Can we walk a little faster?', said the tortoise to the snail. `There is something close behind me and it is treading on my tail'. I suppose that is Senator Chaney's role in a debate such as this. But that is a matter of judgment in terms of the importance one attaches to aggregate wage outcomes and the role which the centralised wage fixation system plays in all that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberals tend to have it a bit both ways. I do not wish to quote Mr Peacock every day, but when he was asked the other day whether there would be a centralised wage fixation system or direct enterprise negotiations if a Liberal government were elected-which would take predominance-he said, `Who is to know?'. In that, he reiterates Senator Chaney's view expressed last week-in a more sophisticated form, if I might say so.

The cause of this matter of public importance today is this document by two officers of the New South Wales Labor Council, which I understand to be a document designed to provoke thought in a discussion-`What do you do about this?', `What do you do about that?', `Yes, that is a fair enough document'. It certainly did provoke some thought, having been leaked. But if, every time we get a little support for Senator Chaney's industrial relations policy by junior clerks of the Labor Council or from somewhere else, we have a matter of public importance on the basis of that, we will be here until long after Christmas. There is support for Senator Chaney's view from about 20 per cent of the population and about 20 per cent of the business community. There will always be little documents coming out supporting that view. Senator Chaney's matter of public importance today reminds me of these people who write to luminaries around the world and say, `I have a very good idea, Professor Einstein', or `I have a very good idea, President Bush; what do you think of my idea?'. The people being nice people, write back, and say, `Thank you for your letter, Mr Smith; I think it is a very good idea'. Of course they write back and say that.

Senator Chaney is using this Mickey Mouse endorsement for his policies from the Labor Council of New South Wales as a means for burdening honourable senators with the same matter of public importance yet again. He then goes for the, I think, very good rhetorical point of psyching up his own side. He says, `We are absolutely determined. All of these people on the opposition benches are determined, and, just in case we are not, we will have Peter Costello and all of these people in here after the next election and that will make sure we are absolutely determined. That will give us the part of our anatomy which we have generally lacked for the last seven or eight years. That will help us with that part of our anatomy which we have not had for the past seven or eight years'.

So Peter Costello and all of those people are coming in here to give the coalition a bit more spine. Yet the one person whom Senator Chaney does not mention, for the purpose of his argument, who is coming in here to help him with all of that is of course Ian McLachlan from the National Farmers Federation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did mention him.

—I do not think the honourable senator did, but maybe he did. Mr McLachlan has been quoted over the weekend as saying, `Well, if a conservative government were elected in this country it might have to implement a wages freeze'. He spends all his time talking about the importance of enterprise bargaining. How on earth could a wage freeze be implemented if there were enterprise bargaining throughout the country? What would be the mechanism for having a wages freeze in the country? The coalition would have to tell all of those weak employers around the place whose work force would be clamouring for more wages, `Fellows, you have to resist them. We are having a wages freeze under this new, you-beaut government that we have in Australia now'. How on earth would the coalition implement a wages freeze? That is how much Mr McLachlan understands about the relationship between a centralised wage fixation system and enterprise bargaining.

SPEECH.PARA: This issue is said to be the key piece, the linchpin, of the Liberal-National party economic strategy which was handed down-I do not know how long ago, it seems a long time, but it is probably a month or two ago. It is a bit messy, even when explained by its most articulate exponent, because it relies on comfortable cliches such as `We all need more productivity; we are in favour of people working harder; these are the things that will make Australia great; Australians know that they are not earning their keep in the big wide world'. That is the sort of philosophical base for this strategy. These are the sorts of comfortable cliches that the coalition is using. It then launches into a discussion about how to fix the economy up and it is not quite sure about that.

Senator Chaney has been citing a lot of figures today. If one looks at productivity growth in Australia compared with other countries from 1960 to 1973-these figures are taken from a paper, `Interim national comparisons of productivity growth', published in May 1988-one can see that in the 1960s Australia's total factor productivity was 2.1 per cent. In the years 1960 to 1973 the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) average was 2.8 per cent. In 1973 to 1979 the total factor productivity in Australia was 0.6 per cent; the OECD average was 0.7 per cent. In 1979 to 1986 total factor productivity in Australia was 0.5 per cent; the OECD average was 0.6 per cent. From that one can see that right throughout that period of history we have always been hanging in there at just a point below the OECD average.

Senator Chaney refers to forecasts for 1987 to 1990. I say to Senator Chaney that when one looks at the figures at the end of this period one will see that they will reflect exactly the same sort of pattern, in my view, as they have since 1960. That is to say, when award restructuring and the surge in capital investments which are now happening are taken into account, when one looks at these figures in another two or three years time, one will get exactly the same pattern as there has always been. The adverse characteristic of productivity growth in Australia in the last few years has been that it cannot really be measured in the service sector. There has been enormous growth in the work force in Australia over that period and that makes it very difficult to measure productivity.

That brings us back to the debate about whether a proper measure of standard of living is real wages or whether it is household disposable income. We have a disagreement about that. All I can say is that in terms of real wages, as long as I have been a Minister, the Liberal Party has said that every wage case increase should not have been allowed and that it would have opposed it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are talking about money wages now, aren't you?
—Yes, I am. It affects real wages.
—It cannot affect it adversely.

—That is true. Throughout that period that has been so. When Mr McLachlan, the new hero, comes in here he will have a wage freeze. How he will implement it I do not know; but that is his scenario. What happens if the Liberal-National party system falls to bits-if it does not work? What will Mr McLachlan do? He says that the coalition will have a wage freeze. That is the sort of context in which that debate must be seen.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney went on to say at great length that the Government would claim that the Opposition would be confrontationist in its approach if elected to government. I do not know whether or not that is true. I cannot say. I am sure that some of the men of steel who are coming in here, as Senator Chaney has mentioned, would tend to be confrontationist. They have a pretty good record in respect of that. But one only needs to look at the way in which Senator Stone has mellowed since he came into this chamber. I thought that he would go right through this place like a steam engine, confronting everybody. I thought that there would be no mercy for us when he arrived here. But he has mellowed and turned into a genial old senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —He doesn't like the `old'. He is not old. He is a young man.

—Senator Boswell should keep out of this debate. He has been very naughty in the past few weeks. He knows what happened on Saturday. He should be up there burning brown paper bags. Senator Stone has been much less confrontationist than one might have imagined. That could happen to the others when they come into this Parliament, if they do so, after the next election. I suppose that one or two of those fellows could win. But I do not know about that.

SPEECH.PARA: Other people are saying that the coalition is likely to be confrontationist. Other people say, `We do not know how this system is going to work'. Senator Chaney got the message from the Chamber of Automotive Industries last week. He got the message from the Metal Trades Industry Association a week or two before that and I think if he had intelligently read the documents from the Business Council of Australia he would probably have got one or two messages from the as well. Mr Easton said that the coalition will be confrontationist. At the weekend the abashed Mr Easton put out a document saying that the coalition would be a confrontationist lot.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has just confronted his junior officer.

—He said that about the Liberal alternative if that Party ever gets into power in Australia. I am not saying that necessarily. I am saying that other people say that. Other people are very concerned about the way the coalition's proposed wage fixing system would operate, and what it would do to the Australian economy, to the good work which has been done under this Government in building consultation and trust in the work force and to all of the good work which goes to make up what one can call, for the purpose of this debate, factor productivity. The important things which all go to making very big changes to productivity are things like changes in concerns about quality, production techniques, work force attitudes, industrial disputation and skills of the work force. I regard those things as important and believe they can be enhanced under the environment encouraged by the Government. I do not in any sense say that there is not room for improvement in increasing the capacity of people to enter into certified agreements and things of that kind; there is room for improvement in work practices in some areas and in making more efficient use of infrastructure and so on. All these things go to improving the productivity of Australian firms and industries as a whole.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot avoid referring to some very good examples of management initiatives. They must take account of all the issues of skill training and reduction in industrial disputation, using infrastructure better, and using the work force better. Through management initiatives companies like BHP Steel, Tubemakers of Australia Ltd, BTR Nylex Ltd, and Southern Aluminium are making the way in terms of improved productivity in Australia, improving the outlook for all Australians. I do not resist the proposition that in the longer term the success of this country, the well-being of all its inhabitants, its businesses, its work force and so on will depend to a very large extent on improving the productive capacity of the country. There is no doubt about that. That is where we have lagged for the last 15 years. That is where all the issues of structural adjustment now become important, because we had lazy governments that did not do anything about them.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have to have structural adjustment of the union movement. That is the key point. It is going the wrong way, as this document recognises very clearly.

—Senator Stone will get his chance later. I am making a speech about a particular issue; he wants to make a speech about another issue. He can do that later. I am simply making the point that these structural adjustments are very important in improving the productive capacity of the Australian work force and so on. The examples I gave of BTR Nylex, Tubemakers and the other firms I mentioned are very important.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney also referred, both at Question Time and thereafter, to the measure of productivity. I repeat the view that gross domestic product (GDP) per hour worked is not a reliable measure of productivity and it certainly does not lead to any implications for the likely movement in real wages. A number of authorities take that view. The Australian Bureau of Statistics, the ABS, stated in its bulletin on productivity measures that the measure it uses, GDP per hour worked, in the table that Senator Chaney referred me to does not make any adjustment for the quality of labour used, skills and things of that kind. The Government's wages policy does that, which is one of the reasons we will get a better productivity performance in the next few years. As I said, this debate has been recycled on numerous occasions.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will have it again.

—Senator Chaney and Senator Stone are persistent in the face of great adversity. The Opposition will go on losing the debate, but for goodness sake I ask that the Opposition not use every conceivable excuse it might have to come in here and have a matter of public importance on it, as it did today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating as a matter of public importance the proposition proposed by Senator Chaney, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Accord, as recognised by the leaked New South Wales Labour Council paper, and the urgent need need for the adoption of the Liberal and National Parties' Industrial Relations Policy to boost productivity as the only basis for higher real wages and a reduction in Australia's massive foreign debt burden.

The subject of this matter of public importance cannot help but produce a feeling of deja vu. As Senator Button has said, this must be the third or fourth time that the Opposition has raised virtually the same subject and there is very little left to say that has not already been said. Senator Stone has indicated that we will debate it yet again; so be it.

The so-called leaked paper, which originated in the New South Wales Labor Council and about which the Opposition is now making such a fuss, appears to all intents and purposes to be a sign of dissatisfaction from a couple of employees at the Labor Council, which was leaked to the press in a fit of destructiveness. It is another example, perhaps, of the way in which the Australian Labor Party (ALP) has internecine warfare down to a fine art. However, it has been able to pull its act together in recent times. Hopefully this will not be typical of what will be forthcoming in the next few months. Despite this, the paper has the ring of truth about several of its assertions. Both wages and living standards are dropping under the accord and foreign debt is still rising at an alarming rate. Until a government of any persuasion, Labor or coalition, is willing to infuriate its rich friends by changing the tax laws, that will continue to be the case.

The Opposition's industrial relations policy, which is intimately linked to its wages policy, has come under the spotlight in recent times-times which have seen the likes of Mr Ian McLachlan and even Mr Peacock unsure of the likely direction of the economy under the control of the coalition. There is certainly a degree of uncertainty about what the impact and economic outcomes of the revised industrial relations policy and the wages policy would be. The coalition's unconstrained industrial relations policy would see Australia adopting the Sir Roderick Carnegie solution to our economic problems. In the opinion of the Australian Democrats, it would see unemployment in the blue-collar sector explode while allowing those in high technology communications-based sectors such as banking, broadcasting and computer development to receive unacceptably high pay increases. This would result in a huge gap emerging between major sectors of the Australian community, with those in highly paid and challenging employment being, as the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) calls them, the information rich, and the rest of the community employed in deskilled, poorly paid employment at best, or at worst depending completely upon the state for their well-being.

The less well off in our society also need an industrial relations system which will ensure them an adequate level of financial reward and satisfaction from their employment. There is no doubt in the minds of the Australian Democrats that the alternative model, the Opposition's industrial relations policy, would be one with a bias towards those who are well placed to exploit enterprise bargaining. Conversely, it is in the interests of the general community that we have an industrial relations system that ensures that those industries experiencing a shortage of skilled labour do not bid themselves out of their potential international competitiveness, since this is clearly linked to the element in the economy which is cited in the matter of public importance, namely, our exploding international debt.

Mr Ian McLachlan, the guru of the Liberal Party's Drizabone policies, states that `the enterprise bargaining section would become self-regulatory'. This statement makes a mockery of the coalition's claim that enterprise-based contracts would not have significant flow-on effects. The reality is that, in a system that lacks any policy of containment, spillage is absolutely inevitable. Unfortunately, it is spillage that would enable the yuppies to continue spending extravagantly on overseas luxury goods and service high interest rates, while the general community would continue to suffer through the extraordinarily high interest rates which are not likely to come down within the foreseeable future, as has been admitted by even Senator Stone, although we are being tantalised--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what I said; I said `within the first month of taking office'.

—Senator Stone can correct me later in his speech, by all means. Australian Labor Party and Liberal-National party policies on high interest rates are virtually the same. The substance of this matter of public importance is that a Liberal-National party industrial relations system would produce higher wages, higher living standards, and a significant reduction in our foreign debt; that is the proposition that has been advanced to us here today by Senator Chaney. The Opposition is saying that Australian workers and trade unions are entitled to have high expectations when dealing with a coalition government in an enterprise-based industrial relations system. It is this element of high expectations that we need to be alerted to. These expectations cannot possibly be fulfilled without many other changes in taxation, tariffs and economic policy generally. We do not believe that the coalition would be willing to make these changes-the ALP Government has certainly been unwilling to make them during its term of government. The level of expectation is a potentially dangerous element of the alternative model of industrial relations proposed by the coalition.

SPEECH.PARA: The unease and confusion that have been expressed by some members of the New South Wales Labor Council towards the apparent lack of ALP guidance in industrial relations is understandable. The labour movement has been forsaken by the ALP, which has failed to deal effectively with the issues of labour market reform. It is on record that since 1981 the Australian Democrats have pursued an industrial relations policy of employee participation and direct negotiation-a policy which would allow for the development of enterprise-based bargaining to occur within the control of an industry-based award overseen by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Unfortunately, it has taken the ALP until 1989 to start to adopt the industrial relations system for which we have been calling for almost a decade. We are pleased to see that it is finally happening.

In another recent debate on industrial relations, I mentioned an article by Paul Kelly in the Australian newspaper. That article contained what Paul Kelly called the `shocking news' that enterprise wage deals were inevitable. In his article, Paul Kelly observed:
The irony this week-
that is, about two weeks ago now-
is that while Mr Hawke was slamming the coalition for its obsession with labour market deregulation, Mr Keating was actually promising to pinch this Liberal policy.

And to whom was the Treasurer (Mr Keating) making the promise? To the Japanese investors who have kindly lent us 18.9 per cent of our gross debt. Japan is our biggest single creditor country. If the Japanese decide not to roll-over-that is to re-lend our debt when it falls due-Australia will immediately become a banana republic. Our foreign debt will not be reduced drastically by any actions within the industrial relations system.

Outside forces exert a massive influence on the size and manageability of our foreign debt. It is very important that the Japanese financial institutions which have lent money to Australia should be willing to re-lend because 85 per cent of our $137 billion foreign debt needs to be repaid or refinanced within three months. If the Japanese are edgy about lending to Australia following the collapse of Qintex, and maybe some other companies, the Australia of the last 50 years will disappear overnight, to be replaced by an Argentine-type economy. These are the realities of the foreign debt fiasco which we have on our hands.

So here we have the three political parties-Liberal, Labor and National-which have happily handed over our economic sovereignty to the international marketplace through deregulation, bickering about which one of them would be the most efficient deregulator of our labour market. The Hawke Government and the Peacock conservatives have created a situation where we have to do everything demanded by our foreign creditors. The foreign creditors demand labour market deregulation and the Liberal-Labor-National grand coalition tells Australians that we must deregulate the labour market. They neglect to tell us that it is necessary only because they got us into this mess in the first place and they do not have the courage to get us out of it. They want us to believe that we must go on borrowing and living beyond our means and that our foreign creditors will never pull the plug on Australia because we are their friends and allies. We recently witnessed Mr Keating running off to Tokyo to tell the Japanese that they can have whatever they want provided they keep lending to us. This should make all Australians stop and think, especially Australian unionists. The odds are that the Hawke-Keating Labor Government will steal more Liberal-National Party policies, that our foreign debt will continue to mount and that our living standards will continue to drop. They will drop just as quickly under a Liberal-National Party government.

We have all heard that the conservatives intend to take people off the unemployment benefit after nine months. The Australian Democrats believe that the Labor Government, if returned after the next election, will do the same thing. Perhaps it will be more generous and choose 12 months before it removes the unemployment benefit. It could then say to its supporters, who are concerned about equity and income distribution, that it is more caring than the conservatives. On the other hand, perhaps the Treasurer feels the need to demonstrate a really macho attitude to placate the Japanese and will insist upon the unemployment benefit being cut after six months. Whichever of the two conservative alternatives is elected to government, the result will be a deregulated labour market with little, if any, minimum wage restrictions.

This could, at worst, produce a real banana republic-a country where 30 per cent of the population would become servants to the 20 or 30 per cent lucky enough to have a job and a decent wage. These people would be forced to work for whatever pay is available with no social security safety net and nowhere to live. This could create a class of cheap servants willing to work ridiculous hours for little more than food and shelter. Like any other banana republic worth its name, Australia would be a society where some of its citizens would be forced to live on the streets and starve or work as servants for the lucky.

Even the right to strike is no longer guaranteed to Australian workers, and neither the Opposition nor the so-called Labor Party wants to have anything to do with guaranteeing Australian workers that right. The Democrats will be very interested in the response of both the Government and the Opposition to my private member's Bill on the right to strike, which will be brought before the chamber in the very near future.

Ordinary Australian wage earners, pensioners, home buyers, rural producers and small businessmen have already experienced a decline in living standards through the expenditure cutting and high interest rate policies of this Government. We are told that Australians must suffer to reduce our foreign debt. But whose foreign debt is it? Private sector debt accounts for well over half our level of foreign indebtedness. The Bonds, Elliotts and Murdochs of our society borrow overseas and ordinary Australians are forced to tighten their belts because `we' are borrowing too much. We are not borrowing too much; they are borrowing too much. Those who borrow overseas should be asked to pay for it-not pensioners and home buyers.

The Australian Democrats acknowledge that the continued development of an effective and flexible labour market remains vital to the economic future of Australia. This development must, however, occur incrementally and not be imposed upon the economy in an ad hoc, irrational way. The continued development of industry-based unionism provides the economy with the opportunity to continue to restructure while avoiding any further inequalities emerging in the economy and will ensure our international competitiveness. It is obvious that workers in high technology industries, such as computer electronics and software, will be in an elite position and, under a completely deregulated enterprise-based labour market, would be able to bid up the cost of their services if there were not a central agreement around which their awards or pay increases were dependent. The wages explosion that would result in these industries would prove to be damaging to the Australian economy and would undermine our export potential.

There is a real need to retain government control over wages and industrial relations through an industry-based union structure so that minimum income levels are protected, small businesses are not held to ransom in times of labour shortages and our export competitiveness is protected. Greater labour flexibility provides benefits to the worker through reskilling and greater job satisfaction and choice; it provides benefits to the employer through the potential increase in profit levels and greater control over employment agreements; and it provides benefits to the community through greater economic potential. These benefits can occur only in an environment of equity and democracy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating a matter of public importance placed before the Senate by Senator Chaney, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Accord, as recognised by the leaked New South Wales Labour Council paper, and the urgent need for the adoption of the Liberal and National Parties' Industrial Relations Policy to boost productivity as the only basis-
I repeat `the only basis'-
for higher real wages and a reduction in Australia's massive foreign debt burden.

In the course of earlier speakers' remarks one or two comments were made to which I just want to pay some passing attention. I was interested, for example, to hear Senator Button making the point, which is totally correct, that today the trade union movement is much more public service oriented than it is private sector oriented. Senator Button confessed-I think he slightly exaggerated-that only 33 per cent of the private work force is now in trade unions. We all know that about 67 per cent of the public sector work force is in trade unions. There is a very large and increasing importance of what I might call the public service mentality operating upon trade union policies. Senator Button, inadvertently I think, was giving the game away in making that remark.

I was disappointed in Senator Button's attitude towards this extraordinarily interesting document-I do not say that in any provocative way, but in a quite detached, objective manner-which has emanated from the New South Wales Labour Council. It was leaked to the press and published in recent days. Senator Button sought to dismiss it in a contemptuous manner by referring to it as the product of two junior clerks. No doubt we will find out in due course who the two authors of this document are, but if the New South Wales Labor Council has in its employ two junior clerks capable of putting together a document of such high quality analysis and intellectual content as this, then it is an extraordinarily fortunate body. I only wish the same could be said for the Labor Government.

Senator Button, in a characteristically scathing manner, dismissed the document as a Mickey Mouse endorsement of the Opposition's industrial relations policies. At least he did not attempt to quibble that it is certainly a ringing endorsement of the Opposition's industrial relations policies. He may choose to describe it as a Mickey Mouse endorsement, but this document will be read, before we are through in the next few months, all around the land. It will not be seen as a Mickey Mouse endorsement because it rings true. It comes from the heart and, importantly, from the mind of the people who wrote it.

SPEECH.PARA: The future of the industrial relations scene in this country happens to be one of the most important, if not the most important, policy matter before the Australian people today. Almost nothing can be more important than that. Upon that will largely turn the ability of the Australian people to gain and attain a rise in their own real standards of living and also will turn and depend the ability of this country to cease getting into this foreign debt trap into which this Government has been leading us at a headlong pace ever since it came into office. Senator McLean quite properly referred-I want to take this opportunity to agree with him on this-to Mr Keating running off to Tokyo a couple of weeks ago to tell the Japanese that they can have anything they want as long as they keep lending to us. I agree with Senator McLean; he is quite right. That is the situation we have in this country today. The Treasurer of this country is so beholden to foreign lenders that he has to go to Tokyo and say to them the kind of things that Senator McLean has just referred to.

The motion before us refers to the failure of the accord. I do not propose to devote very much time to those words. The accord has failed and I think it is clear to every independent observer. What are the objectives in an industrial relations policy? They are to attain a rise in real wages-not a rise in money wages. Anyone can get rises in money wages and have them eaten up again the day after by equivalent rises in inflation. People in this country, and other countries, are interested in a rise in the real purchasing power of their wages and salaries. That is the individual's point of view. From a national point of view, all Australians are, and should be, interested in improving the competitiveness of this country so that we can once again begin to pay our way in the world instead of having to pay our way by borrowing the difference.

What have been the outcomes of almost seven years of a Hawke-Keating Government? As Senator Chaney very properly remarked, we have had a fall in the real earnings of wage and salary earners in this country for every year but one during the life of the Hawke Labor Government. Senator Button, quite innocently and inadvertently, admitted that the reason for that has to do with the system of industrial relations which this Government, with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) as its partner, has imposed on us. Senator Button said, and I wrote it down as I was so astonished by the slip, `real wages have fallen'-in every year except one under the Government-`because of the operation of a centralised wage system'. He is quite right. That is why they have fallen. He appeared to be making a boast of that and claiming credit for it. What he apparently failed to understand is that that is the greatest single indictment of the Government during its term of office, and the centralised industrial relations and wage system, which is the central feature of the so-called accord between the Australian Labor Party and the ACTU. That is the result. Real wages have fallen because of the operation of a centralised wage system. It is the centralised wage system and all that goes with it in the accord that has led to the deplorable record on productivity. Senator Button tried to weave his way around that admission by saying that household disposable income has risen in most years under the present Government. We have not got time to go into that apparent conundrum today. I suggest if one is looking for the answer to that one might ask by how much our foreign debt has expanded during the time of the present Government. I can tell you the answer to that: it is about $87 billion in net terms. That might explain why the Government has been able to see household disposable incomes rising at the same time as real wages and productivity have been falling. We have been borrowing ourselves blind.

The proposal goes on to refer to the urgent need for the adoption of the Liberal-National Party industrial relations policy to boost productivity as the only basis for higher real wages and the reduction in Australia's massive foreign debt burden. That is un- deniable. It is the only basis. There is no way the people of this country can pay themselves, or be paid in real terms, more than they are actually producing other than by continuing to borrow from foreigners. As I have said, the facts have been stated by Senator Chaney. No matter how much Senator Button wants to quibble about the basis of the measurement of productivity, whatever basis he chooses, the result is still the same. This remarkable document from the New South Wales Labor Council proves that again and again. The central passage on the first page of this paper states:
Now, nearly three years later,-
that is, three years since the last election-

the `bacon' has clearly not been brought home, interest rates are sitting at 17 per cent and there is little likelihood of an imminent fall, real incomes have fallen further, the foreign debt and trade deficit have worsened with no signs of an early recovery, unemployment is set to rise on the back of the growth recession we are now moving into,-
a new point but one which will attain a good deal more prominence in the months ahead of us-

our international credit rating has been further cut, the government is clearly looking strained and tired, the ALP state branches have reduced the degrees of policy freedom in terms of fiscal policy and privatisation, the Accord has reached the limits of its capacity to assist in flexible adjustment to continuing economic change and pressure. And, perhaps most importantly, the Federal Opposition has finally got its act together . . .

We will leave that aside. In half a paragraph what more crushing indictment could there be of the record and performance of the present Government? Turning to the specific question of productivity, we have this from the authors on page 6 of this document:
Supporters of the Accord point to job growth, a decline in disputes, and a decline in real unit labour costs as indicators of the economic success of the Accord.
However, job growth in and of itself is meaningless as an indication of the success of the Accord. The key issue is the type of job growth.
The authors then say:

The recent report of the Australian Manufacturing Council indicates that Australia has not been able to achieve the dramatic structural adjustment required to position the Australian economy at a point where current living standards can be maintained or expanded.

Senator Button told us again today what a great job had been done in the Australian steel industry in raising productivity, but he failed to tell us how fast productivity in steel making has been growing in the countries of our competitors. It is perfectly true that we have raised productivity in steel making in this country; it is also perfectly true that the productivity increase has been even faster in the countries of our major competitors-Korea, Japan and other such countries. At page 8, the authors of this document say:
Productivity increases have not been forthcoming under the Accord and therefore real wage growth is impossible under the current system.
They go on to say:
The outlook for wages-
that is, real wages, of course-
is one of continuing decline. This will further exacerbate disaffection with the Accord and with the Trade Union Movement.

Of course, do not forget that the authors of this document are themselves trade union officials and are concerned about the future of the trade union movement, including their section of it-the New South Wales branch of the trade union movement. I could quote from this document all day but I have only another minute or two. The authors of the document go on to say:
There is a real danger that the current way we are approaching award restructuring . . .

Mr Deputy President, you have heard of that; that is the buzz phrase that Mr Kelty has imposed upon the Australian public for the last year or so-`award restructuring'. The authors of this document say:
There is a real danger that the current way we are approaching award restructuring will further reduce the pressures on employers to invest in new technologies.

A fascinating part of the document refers to the whole approach to the restructuring of the trade union movement itself-the reorganisation of the trade union movement itself-in which its authors point to the obvious fact that, when people find themselves involved in larger and larger organisations, which is the end to which Mr Kelty wants to lead them, they become less and less interested and less and less bonded, so to speak, to that organisation because it becomes remote and they become disaffected with it. The solution is to have people involved in enterprise unions-the Opposition's policy-and then people can relate to something. It is like having a community party, a street party in which people who are one's friends, neighbours and the people one knows can take part. If somebody says, `Come and have a party in the centre of Sydney', we might do that once every 100 years-we did that in January last year-but that is all that we will do.

As my time has almost expired I say that, far from this document being a matter for ridicule, it is a matter which the Government ought to regard with the utmost seriousness because it is an example of analysis applied to a real problem.

The Opposition, to establish its case in the debate today, simply has to establish the veracity of four points: firstly, that the accord has failed; secondly, that Australia has a massive foreign debt problem; thirdly, that a boost in productivity can be the only basis on which to reduce our foreign debt and on which Australians can obtain higher real wages; and, fourthly, that the industrial relations policy of the Liberal and National parties is the best way to achieve that boost in productivity. We ought to be looking for increases in real wages which are based on productivity growth-the only basis on which wages in real terms can rise. If we have wages that are based on anything other than productivity growth, then we simply have a fiction, a Clayton's wage rise, a wage rise which is very soon eaten up by rapidly escalating inflation. Of course, under this Government, with its rapacious desire for revenue, there are also the diminishing effects of higher marginal tax rates on take-home pay. The paper put out by the New South Wales Labor Council that came to light last week is simply one more document which spells out the failure of the accord over the period in which this Government has been in office. That point must be emphasised over and over again because it is the real crux of everything that is wrong with our economy and it is central to the problems in our industrial relations system and to our lack of competitiveness with other countries. The accord simply locks this country into ever-spiralling wages but even faster rising prices so that we have inflation running out of control.

The Government claims that under the Opposition's proposals, which I will refer to in a moment, we would see a wages break-out. What that criticism also fails to recognise is that under our system the voluntary agreements-the enterprise agreements-will apply only where there is joint agreement between employers and employees to opt out of the system and to reach an enterprise based agreement. That will be achieved only where the employer recognises that under an enterprise-based agreement he will get greater productivity from his employees and make his products or services more competitive and, therefore, capable of getting a greater market share, whether that be on the domestic market or on the export market. In that sense there is no danger of a wages spiral as a result of our policy.

Where agreement is not reached-where employers and employees do not agree as to the outcome of an enterprise-based negotiation-they will remain in the centralised system; they will remain subject to judgments by the Industrial Relations Commission.

More importantly, under our government compliance legislation will be introduced to ensure that recalcitrant trade unions cannot buck the system, that they cannot go outside the system unless they achieve agreement with their employers. They will have to remain within the system and accept the judgment of the Industrial Relations Commission unless that agreement is reached. So because of those two prongs of our policy-the greater competition within the economy and retention of the jurisdiction of the Industrial Relations Commission for those situations where voluntary agreement is not reached-there is no danger of a wages breakout.

All we hear from the Government these days are platitudes: platitudes telling us that high interest rates are not a problem, that, in fact they are good for us; that no child is living in poverty; that the pilots dispute is over; and that our escalating foreign debt is manageable. It has increased from $33 billion in 1983 when this Government came to office to more than $100 billion today. Research now indicates that it is likely to increase to 44 per cent of our gross domestic product within five years and to nearly 60 per cent of gross domestic product by the year 2000. This is worse than banana republic stuff; it is the stuff of bankruptcies. Unless we can increase our productivity and reduce our labour unit costs, not simply in terms of our own domestic economy but in relation to the rest of the world, we will not get out of this spiralling road to bankruptcy.

Some research recently produced by the Department of Mathematics at the University of Adelaide further demonstrates the declining living standards that have been a direct result of the accord. It shows that over the last decade there has been an increase of some 139 per cent in average weekly earnings but that taxes, the Medicare levy, State taxes and charges and council rates-all charges directly attributable to government-have over the same period increased by 205 per cent. That is another example of the way in which governments have failed to deliver in terms of efficiency. The cost of an average house has risen by 196 per cent while repayments on the loan to purchase that house have risen by 333 per cent. In June 1979 a buyer would have needed $90 a week out of his after-tax average wage of $169 to meet the repayments on a normal house and car loan. The only way to reduce our foreign debt is to increase our productivity so that our goods and services become more cost competitive and can therefore be sold in greater quantities overseas by exporters, earn greater export income and, in turn, be sold in greater quantities on our domestic market and be more competitive against imported goods.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that in Queensland the policy did not act perfectly because the Government, as was its wont, from time to time would intervene to interfere in industrial relations. We know it is not perfect but it was an example of all the things that are characteristic of this type of policy. Most importantly, I honestly believe that it threatens the 80 per cent of wage and salary earners who depend for their living basically on their wages and salaries. Senator Chapman, who has just spoken, had the audacity to talk about throwing governments out of office. There is no question that in Queensland the Government was rejected, as were all the ingredients in the industrial relations policy, because that is part of the economic policy of any government. It was the exact policy that existed in Queensland. It was based on brute force. It was the power and dominance of money which inevitably led, as Senator Stone knows too well, to the corruption that was characteristic of the Queensland political system. Premier Goss-I say that again; I like to say `Premier Goss'-will introduce a policy that will clearly fit in with the accord that this Federal Government has established. He will do away with the New Right fanaticism that Senator Stone and his colleagues had in Queensland. Let us look at our significant results in industrial disputes. When I was in opposition years ago I made many speeches about the way in which the Fraser Government's industrial relations policy worked. Since that time there has been a 60 per cent reduction in the number of working days lost per month. There has been a genuine examination of work practices throughout industry in this country. That has never occurred before. Work practices are only one side of it; it goes further. All over Australia people have sat down to discuss how they would do things better.

It is ironic that Senator Chapman should also talk about the employment situation. I do not know what he meant. But the reality is that we have created more than one million jobs. The trade unionists and the people in the work force know that it is their wives and friends in particular who have been able to rejoin the work force. Middle-aged people who were rejected have been able to come back into the work force, and young people have had a better chance to get into the work force. The education and training programs of this Government have been altered and developed so that people are now able to get the benefits of award restructuring and the career paths that will now become characteristic of industry.

I do not deny that it is a slow process-all significant change is a slow process. The difference between the Government and the Opposition is that the Opposition is really talking about an ideological quick fix and a waving of the wand. The Opposition's industrial relations policy is a hard policy-the McLachlans, the Costellos, the Copemans and the Elliotts are hard men. It is a hard partisan policy tailored to their extreme views. I appreciate the soft sell of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Chaney, and I appreciate the confusion of his leader, Mr Peacock, over these issues. They are being pushed by a policy that I suspect deep down they are not terribly happy about. I appreciate the reference to people waiting in the wings. Unfortunately, we would face a flying wedge of extremists in the next Parliament if those people were successful.

I will look to my State of New South Wales for a moment. It is rumoured that the Premier of New South Wales is under pressure from his parliamentary colleagues in this chamber to introduce enterprise agreement-type legislation in New South Wales. There is this crazy idea that there can be hundreds of thousands of agreements without destroying the long tradition of wage fixation in this country. It is important to note that this is not what I say; it is what the employer organisations in my State say about the pressure on Greiner to introduce this legislation. The practical people know that we cannot risk losing a reasonable industrial relations climate by experimenting. The Metal Trades Industry Association of New South Wales, the New South Wales branch of the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, and all the major employer groups are aghast at the possibility that the Greiner Government will finally go ahead with this. Their spirit is reflected by national employer organisations and individual employers, who point to the danger of allowing in New South Wales the sort of policy proposed by the Federal coalition.

It is out of step with the award restructuring process, which is now very well advanced. It is inconsistent with the national accreditation of career paths for people. It reverts to the insular and selfish approach of just looking at one enterprise. This Government has tried to make sure an industry's needs are looked at. It plans training for an industry and gives people a career in industry. It is all right for universities and the Public Service to have career paths. Nobody in the Government would deny that people have made sacrifices, and they have done so to the extent that more than one million jobs have been created.

We have to look at what would happen were the Opposition's proposals to go ahead. Honourable Senators should remember that at the moment the people being cited by the Opposition are protected by a minimum wage document which is invariably the result of union-employer negotiations and has been ratified by the Industrial Relations Commission. There is a protective blanket to make sure that when firms set about to restructure the work in their particular enterprises they know that the whole industry is working in the same way. How can 100 workers in a factory negotiate with an employer when they do not have the same rights? Every coalition proposal gives every right to the employer to receive advice from associations, lawyers and economists. All the expert legal people are allowed to advise the employer. The 100 workers can have that right, if they can find a union or some lawyer, but they may not have the resources to employ anyone. Inevitably, the result will be uneven for the employees. The real aim is to reduce advantageous outcomes for workers as far as wages and salaries are concerned. The crocodile tears of the Opposition for workers cannot wash away the truth of its policy, which is to embolden the employers and make it much more difficult for employees.

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Accord, as recognised by the leaked New South Wales Labour Council paper, and the urgent need for the adoption of the Liberal and National Parties' Industrial Relations Policy to boost productivity as the only basis for higher real wages and a reduction in Australia's massive foreign debt burden.

This is a very important matter for us to discuss. We have an extraordinarily poor industrial relations system. We have large numbers of unions-many of them craft unions-across the board, inherited largely from Britain; constitutional division of responsibility between State and Federal governments; and a highly legalistic and centralised dispute settling and wage fixing system.
