As far as I can gather from speeches from the Government benches, they would also like to see the system controlling prices. This is the very system that the people of eastern Europe, having experienced it, are desperately trying to break away from. This Government would take us down the path that the people of eastern Europe are just abandoning-centralised control of the economy, of prices and of wages. That is what they are breaking away from. If we look at the basis for this, the accord of the Labor Government and the ACTU, we see the results: in six out of seven years we have had falling productivity and falling real wages. This is happening in a time when the productivity of our competitors, other countries, is going up. We are paying for this as a result of the accord. We have, of course, created some new jobs during that time and we have increased household spending, but at the cost of borrowing from overseas $90,000m, which has to be paid back. In order to restrain spending, the Government has record sustained interest rates. The result of that, in the awful cause and effect that it is involved in, is an overpriced dollar which makes our manufactures less competitive either as exports or as import replacements. We have got ourselves in a diabolical mess. Economically, around the world, Australia is on the nose. Our credit rating has been twice downgraded in the time of this disastrous Labor Government.

Central to our getting out of this problem is improving our industrial relations. We must make a new start in this area. Australians can be extremely productive. Our primary producers are probably the most productive in the world. It is only where we are highly centralised and highly unionised that Australians become less than normally productive. It we can do these things-other countries have; we should be able to-we will again merit the title of the lucky country.

This Bill represents an important measure in the Government's efforts to strengthen and, where necessary, protect the legitimate autonomy of higher education institutions. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to continue my remarks with regard to clause 35 of the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989. Before the Senate adjourned last Thursday I described how the Government's proposed amendment will discriminate against some invalid pensioners once they reach the age of 65 in the case of a man and 60 in the case of a woman. I remind the Senate that since 1908 the invalid pension has been paid in respect of permanent incapacity to work. At the present time, people who come to Australia as migrants, able-bodied and able to work and who subsequently have an accident or develop an unforeseen illness and therefore become unable to work, are eligible to receive an invalid pension.

SPEECH.PARA: The discrimination and inequity arise when that same invalid pensioner reaches the age of 65 or 60. At that age, the invalid pension automatically ceases. However, unless the person concerned has not been in Australia for a minimum of 10 years, he or she is not eligible for the age pension. This means that the person is in a state of limbo: too injured or ill to work through unforeseen circumstances and not having been in Australia long enough to be eligible for the age pension. I also remind the Senate that the invalid pension is paid only to recently arrived older migrants who can prove that they are 85 per cent permanently incapacitated for work, that at least 50 per cent of their incapacity for work is caused by medical impairment and that their incapacity for work occurred while they were an Australian resident. If they cannot prove that their incapacity for work occurred while they were an Australian resident, they must wait until they have been an Australian resident for 10 years.

In 1974 a previous Labor government abolished the five-year residence qualification for invalid pension for people who became incapacitated for work after their arrival in Australia. This was supported by the Opposition parties, which recognised the hardship that such a requirement caused Australian citizens and residents. However, the present Government is now seeking to reimpose that hardship on older migrants and on their families. The saving from this change will be somewhere in the region of $700,000 for the 1990-91 financial year. As the single invalid pension is around $130 a week, or $6,760 per annum, some 103 would be affected. Some people might say, `Why should we worry about 103 people?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats worry about them.

—As my colleague says, the Australian Democrats certainly worry about those 103 people. The point in question is that these 103 people would be discriminated against in a most blatant fashion: not only having come to Australia able bodied and prepared to work and having had the misfortune to have an accident or suffer illness which incapacitated them and prevented them from working, they also become aged 65 or 60 years too soon. They are discriminated against through becoming aged while on an invalid pension.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has justified this change on two grounds. In the first place the Government states that the current eligibility guidelines are inconsistent with age pension requirements: that is, that there should be a minimum of 10 years residence in Australia before being eligible for an age pension. But when applied in this case, this is a nonsense because there is the same requirement for eligibility for an invalid pension: that is, persons are not eligible for an invalid pension unless they have been in Australia for 10 years or unless they became ill or are injured after their arrival in Australia. In the second place, the Government justifies this change by saying that it will prevent older migrants from receiving the invalid pension and will force them to claim the special benefit instead at age 65 or 60. The Government will then be in a position to claim this back from those persons' relatives. But this is a heavy price to pay for older relatives who have the gall to age while being sick or injured.

This situation would place an unfair or unequal burden on newly arrived families who are struggling to establish and to make a new life for themselves in Australia. Therefore, the introduction of these changes will constitute a gross violation of the Government's social justice principles of access and equity and also of the Government's stated commitment to multiculturalism. It will also go against the Opposition's stated commitments towards easing the economic burden on families. During the committee stage of this legislation, Senator Powell will move an amendment on behalf of the Australian Democrats which will address this inequity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989 and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989 come before us towards the end of the session, which is something to which we have become accustomed in this place. These two significant Bills, which form the social security package for this session of Parliament, have been introduced in a political environment in which the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) had called for more social justice. He has done so in response, in particular most recently, to the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) paper by Saunders and Whiteford called Ending Child Poverty: An Assessment of the Government's Family Package. Also, the Age newspaper of Tuesday, 28 November, contained an article entitled `Howe wants effort to fight poverty'.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that only one Government senator has spoken during this debate-the only debate on social security Bills in this session of Parliament-on these two significant pieces of legislation. Senator Crowley, who spoke for 12 minutes last Thursday, put several points from the point of view of the Government, to which presumably the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) will respond at the end of this debate. On the other hand, Senator Bishop, the Opposition spokesperson in this House, managed to take five minutes, again last Thursday, to attempt somehow or other to get her views across. Senator Calvert who is not in charge of the legislation in this place but obviously is an aspirant, doubled the time of his shadow ministerial colleague by speaking for 10 minutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was 25 minutes.

—I apologise if my Hansard is not correct. I must say that, being in the chamber while he was speaking, I thought it must have been longer than that; but I took my statistics from Hansard. It seems to me that, while Mr Howe might be saying that we need a higher priority on these issues, that view is not necessarily shared in this chamber. Clearly, it is essential, as Mr Howe has said and as the EPAC paper has said, that we take a much broader policy approach if, generally, we are to achieve social justice in this country and if, specifically, we are to achieve the goal of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of no child needing to live in poverty by 1990 or at any other time. I acknowledge that there have been advances under the Hawke Government-for instance, the edging down of unemployment levels. But that edging down is currently at risk as the dampening down of the economy occurs and there is a slowing down in the increase in employment and the acceptance on both sides of the chamber of a 6 per cent or so plateau of unemployment. This Government has increased social security payments for low income families: the family package and, in particular, the family allowance supplement, which has been of enormous benefit to low income families. It has increased indexation so that now most social security payments are indexed, although, in the view of the Australian Democrats, those indexations ought to be quarterly whereas many of them are still annual and most are six-monthly. The child support scheme has been an advance, obviously, but the lack of a maintenance guarantee means that there are still many families who do not benefit from that. Those who do not benefit are the most disadvantaged and those on low income amongst those sole parent families.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a wider spread of employment and training programs than we would expect under a coalition alternative government. But the strong labour market orientation of many of those programs excludes many of the most disadvantaged from those programs, in the intense approach to ensuring that training is the issue and the lack of emphasis on individual support for some people who find it difficult to get into structured training programs.

There have been two significant tax reforms in the life of this Government which have been supported by the Democrats: capital gains tax and fringe benefits tax. But, income taxes have been lowered, first at the top level; corporate taxes are not paid by too many of the corporations in this country; and negative gearing is still there for the advantaged in the community. The EPAC message is not new. The same sort of message has been given for a considerable amount of time. I refer in particular to some comments made by Dr Don Edgar of the Institute of Family Studies in April 1988 at a conference on child poverty. It is an important message and I quote from the papers of that conference which are now available in a publication from the Institute called Child Poverty:

The point is that if we can afford as a society to provide housing, superannuation, taxation and occupational benefits to the better off, we can afford to remove poverty. The cost to the society as a whole of upper-income welfarism is enormous, yet we hear less about this than about the cost of social security benefits, the exploitation of unemployment benefits, supporting parent's benefits, Workcare and so on.

I think that on an analysis-and one would hope that we would get all the figures right, Senator Calvert-of the time spent in this chamber on debating issues of upper income welfarism versus the time spent on addressing issues of poverty, as outlined by Dr Edgar, that would be supported.

Dr Edgar made the point last April that the only way to alter this tide of privileged special pleading and stigmatising is to insist on the message that to have anyone living in poverty harms us all; to have any youth or any child living in poverty is to harm our future. He went on to say that what we lack now and need most of all is a new measure of poverty not based on income alone, but based on access to those resources which are seen as necessities for the participation in activities of society. Indeed, that is a message that was taken up by EPAC and ought to be taken up by all of us.

I therefore remind the Senate that while the Government pushes the line that it has done a great deal-and it has done some things, some of which I have mentioned-and clearly is preferable in many respects to options which are offered by the alternative government, for instance, the removal of unemployment benefits after nine months, it has developed the most targeted social security system around. It has reduced the outlays on social security even more than the Fraser Government before it. So it is a government which has restricted the welfare payout. It is disappointing that there is so much that concerns us in these Bills. There is concern about a cognate debate late in the session, especially as many of the issues that are contained have not really been widely debated and have not been resolved.

I give a brief outline of a range of concerns that the Australian Democrats have with these Bills. I refer first to the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989. Over quite a period, we have publicly expressed our concerns about the changes to the assessment of de facto relationships. I will be moving a second reading amendment to refer the provisions of this Bill in this respect to a committee. I will turn to this a little later in my comments.

There are other major concerns that we have with this Bill. I will take those in groups. I deal first with the unemployed in our community, a group who, regrettably, are likely to increase in numbers as we move into the economic difficulties of 1990 and who already abound in numbers which are unsatisfactorily high, particularly in some areas in our community. As I said before, the Democrats regret the fact that the 6 per cent or so level of unemployment seems to have been accepted as part of our social ethos. We do not believe that enough is being done to address that and bring the number down to the sort of unemployment level which used to be the acceptable one in this country, which was 1 1/2 per cent to 2 per cent.

In this Bill there is an attempt to restrict the freedom of movement of people who happen to be unemployed. My colleague Senator Haines addressed this issue at some length in her contribution to this debate last week. It is important to emphasise that the provisions in this Bill which would take the right to unemployment benefits from people for three months should they move to an area which reduces, according to the Government, their opportunity for employment, fail to reflect the reality of the lives of the unemployed and of the low income people. The Government is saying to the unemployed, `You can take account of no other aspects of your life'. We should not look at only one aspect of people's lives, the cost of housing, although that is an enormous problem for many low income people in our community. Other problems in our community are homeless children, long waiting lists for public housing, and very high rentals in the private sector. So if unemployed people and their families decide that they cannot meet their housing costs in the area where they are living and they move somewhere else on the basis of being able to afford housing there, they can lose entitlement to the unemployment benefit on the ground that they have moved somewhere where the Department of Social Security will determine that they have lowered their opportunity for employment. In the committee stage I will be specifically asking why we do not have in this legislation detailed information of how the decision is going to be made by the Department about whether people have reduced their employment opportunities by moving. What sort of statistics are they going to use and on what basis will the statistics be arrived at?

We have done some research for one area-the mid-north coast of New South Wales-and discovered that, while that area has a high unemployment rate, it also shows up high in statistics of high employment growth. I will refer in more detail to those statistics in committee, but we really have serious questions to ask about this provision in the legislation. I would also like to look at housing costs and take a family living on the unemployment benefit in Hobart, where unemployment levels are quite high-I believe about 9 per cent-who genuinely want to seek employment and live in an area of much lower unemployment-about 5 per cent or so-Melbourne. But if those people did that their average rent would go up from $148 to $201. The Government dare not move in the other direction. How can those people move from a high unemployment area to a lower unemployment area when housing costs are of that nature? We would like to go into that in more detail. We oppose those provisions in the legislation.

There are provisions in the legislation making it compulsory for unemployment and sickness beneficiaries to provide their tax file number in order to receive a benefit. The Australian Democrats will also oppose those provisions in the legislation. When the tax file number debate was on, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) made a commitment, among others, that this kind of thing would not happen. Again, I will go into that in further detail at the committee stage of the debate. We find it anathema that two groups in the community should be singled out and no longer have a discretion which all other Australians have. That provision in the tax file number legislation was of major concern to the Democrats. We will not support a provision for this kind of discrimination against two particular groups in our community.

Another matter which concerns us relates to the direct payment of pensions and benefits into bank accounts. Some years ago the Government made it mandatory for payments to be made directly to banks, although it has been possible, if one can argue a sufficient case, for there to be an exemption. However, it has been the norm, at the behest of the Government, for that to happen. Many of us during that period have questioned whether the Government had a legislative base for such action. The Government has now discovered that it did not. Therefore, it has provided that base in this legislation, finally legalising its action.

We will attempt to amend the legislation to ensure that pensioners will not be forced into direct payments if that is against their financial interests. We do this, firstly, to give those people freedom of choice in their financial interests-the Australian Democrats do not believe that any less should apply to people in receipt of government benefits than applies to people in the wider community-and, secondly, because of the practice that the Government has agreed to, in spite of the fact that we believe it is contrary to the provisions of the Social Security Act, of allowing banks to garnishee, in a sense, funds in the accounts of pensioners and beneficiaries who have been overpaid or whatever. We believe that pensioners and beneficiaries should be able, if they wish to do so, to move their money around and not necessarily be forced into putting it in certain accounts. We will move amendments to that effect.

Our major concerns about the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) revolve around, firstly, the issue which Senator Jenkins has canvassed fully in the debate; that is, the changes to entitlement for invalid pension which impact heavily and unjustly on a small but significant group-our migrant community. We have further amendments to the Bill relating to the payment of pensions and benefits into bank accounts.

The Democrats have major concerns about, and an amendment to, the change to the definition of dependent child so that a child earning $100 a week will no longer be defined as a dependent child. That is one of the Government's labour market initiatives and it applies to 15-year-olds. We are particularly concerned about those 15-year-olds in a sole parent family which stands to lose $65 or so from its weekly household income. In other words, a 15-year-old would work 33 hours a week for a net gain to that household income of $35 a week. I will go into that in more detail at the committee stage. We will move to amend that provision to at least make it an annual income so that families whose children work on any kind of sporadic basis are not affected by it.

We are concerned that the major impact of this measure, which the Government believes will bring in $11m in the first full year, is almost totally on low income families-not just the families of beneficiaries but low income working families; families who are receiving the family allowance supplement. It looks to us as if there will be a net loss of around $43 for those families. There is a sense of child slavery in this: the taxpayer will be thrilled to save $11m but the kid will be working for 33 hours a week for $35. I am not comfortable with that and I do not think that anybody should be.

The major impacts in both Bills are on sole parent families. In most cases the effect will be to put that parent on the unemployment benefit. This is also linked to the changes in the assessment of a de facto relationship. After the removal of the class B widow's pension a couple of years ago, it is becoming clear that the Government is attempting to almost eliminate the sole parent pension. I challenge the social justice approach that is behind this kind of exercise because it is becoming increasingly difficult, particularly for women-the vast majority of those in receipt of this pension are women-to sustain even an application for this pension, which means a great deal to someone attempting to bring up a family mostly on her own.

If this were not a cognate debate I would have more time to canvass our concerns. However, it is terribly important that we spend some time considering the attitude that is abroad about sole parents. I do not make these statements out of my own feeling, sense of justice or anything else. I refer to a paper on supporting sole parents prepared by Alison McClelland of the Brotherhood of St Laurence for the Australian Council of Social Service which was published in October this year. Alison McClelland puts the proposition that there is a very strong need for an increase in the mothers/guardians allowance-the only payment which is available specifically and only for sole supporting mothers. The paper stated:
A significant minority of Australian families are sole parent families.
I hope that those people who will be out on the hustings campaigning on families for the next four or five months at the outside understand what she is saying. She continued:
In 1988 there were 342,600 sole parent families making up 15 per cent of all families with children.
None of us should have policies which exclude 15 per cent of Australian families with children. She continued:

The majority (87.6 per cent) were headed by a female and they became sole parents largely as a result of separation and divorce. Over 260,000 sole parents were reliant on a Social Security Pension or Benefit and contrary to popular belief most remain on a pension or benefit for a relatively short period of time. Most sole parents received the pension for less than 16 months.

We must add to that the fact that half the children in poverty in this country come from those 15 per cent of families, which is a gross disproportion, and that a quarter of the homeless children identified in the Burdekin report are also from those families. This is a totally disadvantaged group and stands to be further disadvantaged by this legislation, in spite of efforts which the Government appears to have made in other fields.

McClelland argues that there is a strong case for specific additional assistance for sole parents, especially sole parents of pensioner and beneficiary families. She says in her paper that the Government provides income support payments on the understanding that parenting is a very important activity, but she points out that sole parenting is made much harder because sole parenting is generally undervalued, sole parents do not receive enough support from the community, they face punitive community attitudes and frequently are the target of actual or threatened welfare cuts and that this is both unfair and unproductive. It is important, particularly for members of the Opposition, to note a further point that Alison McClelland makes in this paper, in the general sense:
Child rearing is an important and worthwhile activity that provides benefits to the Australian society and economy.
I am pleased to read that. I certainly believe it. Child rearing was virtually my sole occupation for 20 years. She continues:

It therefore should be recognised and supported by the community. One positive aspect of Australia's social security system has been its support for caring work, including support for child rearing. This must be retained and strengthened.

It is remarkable and sad that this group currently is so much under siege politically. Alison McClelland puts the point that support for this type of family unit ought to be available, free of any obligation to meet the requirements of the work test. This is counter to what is happening. The number of people for whom that support is available without the work test is being reduced. It has been reduced in the past and it is being reduced in this legislation.

Alison McClelland points out that it is not a community expectation that in two-parent families with dependent children both parents should work. In many families both parents work, but it is not a community expectation. Yet for sole parent families a community expectation has developed-and certainly a political expectation in this place-that that sole parent will work. This places no value at all on the work of child rearing, which until now we have valued in this community and which I hear constantly from the Opposition and from more conservative forces in the community ought to be valued. Yet they will sit here and vote against the amendment, vote against the opposition to this legislation that only the Australian Democrats provide in this place. I, as a woman who has spent most of my time-up until now, anyway-child rearing, think that this is a grossly negative change to our social ethos. I for one will not condone it.

There is a lack of physical, financial, social and emotional support from a second parent in a sole parent family. It has been put this way in another paper by Patricia Harris, called Child Poverty, Inequality and Social Justice, for the Brotherhood of St Laurence:

Parents, whether in or outside the work force, can make a direct economic contribution to the household through child care, household maintenance, preparation of meals, cleaning, and financial management. Sole parents either undertake the entire range of tasks themselves, pay others to assist or leave some tasks undone.

One of the tasks that get left undone is financial management. We are clapping these women into gaol now because that is the task they left undone and we are blaming them. It is regrettable that research in the community has shown both the Government and the Opposition that it is the unemployed and sole parents whom they should hit in order to win the next election. They will not do it without being hit themselves-not as long as we are around.

These people are supposed to work but the labour market disadvantages for all women, and most particularly for women bringing up children, whether they are on their own or whether they have a partner, are well documented. Regrettably, I do not have time to go through them. The jobs, education and training scheme is in place to attempt to help these women but while child-care is inadequate, while women are clustered in low income occupations, as they still are, and while there is a lack of jobs, particularly for those who are just geographically isolated, those labour market disincentives will still be there. I move:

At the end of motion, add: `, but that the provisions of clauses 22, 24 (a) and (b), 25, 26, 28, 36, 52 and 53 be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for inquiry and report, not later than the first sitting day of April 1990, on:
(a) the meaning and effects of the clauses:

(b) the nature and extent of any legal, administrative and practical changes to payments of, and entitlements to, payments and pensions, which the clauses would, if enacted, introduce into the operation and application of the Social Security Act;
(c) the implications for personal privacy and freedom of movement of the clauses;
(d) the various ways in which the clauses could be made to operate in practice; and
(e) the likely economic and social effects of the clauses for the government, and for those people, claimants and pensioners who could be affected by them.''.

This amendment is the first attempt to codify in Federal law what a de facto relationship is. This legislation is, in a sense, backdoor legislation which can, and no doubt will, flow through to other areas. It does not seem to us to be an appropriate way to deal with this issue. There are two sides to this problem. Being defined as being in a de facto relationship can in some instances bring an advantage and in other instances bring a disadvantage. To introduce this series of indicia into the Act can affect all recipients. Already it applies in the veterans' affairs area as well under this legislation. The criteria are not even sufficient or necessary and no information is given on how they will be assessed and evaluated.

We do not believe this is the way to bring in this kind of change, nor do a very wide range of groups in the community. So we wish to refer these issues off to a Senate committee. We have made this attempt once before. Perhaps our major concern is that, even when it is determined that there is a de facto relationship, there is no legal obligation to maintain another individual in a de facto regime. We are forcing a situation where women, with no legal right to claim support, may be deprived of an income without any replacement being offered. We agree with the Australian Council of Social Service and the National Women's Consultative Council that it should be an issue that remains undefined in the Act, that the onus of proof, whether statutory or in fact, ought to remain with the Department and that it should not be held that a de facto relationship exists unless there is an ongoing commitment to provide adequate financial support. This legislation is a disappointment. Many children still do live in poverty and still will live in poverty. To quote from the last--

The response read as follows-
One thing Senator Bishop said needs a response: She said:
It has only taken five years of fairly lax administration for it to realise there is a need for a tightening of the system.
A good line-that does not accord with the facts.
Labor has effected some $5 billion of savings in social security expenditure-through sustained reforms to restore integrity to the system after its collapse under Senator Chaney.
The measures in Bill No. 3 are further steps in that process.
More importantly what Senator Bishop did not mention is notable.
Bill No. 4 contains measures to:
Implement all of the pensions aspects of the first ever retirement income policy;
Provide an overhaul of Youth Income Support as part of the Youth Social Justice Strategy and in response to the Burdekin Report on Homeless Youth; and
Adopt a comprehensive approach to the older unemployed and other groups of unemployed people.
Among the detailed provisions of the Bills are measures:

That would see the maximum level of rent assistance increase from $15 a week to $30 a week for people without children, $35 a week for people with one or two children and $40 a week for people with three or more children;
That would index rent assistance in line with the CPI;
To lift the level of pension for aged, invalid, wives, carers, sole parent and service pensioners to its highest level relative to average weekly earnings in 40 years;
To overhaul the young homeless allowance-by a substantial lift in the rate and cuts in the waiting period; and
That introduce a bereavement package to provide up to $1,200 to the pensioner spouse of a deceased pensioner and lump sums to many other bereaved pensioners.
But Senator Bishop did not comment on any of these. That is a comment on the importance the Opposition really give to measures to improve adequacy for the aged.
Senator Calvert similarly did not address the historic retirement income package.

Indeed he spoke of the difficulties of homeless youth without once recognising that the legislation he was addressing implements the social security components of the Youth Social Justice Strategy-that is aimed especially at overcoming the difficulties facing homeless youth.

Senator Calvert also developed two themes that are totally inconsistent with the facts. He cited figures of children in poverty from 1987 research that does not take account of the full implementation of Labor's families' package. He suggested -totally untruthfully-that real disposable household incomes have fallen under Labor.
The opposite is the case.

He suggested that marriage breakdowns involving children are worse under Labor. The exact opposite is the case. Under the previous Coalition government every year from 1977 the number of divorces involving children rose. Each year under Labor the number has fallen.

The electors of Kingston will be interested to know that in her contribution Senator Haines said not one word about the historic package of measures for age pensioners in these Bills. When it comes down to it those measures are not of high enough priority for Senator Haines to deal with.
She did speak of a measure to suspend unemployment benefit when a person moves and thereby reduces his or her employment prospects.
There are a number of points to be made in response to Senator Haines' comments.

The first is that like each of the Democrat speakers in this debate she has been a victim of the rhetoric of the lobby groups they are seeking to please. She constructed her argument on the basis that the Bill provided for suspensions of benefit and I quote her ``for people who move to an area of high unemployment''. She then constructed examples of people without any prospects of getting work who moved to cheaper housing.

The Bill does not do what Senator Haines' complained of. Rather it provides that a person is not qualified when he or she reduces his or her individual employment prospects by moving to an new place of residence.
It is axiomatic that a person with no prospects of employment cannot reduce them.

On the other hand for people who do have prospects of employment Labor takes the approach that you do them no favours by the soft option of providing incentives for them to move to an area where they will be dependent on benefit for the long-term.
Rather Labor's approach is:

conduct economic and wages policies so job growth continues-as Senator Crowley pointed out 1.6 million new jobs has meant the number dependant on unemployment benefit has fallen from 630,000 to 350,000;
provide effective, targeted labour market programs, integrated with income security measures, to help the excluded and disadvantaged back into the mainstream; and
guarantee adequate issue support-so the families Senator Haines expresses concern for will receive over the next 9 months the following:
rent assistance increased from $15 a week to $35 a week (or $40 for three or more children);
indexation of family allowance and adjustment of additional benefit for children for inflation;
indexation of the basic benefit; and
increase above indexation of $3.30 a week for a married couple.
Many of those measures are in the Bills before the Senate-but again Senator Haines did not refer to them.
Finally Labor builds its approach on reciprocity-in return for adequate income support and effective labour market programs we expect unemployed people to try to get back to work if possible.
Two further points should briefly be made about Senator Haines' contribution:
The Government's advice is that no state government removes people from public housing waiting lists because they decline an allocation in a country area.

The Legislation is not designed to be a rigid, widely-applied measure to restrict freedom of movement among unemployed people generally. Rather, it will prevent the most obvious cases where relocation substantially reduces the prospects of finding suitable work, and especially where the move is deliberately designed to ensure unemployed benefit can be received indefinitely on the basis of limited local job opportunities.

In particular, it will enable DSS to deal more effectively with unemployment beneficiaries who opt to move from, say, Sydney to the north coast of New South Wales, or to other remote rural areas, for lifestyle reasons.

The legislation will only be applied where there is clear evidence of substantial reduction in employment prospects. It will not be applied in marginal situations. This has been made quite explicit in instructions to the CES and DSS networks.
Senator Jenkins argued that an amendment to prohibit the grant of invalid pension to people over age pension age was harsh and discriminatory.

Invalid pension is a work related payment. To date it has been the only one of three work related payments in the social security act which does not have an upper age limit. Sickness benefit and unemployment benefit do have such a limit and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) has noted that the absence of any upper limit for invalid pension is a ``curious feature'' (re Blando).

The AAT has also noted that the common sort of case which arises is that of someone who has come to Australia at an advanced age, but who becomes permanently incapacitated not long after arrival because of degenerative health problems (many of which are an ordinary part of the ageing process). Many will have come to Australia for family reunion purposes and it is not reasonable that the full burden of their support be readily placed upon the Australian community. The assurance of support scheme seeks to ensure that this does not occur.

If a person is precluded from invalid pension by clause 35, special benefit would be available. As a result of clause 59 (c) of the Bill-not referred to by Senator Jenkins-special benefit would be payable up to the same rate as invalid pension. If in such a case an assurance of support is operative, then the person's entry to Australia was conditional on the assurer providing adequate assistance rather than the Australian taxpayer.
I would make one further point in reply to Senator Jenkins:

She constructed her argument on the basis that people migrating to Australia in their late 50s or early 60s, and their families, could not foresee that they might become too ill to work in the next 10 years. That is pure fantasy. While many people do remain fit and healthy well into their 70s many others become ill or frail in their 60s.

I wish to speak of our opposition in particular to the inclusion in this legislation of the need for social security beneficiaries to provide a tax file number. I would just like to make the reason for that opposition a little clearer, as time was limited in the second reading debate. Clauses 18, 19, 20 and 38 of the legislation really preclude people who qualify for unemployment and sickness benefits from receiving these payments if they do not provide their tax file number to the Department. In the second reading debate I did say that we felt that making these groups of people in the community the only people who do not have the discretion as to whether or not they provide their tax file number was an unfair discrimination. I remind the Committee that on 1 September 1988 the Treasurer (Mr Keating), in discussing the tax file number legislation in the House of Representatives, stated:

. . . the essential purpose of the new file number arrangement is to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the Australian Taxation Office's income matching system as a means of furthering the attack on tax evasion.

What tax evasion has to do with people on unemployment and sickness benefits needs to be answered. Senator Tate in this place reiterated that the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) was a fundamental attack on tax evasion, increasing the efficiency and effectiveness of the Australian Taxation Office. On 4 November 1988 Senator Tate stated:

Further, the Government has accepted the Opposition's suggestion that the tax file numbering scheme be made completely voluntary. The Bill now ensures that taxpayers will in all circumstances retain the right to elect to have tax withheld at source rather than quote their tax file number.

At present unemployment and sickness beneficiaries are effectively taxed at a rate of 50.25 per cent if they do not declare a tax file number, and they have to wait until they submit their tax return before their tax credits are refunded. That is the same for employers and investors. They will not have this discretion if these clauses pass. The Government says that this is necessary to reduce fraud and abuse and will save $49.8m in a full year. However, we have not had evidence from the Government that beneficiaries are more fraudulent than any other members of the community, and that is certainly what is implied in these provisions. Taxpayers as a whole, with the exception of these people, still have the discretion as to whether they provide their tax file number. The only really logical and just basis for singling out a group of people would be to demonstrate that they are so much more fraudulent, as a group. When we look around at the taxpayers of this country, the higher we raise our sights in terms of actual income, the less likely it is that the Government would be able to make stick the accusation which is inherent in these clauses. It may not be fraud, but it is interesting that one of the things that Christopher Skase has to sell is tax credits.

These provisions enable the Government to use the tax file number to avoid its obligation to pay benefits to people who are qualified otherwise. It is not easy to qualify for an unemployment or a sickness benefit and it gets more difficult day by day. Even if one does qualify, there is an extra hurdle to jump. It is a question of equal rights in the community. The Government has an obligation to support people in the community who need support. For that reason, we do not believe that the Government has provided sufficient argument for us to support this move in the legislation.

In my amendment No. 4 the Democrats will be opposing clauses 36 and 39 which relate to provisions of the Bill which withdraw benefits from people who move from their place of residence and so reduce their employment prospects. In the second reading debate I pointed out that we do not have, as yet, any clarification as to how this will be administered and on what basis the department will make its determination as to whether a person's employment prospects have been reduced. There is an exception to this: if a family member has a residence in that place, however that place is determined, that will be all right, or one can move near a family member who has a residence in that area. Senator Haines in her contribution in this debate said that this was rather a quaint new version of family reunion. Clearly there is a great cloud over how this will be determined. We want to hear from the Government, although I doubt that it will change our mind about our opposition to these clauses, but we have not heard anything to date. That is a feature of this debate and one reason we objected to the statement of the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) being incorporated rather than read out. Those who are on unemployment benefits are in limbo on this matter. We believe that there is a need for a great deal more detail.

It is important to point out that unemployed people could be in even more limbo than I and Senator Haines have outlined. It is interesting to look at the Opposition's proposals on unemployment particularly as we have supported its second reading amendment which called upon the Government to change direction. The Opposition has foreshadowed one way in which it would change direction: that is, to cause people to move in order to increase their opportunity for employment. I will give figures of the research we have done on the mid-north coast. In Sydney from 1983 to 1989 employment growth went from 10.5 per cent to 20.8 per cent and on the north coast employment growth went from 22.2 per cent to 41.9 per cent. Unemployment figures in that area show quite the contrary: in the mid-north coast there is an unemployment figure of 15.1 per cent, and in the Sydney region, the unemployment figure is 10.3 per cent. On the one hand the Government says, `You lose your benefit if you move to the mid-north coast because there is a higher unemployment level there'. On the other hand, the Opposition might be saying, `Move to the mid-north coast'. The Opposition has not outlined how it will determine this matter either. The Government says, `Do not go there'; the Opposition says, `Go there'-perhaps. We need a clarification. Clearly it is not an open and shut case. This is a very difficult matter and does not take account of the needs of people who are on the unemployment benefit. They need to have accommodation at an affordable level, which is a point I made in the second reading debate. On those counts the Democrats will be opposing these various clauses in the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few remarks in committee on this particular matter. As has been said previously, the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989 will implement some of the measures announced in the 1989-90 Budget and the April 1989 Economic Statement, and some other minor administrative changes. TALK.START.PARA: —What about taxes?

—We are not talking about tax, Senator Powell. We are talking about unemployment at this particular time. We are supporting the Government. We are certainly not supporting the Democrats' amendments. The Democrats are moving amendments Nos 1 and 2 together. SPEECH.PARA: Just for the record, Senator Powell, I believe that the unemployment rate in Tasmania has decreased from 9 per cent to 8 per cent. I do not know whether that was because a lot of the people who have been working for the green movement in Tasmania moved to Queensland for the election.

TALK.START.PARA: —There will be a lot more going up there now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government also does not support the amendments moved by Senator Powell. In respect of the first area that she raises, that of the tax file number, I am advised that there are currently about 7,000 people receiving a benefit who have not provided a tax file number and who are being taxed at the top marginal rate. It can be fairly assumed that there are three categories of those 7,000: those who obviously do not want to provide the tax file number for privacy reasons; those who have difficulty in providing such a number; and those who are not entitled to benefit payments. This legislation will mean that those people who have difficulty will only need to deal with the Department of Social Security and will be helped to get that tax file number. Those who are not entitled to benefit payments will be excluded.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government states quite clearly that this provision does not mean that the tax file number will be used for narrow social security purposes. I refer Senator Powell to the provision in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989, which will follow this one and which will substantially strengthen secrecy provisions applying in this area. Overall we anticipate that this measure will save over $30m in wrongfully paid social security benefits.

The other point encompassed by the Democrat amendment is the category that we are talking about-people moving to an area where they may, or would, reduce their individual employment prospects. It should be stated at the outset that it is axiomatic that a person with no prospects of employment cannot increase them. That should be taken into account when considering the effect of this legislation. Clearly, what the Government has in mind is that category of persons who have prospects to take employment and move to an area whereby, in a significant way, they reduce their capacity for employment. Basically, the legislation will be applied only where there is clear evidence of a substantial reduction in employment prospects. It will not be applied in those marginal situations.

It should be recognised that this particular policy is very much one of reciprocity. The Government's approach has been to provide the climate for employment growth, and the Senate does not have to be reminded at length that over our term of government 1.6 million new jobs have been created. Most importantly, the numbers dependent on unemployment benefits have fallen from 630,000 to 350,000. We are providing a targeted labour market program. We are guaranteeing adequate income support to the families that Senator Haines mentioned in her second reading contribution. We are providing support by way of rental assistance, indexation of payments and indexation of basic benefits. It should also be recognised that much of this extra support is in fact encompassed in this particular Bill before the Parliament.

On the one hand we are providing opportunities and income support and on the other hand we make it very clear that it serves no-one any good for persons to be allowed to take that step which would lead to clear evidence of a substantial reduction in employment prospects. The legislation will be applied quite precisely to ensure that where there is clear evidence the benefit will not be available. In the context of the Government's balanced approach this is a fair provision when one looks at the other measures that are in place. Also, when one looks at the actual position of individuals it would serve no good for them to be allowed to take the soft option.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it rather quaint for the Government to point to three different groups of people who are not providing a tax file number and who are receiving unemployment and sickness benefits. The Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) said that one group is exercising choice and another lot is having difficulty; and I did not quite understand what the third lot were doing. Does he have to plead his case?

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was asking the Minister for clarification of the clauses regarding the withdrawal of the unemployment benefit if beneficiaries move without sufficient reason to an area where their employment prospects are reduced. I really do not believe that the Committee has had clarification of the sorts of criteria that will be used and how an individual will be able to establish what is or is not sufficient reason. Certainly, these clauses establish that sufficient reason would be an unemployment beneficiary moving to an area in which a family member is living-that will certainly be approved of by this legislation. But that seems to be the only sufficient reason. We are asking: What will be sufficient reasons? How will the beneficiary establish those reasons and will this be like an increasing number of provisions in social security legislation where, in essence, the beneficiary is considered guilty until he or she proves his or her innocence? In other words, when a person moves, the Department of Social Security says, `Sorry, you have reduced your employment prospects', and the beneficiary then has to prove that he has not reduced his employment prospects and that he has sufficient reason to move. That is the sort of scenario that I can see.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government expects the Australian Democrats not to oppose these clauses, as we are saying that we wish to do, it certainly has to come up with more clarification than that. I have certainly not seen anywhere on the public record, in the Minister's second reading speech, in the explanatory memorandum, or in the detail of the legislation, the answers to any of those questions. Not only do the Democrats need some glimmer of information about how these new provisions will be implemented, but also I certainly believe that the people of Australia need some information, particularly as it is highly likely that there will be more unemployed people next year than there are this year.

So I am asking the Minister whether he can possibly clarify for us what sort of arrangements are in place or might be put in place on this matter. As I said, it might be that unemployed persons have an idea in their minds that a certain move will improve their employment prospects. They might be prepared to make a major career change in their life-a change in the direction of their employment. Yet, on the surface, on some sort of statistical analysis, about which we know nothing yet, the Department might determine that these people had reduced their employment prospects. I would just like to hear from the Government something about how this will work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Powell has been here for eight years or so.
—It is only three; it just seems longer.

—Only three? It just seems that long. The point I wish to make is that we are dealing with legislation. If we were to encompass in legislation every conceivable permutation of circumstances that might arise, we would be sitting here day after day, through Christmas, and thereafter.
—We are; and there's a long way to go, too.

—Obviously, in legislation, there needs to be a certain degree of generality and that, Senator Hill, is something that all governments, whether State, Federal or otherwise, have adopted. To that extent, the advice and assistance of the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) will be the most important benchmark for deciding whether someone qualifies within these guidelines. I say quite strongly in terms of the point I made earlier that the Government's policies in this area are geared very much towards creating employment opportunities and, tied in with that, training and education programs. To that extent, the advice of the CES will obviously be taken into account as regards the particular person that Senator Powell talked about, as well as the area to which that person goes.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us not forget that this legislation is not to be interpreted solely by the officers of the Department of Social Security. We do have appeal mechanisms and those sorts of structures, and if the Government's commitments were not achieved to Senator Powell's satisfaction, then the protections are there. They are substantial protections as regards the way that the legislation will be applied. That the amendments (Senator Powell's) be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Page 11, clause 28, proposed subsection 43a (1), line 38, before ``period of at least 8 weeks'', insert ``continuous''.
(4) Page 12, clause 28, proposed subsection 43a (2), line 13, before ``period of at least 8 weeks'', insert ``continuous''.

These amendments seek simply to clarify within clause 28 of the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989 the period of time in which certain provisions of proposed new section 43a (1) will apply. The Bill reads:
This section applies where, for a period of at least 8 weeks, 2 people of opposite sexes who are not legally married to each other have shared a residence . . .

Then a number of other criteria follow. That occurs again in proposed section 43a (2) which is the subject of our amendment No. 4. In the context of this legislation I remind the Committee that the Australian Democrats would prefer not to be dealing with this clause of the legislation by amendment but would rather have seen it sent off to a committee for proper consultation and consideration. But we do have the clause before us and it is important that the period of time involved should have to be continuous.

One of the problems we have with this clause of the Bill dealing with marriage-like relationships is that it takes little or no account of the lifestyles of people on low incomes-in particular, people on pensionor benefit and, most specifically, people on a pension bringing up children alone. For many people a feature of that lifestyle is living with a group of people, for obvious reasons-communal support, emotional support, simple physical support and general companionship as well as a sharing of costs on the very minimal incomes on which these people have to survive. The lifestyle of groups often means that people tend to move from one place to another. Very often these people are on long waiting lists for public housing and, if they cannot get into public housing, are at the mercy of private landlords. That often means that they must move from time to time.

Without the insertion of the word `continuous' it is possible that some people might come under the provisions-I repeat that they are odious provisions-of this legislation in a sense by accident and unjustly. Over some period of eight weeks, which is all that is prescribed here in the legislation, they might happen to have lived with another person of the opposite sex just by virtue of the sort of lifestyle that they are leading but it might not have been for a continuous period. I believe that the Government's intention with this legislation is that it should be a continuous period. Should the Government not support these two simple amendments I will be quite amazed.

While we are on this clause of the Bill I also note that it talks about the eight-week period of co-residence between two people of opposite sexes and then applies a range of other criteria. Further on the criteria include the question of whether or not there is a sexual relationship between these people. That is one of the criteria that come into play in this clause.

I note that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has expressed its concern that having regard to sexual relationships between a couple to determine whether the people are living in a marriage-like relationship or to determine de facto spouses may intrude upon personal privacy. We share that concern. I reiterate a point that I made in the second reading debate-that the bottom line, if you like, of determination that a person should not qualify for a sole parent pension ought to be financial support available in a relationship. That would mean that any sexual relationship or, indeed, some of the other criteria in this legislation, would be irrelevant. However, these amendments are moved on the basis that we believe that this is the Government's intention and therefore we believe that it ought to be in the legislation. There are enough grey areas in this social security Act as it is and we do not believe that we should be putting more in at this particular stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too am aware of the concern in the community about this matter of the definition of `de facto relationship'. I am also aware that the Government's attempt to define this de facto relationship has caused a certain amount of concern amongst some sectors of the community. We in the Opposition have received numerous representations from welfare groups and sole parent associations. No doubt the Government has also received these representations, in particular from the Australian Council of Social Service, the Women's Electoral Lobby and the National Women's Consultative Council, which have criticised the scheme. Their major concerns of course include the continuing confusion over the definition as it appears in a range of State and Federal legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation seeks to provide a series of very specific guidelines that determine whether a bona fide domestic relationship exists. As Senator Powell pointed out, this could affect all pensioners and beneficiaries, including age pensioners. The Secretary, through this legislation, will have regard to a number of matters upon which he can base his decision. These include financial aspects, the nature of the household, social aspects of the relationship, any sexual relationship and the nature of the people's commitment to each other. One would have to admit that this legislation could be seen by age pensioners as yet another example of government interference. It could thus be regarded as a gross invasion of their privacy. I concede also that almost any attempt to tighten up areas of potential abuse would also meet with criticism.

The issues raised are of legitimate concern. We support the Government's intention to tighten up an area of the social security system, which there is clear evidence to suggest is being abused. The Opposition has no wish to disadvantage people who are not breaking the rules. We will therefore be seeking assurances, as I said earlier, from the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) that the appeals mechanism will be fairly administered.

As I said, we support the overall tightening of the welfare system and therefore this package of Bills, including these provisions that will ensure that people who are not married are not advantaged over those who are married. As I said in my opening remarks this afternoon, we have given an undertaking to monitor applications of these provisions and to ensure that they are administered fairly and equitably. When we attain government we will take any action to change that legislation if need be. For those reasons, the Opposition does not believe that the amendments make a significant difference to the operation of the Bill. Therefore, we will not support them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government also opposes the amendments. I wish to make two comments. We seem to be very much into this question of de facto relationships and now the social security system operates to handle them. We are not approaching this in a vacuum situation; we are approaching it from where there has been a definition through common law of what is and what is not relevant. In essence, it should be noted by Senator Powell and anyone else entering this debate that we are not operating in this vacuum situation. The Government's provisions do essentially two things. First, we codify procedures and the relevance of all sorts of considerations. In doing so, we obviously give more certainty to the existing structure of the law. Secondly, in doing so, we are in some areas providing more rights to individuals. For instance, the existing provisions permit the compulsory overriding of common law privileges. The new provisions do not do that. In terms of the whole area, I mention these two points.

SPEECH.PARA: In the two amendments that Senator Powell has moved, amendments Nos. 3 and 4, she is insisting on the insertion of the word `continuous' in the proposed sections 43a (1) and (2). Her intention may be appropriate, but the amendments do not take into account the degree of uncertainty or the effect on temporary absence in the relevant period. For that reason, we maintain objection to the insertion of the word `continuous'. The Bill, as it now stands, provides a degree of flexibility and does not incur the crabs that would be incurred by the insertion of the word `continuous'.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Minister's last comment, he referred to temporary absences as the reason that the Government would not want to insert the word `continuous'. That brings me to question what the Government really means by `shared residence'. Clearly, there must be a definition which would allow for temporary residence. If people are actually living together or sharing a residence and one goes away for a day or two, presumably they are still sharing the residence. The criteria for sharing must have something to do with things such as paying the rent, and indeed, with many of the aspects of the provisions of this clause of the Bill. Given that that is the case, surely that is covered. We are seeking to make sure that consideration is given to a genuine break-up of sharing for one reason or another. A couple might share accommodation for a month, and then one might move for a range of reasons and come back for another month later on. They would presumably come under this provision unless we inserted the word `continuous'. I would like some clarification on that.

—The provision very clearly says that we are talking about `a period'. I think that Senator Powell can understand what that means. Her amendments raise one side of the argument. We are talking about deviations from such a period by temporary absences. As I said earlier, the benchmark is the shared accommodation being the principal place of residence while there is a temporary absence.

—Can I confirm that, in the wording of this legislation, the Government is referring to `a period', which has to be eight weeks-not two four-week periods or one six-week period followed by a two-week period after some sort of break? Is that what the Minister is saying?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The accommodation has to remain the principal place of residence during the temporary absence.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Page 12, clause 28, proposed subparagraph 43a (1) (d) (ii), line 9, leave out ``$1000'', insert ``$10,000''.

This amendment relates to people who have joint assets of a total value of more than $4,000 or joint liabilities totalling more than $1,000. The Australian Democrats seek to remove what we see as outright discrimination against those people with the least money. We want to change the joint liabilities total to $10,000. It seems to us that the Government is discriminating against people who have to club together in order to make purchases, to cover rental bonds or to meet other day to day living expenses.

I note that, when the original legislation was introduced into the House of Representatives, the joint assets and joint liabilities figures which brought people under the ambit of these provisions both were $1,000. The pressure from interested community groups resulted in the Government raising the joint assets level to $4,000. Clearly, joint assets of $1,000 would have provided a trigger in respect of an enormous number of people in a simple shared residence situation. This has nothing to do with a de facto or any other kind of dependent relationship. Many household items cost hundreds of dollars, some thousands of dollars. People need such items if they are to live reasonably. In the early stages of the debate on this legislation, the cost of a refrigerator was the example most commonly used. Anything in addition to the smallest appliances will quickly bring up to total value of the shared assets to $4,000.

The same applies in the liabilities area. The people who have the least cash, the least ready money, who have to club together and therefore have joint liabilities, particularly-while I do not condone or encourage it-in these days of increasing use of credit, are making purchases on credit. It seems to us that leaving the joint liabilities provisions at $1,000 discriminates against those people who do not have ready cash and who can club together with the people with whom they share accommodation, to purchase household items. Do not forget that they share for a range of necessary reasons, including social and moral support. There is an advantage in being able to club together to get some decent things, and sometimes some very essential things, to enable them to lead some sort of reasonable life.

Let us also not forget that we are talking about households, including children. I do not think any of us would want to see a household with children which did not have adequate refrigeration or heating facilities or which was not able to provide furniture to sit on. I think honourable senators would prefer that these people had some kind of rudimentary floor coverings on which to walk and so on. The smallest power vacuum cleaner that I have been able to cost latterly-it really is a pretty pathetic vacuum cleaner-was priced at about $120. Three years ago I bought the same kind of appliance for about $80. If these people have floor coverings they will need something to clean them with. If people club together and buy a few of those things, pretty soon they will have spent $1,000. We suggest, by this amendment, that the joint liabilities figure in this legislation be raised to $10,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wish to make two very quick points. The first point, which was overlooked by Senator Powell, is that we are talking about joint assets and joint liabilities. SPEECH.PARA: The other point I refer to is the raising of that level to $10,000. Senator Powell obviously knows the ultimate effect of that sort of provision, as I think she knows about the ultimate effect of other provisions that follow in the amendments that she proposes. That, basically, is to render useless the policy that the Government is attempting in this area. I make the point again, that we are not coming into this area in a vacuum; we are coming into this area with common law, with a fair degree of certainty, but with a fair degree of inequity in terms of interpretation of the law overriding the existing protections and privacies. That the amendment (Senator Powell's) be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Page 12, clause 28, proposed paragraph 43a (1) (f), lines 11 and 12, leave out ``with each other'', insert ``or residences with each other for a period or periods totalling not less than 12 months during the preceding 2 years''.

In moving this amendment, we have a similar concern to that which we had in moving amendment No. 4. The amendment is to proposed paragraph 43a (1) (f). We wish to clarify the situation in which claimants will be deemed to have been living together by inserting the words `or residences with each other for a period or periods totalling not less than 12 months during the preceding 2 years'. This concern applies in a number of areas in the legislation. As we go through the clauses, quite often we wonder where the economies will arise because clearly there are many administrative pitfalls in the legislation. It seems to us that this proposed paragraph, in which the period of residence is not clearly established, is one of them. In order to clarify that, we think this amendment needs to be inserted in the legislation. As the legislation stands now it concerns the simple sharing of a residence. We think that for the Department to take this issue into account, for it to be part of a genuine or likely de facto relationship, a period of time ought to be specified in the legislation. We are suggesting 12 months over the period of the previous two years as a reasonable approach, given that this is one of a set of criteria after which a final decision will be made by the Secretary.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Powell pointed out, this amendment is similar to the one before it. I did not speak on that amendment, but I make the general comment that whilst the Opposition is not supporting the Bill we are certainly not opposing it. We believe that these new regulations should be put in place. We will continue to monitor them in opposition and in government. We believe that the legislation should be passed as quickly as possible to allow this to happen.

—The Government also opposes the proposed amendment. It would introduce a fair degree of rigidity for which there is no real basis. It would complicate the process involved for all sole parent pensioners and ultimately would limit the capacity of the Department to ensure integrity in the process. I do agree with Senator Powell on one point and that was the last one. What we are talking about here is not a condition precedent to the benefit or pension being paid. We are talking of one of a range of indicators. All of those indicators will be looked at in forming the ultimate picture, as happens currently in the common law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister's point about these being a set of indicators is absolutely right and is accepted by us. It is on that basis that we want those indicators to be as clear as possible. I find it interesting that the Minister pleads rigidity in opposing this amendment when, indeed, one of the major concerns about this whole clause is its rigidity and the fact that even with that rigidity there is, in the end, a final decision to be made beyond the provisions of the legislation. Neither the indicia in proposed section 43a nor the following criteria are exhaustive, nor should they be. That is one of the reasons why we would prefer, as I said, along with the Australian Council of Social Service and the National Women's Consultative Council, that this issue not be legislated on, at least until there has been far more widespread discussion about it.

SPEECH.PARA: We maintain the view that this provision is too broad and open. It is part of a series of indicators. In regard to the case we just dealt with, concerning the figure of assets, if the Government did not want to be rigid why did it not say `substantial' shared assets or `substantial' shared liabilities? That would have been unrigid, just as this provision is. We believe that there ought to be some reasonable provision in the legislation.

I refer to Senator Calvert's response, not just in respect of this amendment but in respect of a number of others. He will recall that the Australian Democrats supported the Opposition's second reading amendment, which condemned the Government for not changing direction in social security policy. It seems to me that throughout this exercise the Opposition is finding excuses-struggling to find them, in some cases-to support the Government. There has been constant reference to, `We will do something about it if it is a problem when we are in government'. It seems pretty silly to me for a potential future government to go to the community and say, `We can do a better job', when it is putting in place a piece of legislation which will clearly create problems and which will clearly set a disturbing precedent. Then it says, `We will clear it up later'.

We are already doing that with another piece of social security legislation with the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. The Committee is examining sections 246 and 162 of the Social Security Act with regard to debt recovery and information gathering as contained in that Act. These provisions were put in, I think, in 1987 when the Australian Democrats attempted to draw the attention of the Parliament to the fact that the provisions would create problems. The provisions are now before the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee and this will require the Committee to have public hearings tomorrow night as we have been doing for several months.

It seems to me that it is always more efficient if there are alarm bells ringing, for then a government or an alternative government-if that is what the Opposition is-will be able to take steps at the appropriate time. In the case of the social security legislation in particular it has provisions which will clearly cause distress in the lives of people in the community, and again in the case of social security legislation, the most disadvantaged people in the community. The problem with these provisions in this section, of which this amendment is one, is really that it limits the choices of, in particular, women.

What we are very concerned about is that the savings which the Government imagines it will get from these provisions will be made at the expense of women and their children staying in households, in family situations, in which they might even be at physical risk, because they fear that if they break away and seek some kind of joint living arrangement for a range of reasons-economic, emotional, social and other reasons-they will be at risk of losing the very minimal income support which they might otherwise have expected from the Government. Therefore, we would like to see more rigidity in this particular clause of the Bill.
