TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Page 12, clause 28, proposed subparagraph 43a (3) (a) (ii), line 28, leave out ``information that might be relevant'', insert ``information that is relevant''.
(10) Page 12, clause 28, proposed paragraph 43a (3) (b), line 32, leave out ``pensioner's pension will'', insert ``pensioner's pension may''.
(11) Page 13, clause 28, proposed subparagraph 43a (4) (a) (ii), line 3, leave out ``information that might be relevant'', insert ``information that is relevant''.

These particular parts of clause 28 of the Bill refer to the information that a pensioner or applicant needs to provide to the Secretary to the Department in order to qualify. Our concern about this relates to the way that it is put in the legislation. One of the provisions deals with information that might be relevant to the question of whether the pensioner is a de facto spouse, et cetera. Another refers to the fact that if information is not given to the Secretary within 14 days the pensioner's pension will be suspended. Again, there is another provision which talks about information which might be relevant.

We believe that we should change those words to the form that we have set out in the amendment. We want to take out the term, `information that might be relevant', as that will be a subjective decision on behalf of the Secretary. In cases being dealt with, that will be the delegate of the Secretary in the Department office. Again, I suppose we want to be more rigid. We want to say, `information that is relevant'. It is clearly relevant. We believe also that the provision should provide for some discretion with regard to what then happens. The provision should read that the pensioner's pension may be suspended in the case that would arise, rather than that the pensioner's pension will be suspended, because all the decisions are made finally not by the provisions of the legislation, which are only indicators, but by officials in the departmental office. In that case we would prefer to leave in that point of discretion.

It seems that the provision of information that might be relevant is part of the process in this part of the legislation which leaves the pension applicant very much open, in the end, to having to prove eligibility, as opposed to having the Department prove non-eligibility. Summary of recommendations
The Committee recommends that:
1 (a) More bills than at present be referred to committees.
1 (b) A Selection of Bills Committee be constituted to make recommendations to the Senate as to which bills should be referred to committees.

1 (c) The Selection of Bills Committee be: The Government Whip and two Deputy Government Whips, the Opposition Whip and the Deputy Opposition Whip, the National Party Whip and the Australian Democrat Whip.
1 (d) Unless the Selection of Bills Committee has no report to present, it report its recommendations relating to bills to be referred to committees at an appropriate time each sitting day.
1 (e) A total time limit of 30 minutes and 5 minutes for each speaker apply for debate on a report of the Selection of Bills Committee.
2 The same time limits as outlined in recommendation 1 (e) apply to other motions and amendments to refer bills to committees.

3 Subject to any change in the pattern of the sittings of the Senate, and subject to appropriate adjustments of broadcasting arrangements, Wednesday of each sitting week be set aside for committee meetings.

4 (a) In relation to a bill received from the House of Representatives, when no Senator indicates to the Chair, either in writing before the second reading of the bill is called on or orally at that time, that the Senator requires to debate the bill, the motion for the second reading of that bill be put without debate.

6 Estimates Committees be given the power to recommend the approval by the Senate of proposed expenditure, with or without amendments or requests.

8 The quorum of the Senate be reduced from one third to one quarter of the Senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak fairly briefly to this report. I think it is a matter on which most senators have made up their minds and I do not think there is anything to be gained by prolonged debate. It is important that the Senate should show willingness to vote and decide on these matters rather than merely deferring them. As far as the Opposition is concerned, it will be a free vote. Nevertheless, many views have been expressed by Opposition members and it is hoped that generally the recommendations will have the support of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to run very briefly through these recommendations to explain what the Select Committee on Legislation Procedures was about. The first, and perhaps the key, recommendation was that more Bills should be referred to committees than at present. I think that is crucial. The Senate passes something like 180 Bills a year, and in the past only two or three, on average, have been referred to committees. I think it is almost a universal opinion in the Senate that the Bills which have been considered by committees have been substantially improved by the process of pointing out defects that have not been considered by the drafters or raising issues that the Senate should have considered before it passed the Bill. The Committee did look, having decided that more Bills should go to committees, at how it should be achieved.

We did not seriously consider adopting in our Senate, the New Zealand system where all Bills are referred to committees. In my view it is not very effective in New Zealand because it has only a single house of parliament controlled by the government and the committees are ultimately the servants of the government. Nevertheless, in their system all Bills go to committees. We did not think that that would be acceptable to the Senate or workable if it were proposed. We had to suggest a method by which the Bills which should be referred to committees were to be selected. The committee that looked at which Bills should be selected should also recommend at what stage in the process the Bills should be referred, to what committee they should go and when the nominated committee should report by. The committee suitable for this purpose, which meets daily, is the Whips Committee; it represents the balance of power in the Senate. Our Committee decided that the Whips Committee should act as the Selection of Bills Committee and do the job of recommending to the Senate, at a routine time each day, any Bills that should be referred to a committee.

I understand there will be an amendment moved by my colleague, Senator Watson, to modify slightly the recommendations of the committee. As it stands, the Selection of Bills Committee had to recommend one of the standing committees as the committee to consider a Bill. Senator Watson made the point, which to me seems valid, that certain highly specialised Bills might not be appropriately dealt with by a standing committee and that it might be desirable to have a select committee established for the purpose and to build in flexibility to that end.

There will be another minor amendment proposed by the Opposition's Whip, Senator Reid, about the Selection of Bills Committee. As the recommendation is worded, it makes an outrageous assumption that we are going to be in opposition forever. I do not think anyone on either side of the chamber would think that is a possibility. The wording is made more neutral to eliminate the apparent wish, or apparent view, that we might be in opposition for a prolonged period. It is only a minor terminological change. I understand that Senator Reid will be moving an amendment to that effect.

One of the problems put to the Committee when we were discussing these issues was that there could be prolonged turmoil every day when the Selection of Bills Committee report was received by the Senate. It was suggested that this would be futile because the Whips Committee represents the balance of power in the Senate and the result would be known before the debate took place. I do not think it very likely that such debate would take place. But if it did, to overcome the problem of prolonged debate the recommendation of the Committee was that such debate should be limited to not more than 30 minutes, with no speaker speaking for more than five minutes. This overcomes a particular problem that was put to the Committee.

That was the main recommendation and one resultant problem did arise. If we are going to refer Bills to committees they have to be able to consider them reasonably promptly. It is notoriously difficult to get senators to gather together during a non-sitting week during a session. It just cannot be achieved. Senators have commitments back in their electorates and it is not practical to get them to come to Canberra to consider Bills. Therefore, we suggest that Wednesday of each sitting week should be the day on which committees should meet. If they have Bills referred to them, they should deal with them. If they have no Bills referred to them they can then deal with the many other references that they have in their general purpose function. Other parliaments allocate special days for committees quite frequently.

We think that, at the very least, the Senate should try it out. I think it is a necessary corollary of referring Bills to committees to ensure that they will be dealt with in a timely fashion. One minor amendment will be necessary. As everyone knows, Wednesday is one of our broadcast days. It is a particularly unsuitable day to be broadcasting, by the way, because the Senate adjourns at 7.30; it is a short sitting day. There would need to be some negotiations with the committee and with the House of Representatives to change the pattern of broadcast days, but I cannot believe that that will result in any problems.

The Committee, having proposed what would be an extra time commitment for the Senate, had to look at how we were going to meet it. In fact, we in this Parliament do not sit for many days. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which in fact, is an appendix to the Committee's report, showing the sitting days of various parliaments-the Australian, the Canadian and the United Kingdom parliaments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. To summarise the table very briefly: the Canadian Parliament sits, on average, for 167 days; the United Kingdom Parliament sits for almost the same time; the United States Congress sits for 170 days; and we sit for 84 days. When I was doing my soundings among my colleagues I found that there was no great enthusiasm for the Senate sitting for substantially more days. We in this Parliament know that there is great pressure on us to be in our electorates and not, as some people in our electorates view it, to be wasting our time in Canberra. It is interesting that that pressure does not really come from the electorates; it comes from the party organisations. Nevertheless, the pressure is there and it would be difficult for us, in the short term anyway, to reverse that process. I think in the long term the Senate will and should sit more but, in the short term, we had to suggest where one could save time in other areas of Senate procedures in order to increase the time available for committee consideration of Bills, and the remainder of our recommendations were devoted to that purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: The first recommendation was one which I do not think will save much time-that is, in non-controversial Bills, or in Bills received from the House of Representatives which it is accepted will go through, we could avoid another second reading debate. It has often seemed to me that, where there has been a substantial debate in the House of Representatives, it is almost pointless for us to repeat the same sentiments in this chamber. It is not all that easy, as there is one party-the Australian Democrats-which is not represented, at the moment anyway, in the House of Representatives, and there are Independent senators, so it will not always be appropriate. Nevertheless, there is a suggestion to improve the machinery whereby second reading debates could be omitted, but I do not believe that that will save a great deal of time.

Where there could be a serious attempt to save time is in the consideration of Appropriation Bills in the Committee of the Whole. When the Estimates committees were set up in 1970 it was clearly said by the coalition government in the tabling statement at the time that it was expected that debate in the Committee of the Whole would be on the report of the committee. That has not been achieved. When the Estimates committees were established there was a sharp drop in the time taken in the debate in the Committee of the Whole. This has gone up-erratically, but it has gone up-and this year we spent 33 hours in Committee of the Whole debate on the Estimates, which is the longest time spent by this chamber since Estimates committees were introduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Senator Walters was not even here.

—And Senator Walters was not even here, as Senator Puplick has just said. Had Senator Walters been here it might have taken rather longer. But the point is that we spent a great deal of time discussing things that should have been dealt with in the Estimates committees. The Senate sets up Estimates committees to examine the Estimates on its behalf. They cross-examine departmental officers and, in my view and in the view of the Committee, we should then consider their report back to the Committee of the Whole. They should say, `We recommend' or in extreme circumstances `We do not recommend the passing of the Estimates which have been given to us to examine, but we would like to draw the Senate's attention to a number of matters that the Senate might like to discuss where there are some questions about the desirability or efficiency of the Estimates'. The debate would be on the motion of the chairman of the committee that the Estimates they have been given be approved and the debate would be on the subject matter, including dissenting reports, contained in the committee report.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt at all that that would limit what currently goes on in the Committee of the Whole. Some senators use the Committee of the Whole to try to extract primary information, which I do not think is an appropriate purpose of the Committee of the Whole. The Estimates committees, which individual senators have the right to attend, if they can spare the time-or, alternatively, they may be able to give other senators questions to ask on their behalf-are the appropriate place to do that. There is no doubt at all, because we are trying to save time, that some of the activities that now take place in the Committee of the Whole would not be practicable under the revised arrangements. It is for the Senate to decide whether the time we spend-33 hours this year in the Committee of the Whole debate-is wise expenditure of the Senate's time; if not, it is for the Senate to decide how we ration the time. The Committee has made what I think is a sensible decision.

It is not as though, if a senator cannot get an answer in an Estimates committee, that that is the end of the matter. There are many other ways in which to get information. For instance, a senator can speak, if he or she wishes to raise an issue, in the second reading debate on the Estimates. A senator can ask a question without notice or put a question on notice. A senator can write a letter to the Minister or make a request under freedom of information. There are many ways in which a senator can establish information if he or she wishes to, though I do admit that the intention of the Committee in making this recommendation was to reduce the time that the Senate was going to spend in this area.

The final two matters in the report did not originate with the Committee; they were put there for completeness. The first is the question of limiting debates on suspension of Standing Orders to 30 minutes, with each speaker being allowed to speak for not more than five minutes. I had a look through the records of the last four years of the debates on suspension of Standing Orders. If they are going to be suspended, there is virtually no debate. It is only when it is known that they will not be suspended that people wish to have a debate. The Committee felt that 30 minutes was long enough for what in fact is a political protest. In the end, it is for the Senate to decide how it wishes to spend its time. If the Senate wants to spend its time in different ways it has to adjust its procedures, and this was one of the ways in which it was suggested that we might adjust our procedures.

The final suggestion was on the quorum. I do not think that would save any time at all. The quorum for the Senate is laid down in the Constitution as being one-third of the senators. The House of Representatives changed its quorum to one-fifth. The recommendation of the Committee was to change the quorum to one-quarter. Effectively at present, 26 senators represent a quorum of one-third, which would be reduced to 19 senators with a quorum of one-quarter. The only argument I know in favour of this is that it will relieve Ministers of the responsibility of assisting to provide the quorum. Traditionally, the Government has to keep the quorum in the chamber, and the Government can expect to have only 33 senators perhaps 34 senators. If 26 senators are required for a quorum, there is no way that Ministers can be excused. If the quorum were reduced to 19, it would be practicable to excuse some or all of the Ministers from answering the call for a quorum. The Senate has to make up its mind whether that is desirable or not.

I draw these matters to the Senate's attention. As might be obvious, I think the recommendations are appropriate and sensible. They may not be perfect. This is not an immutable recommendation. If experience shows that it needs changing, the Senate should be prepared to change. One of the things I have found most difficult in the Senate-it is most distressing really-is the very great difficulty that the Senate has in making up its mind on these matters. We do not get around to making simple decisions on simple matters. This is something we should try; if experience shows that changes are necessary, let us make the changes. Let us at least try a system which has--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not by a steamroller. There are individual rights affected.

—Before the honourable senator came in, I said that on the Opposition benches there is a free vote on this issue. Honourable senators will make up their minds, and of course in the Senate the majority decides, as the majority should. This is a particularly appropriate moment for the Senate to address this problem because nobody knows who the government will be next year. So both the Government and the Opposition have to look at the interests of both government and opposition and see that they are fairly treated; therefore honourable senators are looking at things as impartially as they can. I accept the particular problems of Independent senators, who have both rights and difficulties in this chamber. I am sure that Senator Harradine will be putting his points in due course.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing that makes this a good moment is that we have just had the longest Estimates debate in the Committee of the Whole since the Estimates committees were set up. We have to consider whether that is a sensible use of the available time of the Senate. I recommend these motions. I do not contend that they are perfect; they are an attempt to solve serious problems in the Senate and they are worthy of a trial by this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are three matters I wish to raise in the debate tonight. The third requires, in my view, an amendment to motion No. 1 and I will be moving that in due course. First, I would like to congratulate my colleague Senator Hamer, as Chairman of Committees, for the amount of time he has spent on revising the legislation procedures. It is not just a matter of hours or days or weeks; he actually spent months trying to get this right with his fellow senators. While not all honourable senators will agree with the detail that has been presented to the Senate tonight, I certainly think the recommended procedures are an improvement on what we already have in an effort to expedite the work and the effectiveness of this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter I raise was also raised by Senator Hamer and it is a matter which I debated with him; that is, that it is desirable to try to reduce the amount of debating time in committee during the debate on the appropriations. A number of the questions and also much of the comment could quite easily and more effectively be included in the Senate Estimates committee Hansards. I think that would be a more effective medium in which those comments could be made. However, I do not wish to exclude such comments entirely from the committee stage of the debate in this chamber. This recommendation does not require an amendment, nor do I think it would be appropriate for material to be included in the Hansard without the general consent of a majority of committee members. I ask that honourable senators consider this suggestion.

The third matter was also raised by Senator Hamer. He gave forward notice of my intention to move an amendment to motion No. 1. We do have a number of standing committees in this Parliament. It may be that because of the technical or special features of a Bill the committee which is deemed appropriate may not necessarily have a general expertise or interest in the subject. Therefore there would be circumstances where a Bill should be referred instead to a select committee. I therefore move:
Motion (1), at the end of motion, add
``, subject to the following amendment of the order: after paragraph (11), insert the following paragraph:
`(11a) Where:
(a) the Selection of Bills Committee recommends that a bill be referred to a select committee; or
(b) a Senator indicates that the Senator intends to move to establish a select committee to consider a bill or to refer a bill to an existing select committee,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report of the Senate Select Committee on Legislation Procedures was first debated in the Senate near the beginning of this sitting period, I think on 16 August. On that day I spoke on the motion to take note of the report but was cut off at the lunch break before I had finished my remarks. I want to complete some general remarks that I was in the process of making on that occasion and also to move an amendment to one of the motions that have been put forward. In the time that I had available to speak on the previous occasion I indicated my warm support for the Committee's recommendations about referring Bills to committees and setting up a Selection of Bills Committee for that purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: I indicated the need for some caution about the number of Bills that ought to be referred to committees, pointed to the history of the Senate over the last 18 years in developing the experience of referring Bills to committees, and indicated my view that I did not think a great many more Bills should be referred to committees than has been the case in recent years, when the practice has grown quite considerably. If the Senate is going to adopt a different policy of referring a large number of Bills to committees, then we would really have to engage in a great restructuring of our procedures in the time that we spend in this chamber, and in the number of weeks that we spend in Canberra. I am addressing this question on the assumption that there will not be any major change to past procedures but that there will be a more satisfactory way of selecting Bills and a more orderly basis for doing so. The Senate has already made some very considerable progress in selecting Bills by the informal processes that we have adopted.

That relates to one of the first matters which I have difficulty with, recommendation No. 3, which proposes, subject to any change in the pattern of sittings in the Senate and subject to appropriate adjustments of the broadcasting arrangements, that Wednesday of each sitting week be set aside for committee hearings-that is, for committees dealing with Bills. That is subject to those two very major qualifications, and they could well and truly torpedo that idea. I think very grave difficulties will have to be overcome before those conditions can be satisfied.

I want to address some cautionary remarks about the principle of setting aside one of the days on which the Senate already sits to enable those committees that have Bills before them to devote that day to consideration of their work. As I said, the wisdom of that recommendation depends very much on the number of Bills that are referred to committees and the number of committees that will be sitting to consider Bills in any one week. Clearly if only one or two committees have Bills currently under consideration there would be an enormous waste of time in having other senators sitting around on one day every week and not progressing the other pressing work of the Senate. That would seem to me to be an absurdity.

TALK.START.PARA: —We sit around for four days a week and don't progress any.

—That is the problem. Legislation is brought in at such a late hour and in such an inefficient program, despite the honourable senator's so-called management of this place. More and more legislation is being brought in at the end of a session.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Robert Ray interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is no good putting that line up; until recently the Government did not have any legislation to speak of here in this session. That was quite an unnecessary diversion. The Senate now has to sit for many weeks longer than the House of Representatives, and probably longer than it has done in the past, in order to cope with the volume of legislation the Government brings forward, a large amount of which no doubt could well be abandoned although the Government bores on with it.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also very unrealistic to believe that a committee will do its job on these odd days during sitting weeks. We would get two such days in a month to do the job. As Senator Hamer says, if it is desired to have these committees work efficiently, get on with the job and get a report in, they will not be able to do so by sitting on those odd days; they will have to do the job in non-sitting weeks. Otherwise, the reports will not be worth having. Furthermore, if the committees do their job and put down worthwhile reports, there will be more work for the Committee of the Whole. It is quite unrealistic to go on with these new proposals under the illusion that we, as a Senate, will not sit more often and for longer periods. I will not go to the wall about it but I do think that recommendation No. 3 is based on very unrealistic assumptions about what is likely to happen. It will not help the general disposal of business of the Senate, about which the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) seems to have some complaints, but for which he as well may have some responsibility.
Recommendation No. 5 gives me the greatest concern and it is the only one I have proposed to amend. The recommendation provides that:
Debate on appropriation bills in committee on the whole be confined to matters referred to in Estimates Committee reports for further examination.

I understand that the real concern at the bottom of this recommendation is the fact that when the Committee of the Whole deals with Estimates committee reports, which we have just been through and which we go through twice a year, honourable senators ask a number of new questions; they start new lines of questioning in addition to the lines of questioning that have already occurred in the Estimates committee hearings. That may be due to the fact that senators may not have the opportunity of attending a particular Estimates committee hearing. That would apply particularly to Independent senators or senators from minor parties. I notice that Senator Harradine has put forward an amendment to cope with that problem. It certainly would be most unfair for a senator who had not been able to attend a hearing and who was not a member of the committee, and thereby would not be able to have the matter dealt with in the report of the committee, to be shut out from raising the matter during the Committee of the Whole. That certainly needs to be attended to. Senator Harradine has dealt with the proposal in a more narrow way than I have in my amendment. I certainly support at the very least Senator Harradine's amendment to the proposal.

However, I have some broader concerns about the rights of senators. I believe that senators should be able to raise matters which have been canvassed at an Estimates committee. My proposal would not enable senators to raise matters which they could have raised but did not raise at an Estimates committee meeting. But where an Estimates committee has elicited information, any senator, even if a member of the committee, should be entitled to comment on the information obtained at the committee meeting. I do not think that a right to make comment on the matters that have been dealt with in a committee or on information that has been obtained at a committee should be restricted in this way. The proposal of the Select Committee is very restrictive indeed. It restricts comment to only those matters that are contained in the report of a committee or to reservations attached to reports, presumably by other members of the committee.

One can overcome my concerns if one is a member of the committee or if Senator Harradine's amendment is carried, thus enabling senators who are not members of the committee to put down reservations. That would mean that a great deal more bureaucratic activity would have to be engaged in by senators in order to raise the matter in the Committee of the Whole. I think that is a very severe and unnecessary restriction of the rights of senators. I am certainly in sympathy with the idea that they should not be able to ask a whole lot more questions here. That is not the problem. Senators should be enabled to debate the issues that have been raised in the Estimates committees. In my view, matters that have arisen since the Estimates committee hearings should also be able to be raised in the Committee of the Whole when these reports are debated. A great deal of information today is delayed by departments. Their information is often not available when the Estimates committees report. Information is often presented after the report of an Estimates committee has been finalised and before the debate occurs in the Committee of the Whole.

There are a number of very severe restrictions in proposal No. 5 of the Committee. Certainly, there should be some amendments, at least to the extent that Senator Harradine has proposed and, I hope, somewhat along the lines that I have proposed in my amendment. Subject to those comments, I support the recommendations. I move:
Motion (5), at the end of motion, add ``, subject to the following amendment of the order:
Paragraph (2), leave out all words after `matters' (first occurring), insert: `which have been raised during the hearings of Estimates Committees or which have arisen since those hearings.'.''

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I rise to indicate support for the ideas contained in this series of motions, which hopefully the Senate will vote on tonight. In determining how one goes about changing the way in which the Senate operates, there are two major items to be taken into consideration. One is that the Senate has to be a reasonably proficient operation in terms of its essential business, which is legislation. Secondly, it must do it in such a way as to give all senators elected to this place due and proper consideration so that they can express their views adequately and make their position known on votes which are to be taken. The second item, the rights of individual senators, often has been interpreted in a very narrow fashion. It has been interpreted on the basis that every senator should be able to talk at any length on any matter whatsoever. The difficulty with that is that, every time one senator speaks, it reduces the time available for all the other senators. There has to be a balance. That is very difficult to achieve.

SPEECH.PARA: Depending on the types of Standing Orders that we have in this place, it is possible for somebody who is fairly knowledgeable of the Standing Orders to tie up this chamber in such a way that it could not process any business. It is not very difficult. If anyone wants to know how to do it, I am quite happy to run through a list of five or six propositions which would tie up the chamber and simply make it unworkable. That seems to me to be taking the situation to an extreme. These recommendations are attempting to take another step along the line of trying to give all senators a reasonable opportunity and to make sure that the work is processed.

Senator Durack alluded to a number of matters, one of which was whether or not any legislation was around. I totally disagree with his comments. A lot of legislation was listed on the Notice Paper. I invite Senator Durack to go back and select any of the Notice Papers. He will discover that there were plenty of Bills to discuss at any time that we have met in this chamber since August. In fact, we had a huge amount left over from the first half of the year. We did not run out of Bills to deal with. The Senate is hardly likely to run out of Bills ever again because of the way it processes them.

That is not the problem. One of the worries that I have had-the Senate has seen fit to support a motion that I have moved for a number of years now-regards a cut-off date. In recent times the House of Representatives has become very upset about that. But it was an attempt to stop the flow of Bills which were supposed to be passed by the end of our session, at some time before the day on which we actually finished sitting. We now have in front of us some orderly process for the next three weeks. I think that it is the order in which the business is taken and the way in which it is dealt with that is a major problem.

Again, some of these suggestions go to that point. They do not go very far and represent only a very small step. If we do not come to grips with the way in which we do business, acknowledging always that it is unlikely that the Senate will sit much longer than it currently does, the problems will always exist. One way of dealing with the problem is to sit for a longer period. For example, we can sit for the same length of time, as Senator Hamer noted, as the Canadian Parliament, the British Parliament or the American Congress, all of which sit at least twice the length of time that we do.

If that is what people intend to do, they have to acknowledge that there will be a dramatic change in the political structure of the Federal Parliament. Constituents would not be able to see their elected representatives in their electorate offices. Even now, because senators are committed to a sitting which is about 40 per cent longer than that of the House of Representatives, I am sure that they are already having enormous difficulty meeting their constituent obligations. Being able to find any time to spend in an electorate office to fulfil the long list of engagements of people wishing to see us or who bring representations to us in our own State or Territory is now becoming a very difficult task. If the Senate doubled the length of the sittings I think that we would have to agree that that would place elected representatives in a totally different political context. I am not at all sure that the electorate is interested in that sort of change at the moment-possibly over time, but certainly not suddenly. Any development that we take will be of a nature which is slow, probably methodical, and step by step. If honourable senators look at the changes that have been made in recent times they will see that those changes have been of that nature.

With regard to the amendments which recently have been brought into the chamber-I would have preferred these amendments to have been circulated earlier-I note that this report was put down in December last year. It is not as though the report has been dropped on us all of a sudden. For months there has been an indication, by way of notice, as to when the matter would be debated. Senator Harradine's amendment is an important one. It takes in something that has been left out. I think that it ought to be supported. I support Senator Reid's amendment because it would not be very nice to write into the procedures the suggestion that the current Opposition might be in opposition for life. I think that that wording will probably meet the problems that we have. Senator Durack's amendment takes us back to the status quo. I listened with interest to the various points that he raised. For example, he said that there might be questions that were asked and the information has not been brought forward. That is already dealt with in the report. The Estimates committee report would simply note that the items had not been answered and hence they would be open for debate. Already contained within the report is the view that it is up to the people on that committee or, taking Senator Harradine's amendment into account, any senator, to make sure that that Estimates committee report contains the various items they may wish to raise at a later stage, or refers to them as being yet unanswered and hence enables the senator to raise them again in the Committee of the Whole. All that it is asking, I think, is a reasonable proposition that one should use the Estimates committees for the purposes for which they were set up.

I know that it increases the difficulties. Most of these new sessional orders will make it more difficult for members of the Australian Democrats. I said that at the very beginning when we first brought this report in: smaller groups in this place would have much more difficulty with them. However, all my colleagues have looked at these in detail and are willing to support them on the basis that we believe that the orderly processing of business in this place is what we are supposed to be about. We will accept that additional burden, and it will be quite onerous for us to meet some of these items having regard to our small number. Hopefully, at the next election we will be able to alleviate that problem somewhat by increasing our numbers, thereby making the job less onerous. At least, from 1 July, there will be more Democrat senators in this chamber, so that will make the task somewhat easier. Nevertheless, it will still be a relatively small number compared to other parties.

I believe that in those circumstances everybody is entitled to look at these sorts of items in terms of how they might affect them. This will affect us. We are willing to take on this additional problem because we think it will, in all fairness, enable all senators to have a reasonable time and a reasonable chance to have their views known on major matters.

As we come into these last weeks, we will find that a considerable number of important Bills will get very little time for debate. It is something that the Committee was appointed to solve. I do not think we have got terribly close to that. However, if these are accepted, it might open a window of opportunity further down the line for that to occur. I am not at all sanguine that that will be the case, but let us hope that it is a possibility.

Without a better spacing of legislation throughout the entire time that we sit, I believe that senators' rights will be severely affected. If one or two senators decide to spend a week or two on one Bill, they are denying other senators who may have an interest in a different piece of legislation their right to have a reasonable debate on the Bill of their interest and concern. So the spacing of Bills throughout the period is vitally important. The hope is that those additional references to committees, which undoubtedly will occur under this regime, will assist that particular task. It may or may not, in the famous phrase that is bandied around-who knows? Hopefully, it will, and therefore all senators will have an enhanced opportunity rather than a decreased opportunity, as some senators, unfortunately, are seeing in these reforms.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly support the motions before the Senate and I am happy to commend one or two of the amendments which individual senators have moved to adjust the package before us. I will speak very briefly so we can quickly get to the most important stage of voting on the motions before us and seeing the reforms in place so we can improve the conduct of the Senate and the capacity of honourable senators to contribute in the more flexible way that these improvements to our procedures would allow.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend in particular my colleague Senator Hamer for the way in which he has introduced the reforms. I have carefully discussed these concepts with Senator Hamer over a number of years and I support what he said. I also commend the Select Committee on Legislation Procedures which is chaired by Senator Colston and comprises Senators Jones and Collins from the Government; Senator Reid, the Opposition Whip, with Senator Hamer; and Senator Macklin from the Australian Democrats, who preceded me in the debate this evening. This group of six senators has pulled together a process of reform with which I was very much involved over nine years. I was a chairman of a Senate standing committee during the last Government's tenure and initiatives taken in 1981 are still on the agenda. They have not received careful debate and resolution until now.

Former Senator Peter Rae was a prime mover in rationalising and improving a number of the measures that are before us. Former Senator Doug McClelland, who following those discussions became President of the Senate, contributed significantly to the bipartisan support for the reforms that are still largely before us in the motions that we are considering tonight. This debate leads me to commend not only my colleague Senator Hamer and members of the Legislation Procedures Committee but also former Senators McClelland and Peter Rae for refining the processes of the Senate which are renowned in Australia, and I think overseas in Westminster parliaments, for the forward looking way in which we go about our committee procedures in particular.

I refer to the innovation of committees sitting on Wednesdays and the actuality, achieved by the motions before us tonight, of Senate legislative and general purpose committees when, up until now, they have been mostly general purpose committees with an inquiry function-although occasionally legislation has been referred to them. I put it to all our colleagues in the Senate tonight that Senate standing committees have not lived up to their full potential as legislative committees. The motions which have been moved by the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) tonight would allow committees to play a fuller role-a role that was, I think, originally envisaged for the standing committees-in that they could consider legislation in a more regular way.

In commending the motions before us, I do not quarrel with the amendment put by my colleague Senator Reid on the composition of the committee that would recommend the referral of legislation to committees. I do not have any particular quarrel with the amendment put by Senator Harradine, because we need to recognise that there will be an opportunity in the Estimates committees for a majority report and dissenting reports. Those reports can indicate items that will come up for conclusive debate, or will require an answer from the Government, in the Committee of the Whole. Independent senators, or indeed any senator from the Government or Opposition who was unable to be a member of an Estimates committee, would as of right be able to indicate in the Estimates committee report or a dissenting report some matter for further reference to the Committee of the Whole. So Senator Harradine's amendment, which would allow any individual senator to reserve a matter at the point the Estimates committee brought its report down, certainly wins my support.

Senator Durack's amendment is one which, in principle, I support. Nevertheless, it can be won without being in the precise form in which Senator Durack moved it, which is that any unconcluded matter in an Estimates committee, any question that is not answered, ought as a matter of form to be indicated in that Estimates committee's report and must then be subject to an answer, with all the possibility of continuing questions and debate in the Committee of the Whole. So any matter that is seen to be a current matter, a matter that has a continuing, evolving life to it, would in all prudence be listed by a member of an Estimates committee amongst those items to be referred to the Committee of the Whole by that Estimates committee. So I do not believe that the Senate need now support the precise amendment that Senator Durack has moved but rather acknowledge that the procedures before us in the substantial matters moved by the Government are able to accommodate all that Senator Durack has been concerned about, and which I also am concerned about.

This is an historic moment. It is one that I have genuinely looked forward to for some nine years as I have participated in discussions with other chairmen of standing committees of the Senate, including Senator Peter Rae, Senator Douglas McClelland and a number of others, assisted by the staff of the Clerk of the Senate and others who have greatly assisted the development of the procedures of the Senate.

In the last five years, in particular, I have lamented the decline of genuine debate on legislation in the House of Representatives. I do not wish to reflect on the level of debate in another place. Rather, I wish to congratulate the Senate for the superior carefulness with which legislation, for the good of all Australians, is debated in this chamber. The numbers in this place are always, it seems, different from those in the other place. The Senate, throughout all the time I have been here, has been a genuine forum for debating legislation. That has not always been the case in the other place, where the iron numbers of the government majority have too much presumed that, because the government of the day has proposed a matter of legislation, it ought to be supported by those with the majority, the Government. So too frequently, even without the use of the guillotine, there has been a brief rehearsing of what legislation is about followed by too brief and inadequate a debate. That is one of the reasons why the Senate is sitting much longer.

The Senate is a place of debate about legislation. Setting aside Wednesdays as a committee day will, I believe, extend the reputation of the Senate and will ensure that there is a careful examination of all proposed laws for the people of Australia. For all of these nine years I have looked forward to this historic evening when we would reform the procedures of the Senate. I therefore genuinely support the motions that have been moved in response to the Legislation Procedures Committee, made up of government, opposition and Democrat members. I support the amendments moved by Senator Reid and the amendment proposed by Senator Harradine. I trust that the brevity of our remarks tonight will lead to this process being carefully concluded this evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like, very briefly, to refer to a few points. Senator Teague has just made every honourable senator's heart feel good about the tremendous work that we do here. But one of the things he did not say was that in the Senate we also have the repetition of the same sorts of speeches that are made in the House of Representatives. That brings me to another point I would like to make in regard to the real problem we have; that is that with every increase in the time that the Senate takes in committee work there has to be a corresponding reduction in the set play debates that are a complete repetition of the House of Representatives debates. I said that when we looked at the matter previously.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that we now have the Wednesday proposal I think means that we are getting to a realistic experiment. I think it is worthwhile looking at the last paragraph in the motion of the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) as we have the opportunity now of experimenting with something that is, I believe, realistic. To that extent, I believe that it is not terribly important in relation to the views that one might have on the amendments, but I think it is most important to let the experiment take place.

I would like very briefly to refer to Senator Watson's amendment because I have some concern about his reference to select committees. I appreciate the fact that he is creating the possibility of something being sent to a select committee. The point I would like to warn about is that, if the system is to work, then there should be standing committees that cover most imaginable problems. There will always be a problem, particularly for the Government, if select committees are set up and therefore by-pass the standing committees. The reason for that is to do with personnel.

It does not matter from which part of the chamber honourable senators come; they have the great difficulty of ending up on too many committees. Everybody is conscripted to an additional committee that he did not really want to go onto, but the Party requires him to do it. The system will not work if there is an abuse of the ability to use the select committees. I am not suggesting that that is Senator Watson's aim. I am drawing attention to the fact that, if it is not sensibly applied, then there will be a problem. The fact that we are looking at a trial period here makes it reasonably satisfactory.

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is sensibly applied it will work.

—That is a point. I do not object in principle, but I am a bit apprehensive because there is always a tendency for people with an angle at a particular time to whip it off to a select committee. That will make it much more difficult. In that context, I think we have to look at the problem. Pressure is placed on honourable senators on the Wednesday of each week, and if everybody personalises it, we can see some of the difficulties that we will have, especially when honourable senators are on committees that will have a heavier load of legislation than other committees.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter I want to draw attention to briefly is the problem that Senator Harradine's proposed amendment adverts to. I have no objection to the suggested amendment because I think it is a way in which a matter can be drawn attention to in view of the general change that is proposed. But I think one has to look at the fact that we have had a tendency in more recent times for there to be no attempt to reach agreement on an Estimates committee. With this new system there is a danger of moving further into government and opposition reports on Estimates committees. I have seen some situations in which the reservations have been longer than the committee's report.

I draw attention to the fact that, if the system is to work, Senator Harradine's amendment can be carried, but if it is abused-some people have thoughtlessly abused the system by making sure that their names have appeared on long minority reports-it will fall down. Consequently, the aim of Estimates committee reports and their reservations-to highlight points or to prioritise things-will be lost. We may as well then consider Estimates in the Committee of the Whole and spend the sorts of record times that we have recently created. The proof of the pudding will be in the eating and I look forward to the experiment next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a few comments on the report of the Select Committee on Legislation Procedures. Perhaps I should start by indicating the one part of the Committee recommendations that I certainly will not support-that is, the reduction in the quorum. The history of governments has always been that they have sought to reduce quorums or have got comfort from the reduction of quorums. They get comfort from anything which decreases the obligations which lie upon their members to attend in the chamber. The record of the attendance of Government members in the chamber is scandalous. It is usual for there to be far more Opposition senators in the chamber at any time, including Question Time, and certainly during debate on matters of public importance.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the legitimate tactics that an Opposition has in its armoury is the calling of a quorum, thus making it quite clear that it will not be simply a matter of asking the Government's back bench to respond to the quorum bells. If the Opposition finds itself cast in the role of needing to draw attention to a particular matter by calling a quorum into the chamber, as required by the provisions of the Constitution, the inconvenience which is alleged to be suffered by Ministers should be put up with. It is a discipline imposed on Ministers; it is a discipline imposed on any government to ensure that it does not bring about a situation in which the opposition is forced to call quorums in order to make political points or to even up the sort of abuse of Question Time that we get from Ministers like Senator Bolkus and Senator Cook. They seem to think that Question Time is simply there for them to make statements which they are not prepared to make in order to have them debated in the proper course of activity. For those of us who anticipate with some degree of confidence being on the government benches in the course of the next few months, it is a discipline that we are perfectly prepared to accept for ourselves.

I do not believe that the reduction in the quorum is a point which ought to be supported and I will certainly vote against such reduction in exactly the same way as, in defence of what I believe to be the basic institutional framework of this place, I voted against the large number of changes in the privileges legislation which sought to strip some privileges from this chamber. For that reason, I will not be voting in favour of the motion moved by Senator Robert Ray arising from the report that there should be a reduction in the quorum. As Senator Hamer rightly said in his speech, the only argument put forward was that a reduction in the quorum makes it easier for Ministers to avoid coming into the chamber when the quorum bells ring. That discipline ought to be imposed on Ministers, regardless of from which party they are drawn.

We then come to a series of other matters which are dealt with in these recommendations. I agree with the recommendations in relation to the time limit on the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders. As one who has never had any great difficulty in subverting the Standing Orders in order to talk about their suspension and one who has certainly never had any difficulty in going for considerably more than five minutes on that particular subject--

TALK.START.PARA: —You're not subverting; you do it well.

—I thank the honourable senator. I appreciate the compliment. I am certainly prepared to accept the discipline which is imposed there because it is quite clear that if the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders is so serious that the Government understands that it has to deal with the matter-whether it is a censure motion or a motion of no confidence-it will agree to suspend Standing Orders. Indeed, if it is a matter of form, in order to allow something to be done which is not of very great moment, we usually agree to the suspension of Standing Orders pro forma without any difficulty at all.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is perfectly legitimate that an opposition-it is nearly always an opposition which will be moving for the suspension of Standing Orders-can adequately make its point within the course of 30 minutes in an overall sense because the point which is being made is a political point and does not really need to be debated in a number of 30-minute speeches, of which 15 minutes is usually comprehended in the argument on points of order about whether the senator is speaking to the suspension of Standing Orders or is speaking to the substance of the motion which he wishes to move or to put forward. I think, therefore, that that will take away some of the element of theatre. I do regret the tendency by those without any degree of feeling and soul to destroy the element of theatre which ought properly to attend parliamentary debates and who believe that it should all be reduced to the merest mechanical operation; nevertheless I suppose that five minutes of a good rousing speech will do just as well as 20 minutes of trying to get round the Chairman's rulings.

TALK.START.PARA: —In that case, why not abolish speeches altogether?
—Do not strengthen my resolve in the matter, Senator.
—We could all go home for Christmas.

—The idea of going home for Christmas is obviously anathema to some people, but the honourable senator makes it more tempting by the moment. However, there are a couple of matters which I think require our further thought. I am prepared to support them on the basis that we are only entering into a trial period with some of these Standing Orders. I know that most of these trial arrangements tend to be set in concrete and, therefore, should be regarded with some degree of scepticism.

SPEECH.PARA: The question in relation to the non-debate of second reading motions is something that would have to be watched with some considerable degree of care. I note that the qualification in recommendation 4 (a) is that any senator may, in fact, prevent the question of the second reading being put without debate. Undoubtedly that increases the power of individual senators simply to indicate that they believe that the question of the second reading should be debated and that it should not be put pro forma. I think it will be a nightmare for the Manager of Government Business of the day to know how he is going to manage his program under these circumstances, because any individual senator may raise the question at the time-`orally at the time', says the recommendation-that that senator requires the Bill to be debated and, therefore, the second reading cannot be put without debate.

It means, quite clearly, that if the Opposition has a fit of the collective piques for a week or a day, or if the Australian Democrats have a fit of the giggles, as they frequently do during the day, they may simply-by way of any single Opposition or Democrat senator who feels he has been abused by a Government Minister at Question Time, or has been unfairly dealt with, or who feels that the Opposition or Democrats are being unfairly dealt with-say, `Right, our response to the Government's misbehaviour today is to ensure that there are no formal votes taken on second reading speeches'. We will indicate right at the death knock, when the Bill is before us, that we require that it be put aside and dealt with by way of a second reading speech which may or may not subsequently eventuate as a second reading debate. It will go on the Notice Paper for a second reading debate and that will give the Manager of Government Business, the parliamentary liaison officer and all those trying to plan the program, an absolute nightmare in trying to plan what our legislative program is going to be. We will not know until the matter comes before us whether there is going to be a second reading debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ordinarily we would work through our Whips.

—Of course we would work through our Whips. But every now and then individual senators have a fit of pique with their own Whips and occasionally they misbehave. Nevertheless, I am prepared to take that on a trial basis and see how it works. I agree with the comments about the imposition of a five-minute limit on third reading speeches. They are rarely used.
—In that case, why do you need the five minutes?

—Because, Senator Crichton-Browne, it is only when the motion for the second reading of a Bill is put without debate-that is, when there has not been a second reading debate-that it provides a quite clear and additional discipline on the dealing with non-controversial matters. I am strengthened by the fact that if ever I feel agitated with the way in which the Government is behaving I am conscious that there is still the first reading of a money Bill provision available under the Standing Orders. If the Government is getting to the stage where I think we need to impose some additional discipline on it during its last session of the Parliament in February-if it brings us back then-we may well have to start looking at the first reading of the money Bill debates in order to make a whole series of points.

SPEECH.PARA: I would now like to refer to the last group of recommendations which are the first ones addressed fundamentally in recommendations 1 (a) to 1 (e). I believe that more Bills should be referred to committees. I believe that that will improve the work of the committees. I support the amendment which has been moved by Senator Watson to allow the reference of Bills to select committees. From time to time there are very particular and technical matters which need to be referred to committees. We need to draw together people with a particular expertise on a matter-for instance, some of the Bills dealing with commercial legislation and copyright legislation. In these instances one needs a group of senators with a particular interest in an area of considerable technical difficulty who are prepared to invest their time and effort by way of a select committee to deal with the matter. Therefore, I support Senator Watson's amendment.

I do not want to anticipate debate, improperly, but in relation to the operation of other references, I understand there may well be a move by Senator Harradine to ensure that when a Bill is introduced by a senator who is not a Minister that Bill should be referred to a committee only with the consent of the senator concerned. I would strongly oppose that. Once a Bill is introduced into the Senate it becomes the property of the whole Senate, not of the individual proponent of the legislation. It is up to the whole Senate to determine how it will deal with the matter.

Senator Reid's proposed amendment, as far as the Selection Committee is concerned, is eminently sensible and I will support it. In relation to the management of Estimates committees I believe that Senator Harradine's proposed amendment that there should be the capacity of senators who are not formally members of Estimates committees to have a better input into this process is correct. His proposed amendment regarding the attachment of reservations is also correct.

I am troubled by Senator Durack's proposed amendment. I think that for the purposes of trialling this matter Senator Durack's amendment should be supported. I say that because, if it is not, one of the things that will undoubtedly take place is that departments which have been asked to provide information will deliberately withhold that information until the relevant Senate Estimate committee has reported. That is exactly what will happen within certain areas of the bureaucracy.

TALK.START.PARA: —We must automatically list those matters.

—If we were to list the number of matters which are simply outstanding in terms of non-replies from departments at the time at which the Senate Estimates committees are, by a resolution of the Senate, required to report, for some departments we will have pages and pages of unanswered questions. Some of those questions may be unanswered for good and proper reasons. However, some will be unanswered because departments will look at this proposal and say, `Let us take the punt that the Estimates committee will not report the matter which we want to keep out of the debate of the Committee of the Whole, and we will then rely upon a chairman to rule that the matter may not be debated in the Committee of the Whole because it has not been referred to in the Estimates committee report'.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Teague interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two things to be said about that: a large number of senators will not have been on the Estimates committee; therefore, they will not know what matters have not been responded to unless they have read the total transcript of each of the six or seven Estimates committees. With the best will in the world I have no intention of trying to read everybody else's Estimates committee hearings. Nevertheless, there are matters which, if brought forward for attention, need to be responded to. Therefore, by supporting Senator Durack's amendment we can clearly achieve some discipline imposed on individual senators to try to confine their remarks to those matters which are raised in Estimates committee reports but they are not totally restricted from looking at matters which have arisen since those hearings. My friend Senator Teague knows well that there are many instances where, in the time which elapses between the report of a Senate Estimates committee and the consideration of the Committee of the Whole, other matters do arise which need to be addressed in the debate in the Committee of the Whole.

SPEECH.PARA: The final point I make about that is that that will become even more germane when one sees the sort of situation that we had in Estimates Committee D last time when two things occurred. Honourable senators will recall the debate we had about ministerial instructions to officers not to answer questions. Presumably, that would be covered simply because that point would be reported, but two thick volumes of additional material were supplied in relation to questions asked at Estimates Committee D, which is very difficult to get across. I think we have even seen in the last couple of days the presentation of documentary material from Estimates Committee A. After the debate of the Committee of the Whole has concluded we are still getting material in the chamber. Frankly, undoubtedly that will increase if there is a deliberate cutting-off, by way of some restriction relating the Committee of the Whole debate exclusively to matters which occur in the Estimates committee reports. Therefore, I will be supporting Senator Durack's amendment.

I conclude my remarks quite simply by paying tribute to those honourable senators who have taken the lead in developing these matters: Senator Hamer, who has certainly been assiduous in raising this matter with Opposition senators and focusing our minds upon it; and Senator Colston who was the Chairman of the Select Committee on Legislation Procedures. I believe that taking these matters on a trial basis is a good thing. I think some of them will be found to work effectively and some of them will be found not to work effectively. Under those circumstances I think we can then come back and try to achieve the best of all possible worlds. It is only by trial and error that we will effectively improve the legislative performance of this chamber while at the same time not trespassing unduly upon the rights which are properly those held by individual senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take long; however, I want to make some comments on this report, firstly because I have been waiting for nearly a year to do so-I remind the Senate that the report is dated 1 December 1988, and I think that says something about the practices of the Senate-and secondly because it is a very major reform. In my opinion, this is certainly the most major reform since the Senate set up the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, and therefore I think it is worthy of at least a brief contribution. Along with so many senators, I have been concerned for a long time that the quality of legislation which passes through this Parliament is not good enough. I have had reason to say that on many occasions, particularly in relation to commercial legislation. We note it from the law reports but it is not satisfactory that we have to wait for a judicial determination upon our work to see the failings of the language. Simply not enough time and care is put into the legislative process. It is easy to blame the draftsmen, but more often it is simply that the draftsmen, in the programs set by the Government, are not allowed sufficient time, particularly in the specialised areas, to do the job properly.

SPEECH.PARA: We then get to the role of the two chambers in this process. As was stated by my colleague Senator Teague, regrettably the contribution of quality and detail to legislation by the House of Representatives is negligible-and they are quite brazen about it. How often are we told, `We will leave the detail to you in the Senate; that is not our responsibility'. `Our responsibility is to play out the drama of politics. We are the House of the people and all that. Your responsibility is to look to the detail, and we rely upon you to do that.' How often are we told that by the House of Representatives? So accepting that the responsibility is in this chamber, the reforms suggested by the Senate Select Committee on Legislation Procedures are obviously of great importance.

The opportunity in the Senate to carry this responsibility lies, of course, principally in the committee stage debate of Bills, and consideration will either be through the standing or select committees or in fact in the committee stage in this chamber. In committees themselves, I specifically recognise the internationally renowned work of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and, more recently, the work of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I guess that my own particular experience in trying to improve the quality of legislation has come through my sitting on the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I remind myself of pieces of legislation such as the National Crime Authority Bill, the Cash Transactions Bill, the war crimes legislation and the tax file number legislation, all of which were dealt with in detail by that committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Freedom of Information Bill.

—Before my time, going back to Senator Puplick's time, the freedom of information legislation-all of which, I think it is fair to say, have been markedly improved by a careful committee consideration, and without that the legislative process would have been the poorer. I remind the Senate that I am talking about consideration of detail rather than principally considerations of policy, which are determined elsewhere.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had a recent experience from which I can draw a comparison when I look at two Bills of which I had the management on behalf of this side of the chamber-on the one hand, the corporations package and, on the other hand, the copyright legislation. The corporations package, which contained literally thousands of pages of legislation, went to a joint select committee which examined it in detail and reported back to this Senate, as a result of which the debate in this Senate was dealt with adequately within a matter of a few hours. On the other hand, the copyright legislation-again, a complex and technical piece of legislation-did not go to a committee but should have gone to a committee, and we were left with no alternative but to deal with the detail and many amendments in the chamber, as a result of which the debate literally took weeks. We got through the process, but it is clearly not the most efficient way in which to carry out our function. As a result, time is lost for improving other pieces of legislation. So if ever I needed a lesson as to the advantages of the proper use of the committees of this Parliament in improving the quality of legislation and the function of this chamber, it is that experience.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Haines interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that we have been joined by the Australian Democrats too. I wish to make a couple of further comments. I refer first to the lack of public participation in the legislative process. It appears to be a matter of mirth to Senator Macklin, but I think, compared with some parliaments, the absence of public participation in the legislative process is noteworthy. In fact, a comparison shows how unwelcome in some ways public participation is in this place. For example, in some systems I have witnessed in the United States of America, when a Bill is considered in committee, members of the public are actually invited to come and put a point of view. Obviously the debate has to be managed competently, and a good chairman can do that. It is an extension of participatory democracy which I applaud. I regret that that does not occur adequately within our system. I must say also that the way in which this building has been structured does not facilitate public involvement. It is difficult for members of the public to get into the committee rooms; they do not know what is taking place in the committee rooms, and in many ways their presence or involvement is unwelcome.
—It is discouraged.
—Yes, it is discouraged. I look forward to the day when we might see some value in involving the public more in this process; it would be to the benefit of the final product.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the matters dealt with in the report, which I dismiss, is that there is insufficient time for proper consideration of legislation-an argument which, of course, is always put by government. I suggest that, other than in the most exceptional circumstances, there is always adequate time. I again remind the Senate of the Copyright Bill I just mentioned, which went through the House of Representatives many months before it was finally debated in this place. There was more than adequate time for consideration within a committee. If I look again to my experience with corporate legislation and the practice that was adopted of exposure drafts, certainly that meant that the legislative process took a little longer but it meant that the community had a chance to participate, that views from specialists and other organisations were able at least to be taken into account to some extent in the process. Of course, the Senate was not always made aware of the contribution of these specialist groups, which was disappointing. Nevertheless, the practice demonstrated that there was adequate time for more detailed consideration of a piece of legislation.

It seems to me that there is no doubt that unless there are within the Standing Orders of this place requirements such as those we are debating tonight, governments will always argue that there is insufficient time. In other words, we need a mechanism that will force government, in effect, to take into account the need for proper debate of its legislation within the timetable of the Senate rather than the timetable of government. We want to get away from such experiences as taxation legislation, which is announced and deemed to be effective from the date of announcement but not debated and completed until sometimes 2 1/2 years after the time of the announcement. That is the type of poor legislative practice we should all condemn. One of the best reforms, I should say to Senator Macklin, that I have experienced in this place is the cut-off date for legislation from the House of Representatives, which forces government to look at the timetable of its program and ensures that there is more likely to be adequate time for debate in this place. Basically I accept the recommendations that are being debated tonight. Like all honourable senators I may have differed on matters of detail and I certainly intend to support the proposed amendment of Senator Reid and the amendments of Senator Watson and Senator Durack because I think debate on the Estimates will be unduly constrained by the language that appears in the motion that we are debating tonight.

It might be said that as a result of adopting these new processes tonight committees will be forced into greater specialisation, with more specialist inquiries rather than general inquiries. I do not think that is necessarily a bad thing because most general inquiries are carried on in any event by other bodies as well as the Parliament. In many ways our specialisation is the law-making process. In the long run, to force committees into greater specialisation and greater use of specialist staff to build up our own expertise within particular areas will provide for better quality legislation and ensure that the Parliament is more effective in requiring accountability of government.

With all those who believe in the importance of this institution, I look forward to the passage of these new procedures tonight as a way to enhance the standing of this chamber and, I trust, improve the quality of the product that comes out of our deliberations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I acknowledge the work that has been done by Senator Colston, the Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Legislation Procedures, and all the members of the Committee. I am sure that members of the Senate would agree with me that Senator Hamer has also contributed considerably to the preparation of these recommendations. On 28 September last year, as a result of what I assumed to be a general invitation to senators, I made a submission in writing to the Committee. In it I argued against proposals which might shift the focus away from proceedings in this Senate chamber to unpublicised proceedings within committees. I concluded with these words:

SPEECH.PARA: I fear that in transferring the focus from the chamber to a number of committees senators will be asked to accept a great deal more on trust and that a substantial part of the legislative process will take place away from adequate public scrutiny.

Unless somebody corrects me, the report that we have before us confirms that. I am concerned that sufficient acknowledgment or at least an adequate canvassing of that point was not given or included in this report. In fact, there is an explicit statement to the contrary. We are told at page 5 of the report that a scheme for committee examination of Bills entails a substitution for time spent by the Senate on consideration of the Bills. I also have a range of concerns which I will not go into tonight because I think, by and large, the issue is cut and dried. Unfortunately, as Senator Hamer said in his speech, it looks as though the matter-that is, this procedure of hiving off Bills to a committee-will go through in one form or another.
