I was very interested to hear what Senator Durack, the longest serving member of the Senate, had to say. What he predicted may well come true. He asked whether, given that this procedure is to be adopted, this is a guarantee that the procedures in this place will be streamlined or whether the institution of these procedures will mean a further wasting of the Senate's time. I indicate that I have foreshadowed an amendment to the first paragraph in respect of private senators' Bills. It would be fair for me now to outline that to the Senate. The proposed amendment reads:
Motion (1), at end of motion, add: ``, subject to the following amendment of the order:
``after paragraph (12), add:
`(13) A bill introduced by a Senator other than a Minister shall not be referred to a committee under this order unless the Senator has consented, in writing, to the referral of the bill.'.''.

I think that is important. Under normal circumstances, the honourable senator in charge of the Bill being debated in the Committee of the Whole-it is normally a Minister but in the case of a private senator's Bill, the private senator-is there to answer questions about the meaning of the Bill and its clauses. Under this procedure, it may well be that that senator may not be a member of a particular legislative and general purpose standing committee and therefore will not have the opportunity of being there to answer questions about the meaning of the Bill or to participate in the debate. I have no objection to private senators' Bills being sent to committees, provided the private senator is coopted on to the Committee. Senator Colston might be able to inform me what this cryptic remark on page 10 of the report means:

The membership of the standing committees may need to be adjusted to provide more opportunity for the Australian Democrat and independent senators to be members of committees. The existing procedures allow for such adjustments to be made.

I agree that there have been occasions when senators who were not members of a committee were added to a committee for particular references. Certainly, if a private senator's Bill is to be sent to a committee, in my view, that private senator ought to be a member of the committee. Otherwise, the Bills should be considered under the conditions provided by current Standing Orders. It would be generally accepted in this chamber that if a private senator's Bill were referred to the committee there would be no objection to a motion being moved so that that particular senator could be a member of the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the purpose of that Bill.
—Yes.
—Don't foreshadow it; move it.
—I was just saying that I would accept an assurance.
—He is suggesting it be done at the time of reference.

—As I cannot move the amendment because Senator Watson has moved an amendment to one of the motions, I foreshadow it. Finally, to cut down my speaking time a little, I will not argue my case on the Estimates committees because I understand that my proposed amendment on that is likely to be supported. I see it as a complementary amendment. As a matter of fact, I proposed it because I had in mind one particular department which regularly does not give the details of a very substantial sum of money. I think that in this Budget the proposal is for about $70m. I received the stack of information only after the Committee had reported to the Senate. I was able to arrange with the Minister who was at the table on Thursday or Friday that he would answer my questions if I gave them in writing. He assured me of that. My amendment is designed to cover that situation. I also see my amendment not as being in opposition to Senator Durack's amendment, but rather as complementary to it. I think that what Senator Durack has said is quite useful and I support it. He has referred to matters which have been raised during the hearings of the Estimates committees or which have arisen since those hearings. An Auditor-General's report, for example, could be received after the Committee has reported. That report could expose grave weaknesses in the particular department. I think it would be unfair on senators if, after that, senators could not raise questions with the responsible Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: We agree that there is a need for a streamlining of procedures, but we ought to make sure-particularly in respect of the Estimates-that the powers and functions of individual senators and, indeed, of the Senate as a whole to exercise their audit and control functions over the Executive Government should not in any way be diminished. I believe that supporting the amendments that have been proposed by Senator Durack and me will go some way to retrieving the situation. Though in principle I am opposed to the recommendations that have come forward, I will put my amendment forward in the hope that that will reduce what I see to be the encroachment on the rights and functions of individual senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -I will be brief because the issues that have been canvassed in the report are issues with which I agree. I agree with one of my colleagues who said tonight that he wished the amendments had been brought in a little earlier. After all, this report was brought down just over a year ago, and tonight we are faced with some amendments about which we have to make some decision. I would just like to comment in relation to these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not quite sure where we are in relation to the amendment circulated by Senator Harradine about adding a paragraph (13). I think that some work is to be done on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Colston, that has been foreshadowed but not moved. There can be only one amendment before the Chair at any one time.

—As the amendment stands at the moment I would not be able to support it because, as Senator Puplick mentioned, once a senator introduces a Bill, it becomes the property of the Senate. The Senate should then have the right to refer the Bill. I do not see any problem with referring a Bill to a committee if it is a private senator's Bill. The report of the Select Committee on Legislation Procedures did not canvass that matter but it suggested that the Committee should be able to call whoever it wants. If nothing else happens, I imagine that it would be a strange committee which would not call the person who introduced a private senator's Bill into the Senate. As the amendment stands I would not be able to support the addition of paragraph (13) as circulated.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no problem at all with the amendment which was foreshadowed by Senator Harradine:
Motion (5), at the end of the motion, add: ``, subject to the following amendment of the order:
After paragraph (2), insert the following paragraph:
`(2A) That a Senator who is not a member of an Estimates Committee may attach a reservation to the report of the Committee.'.''.

Senator Harradine and I have been associated on a particular Estimates committee for some time. I can see that there would be great difficulties if that was not in the report. I am thankful to him for raising the matter. In relation to Senator Durack's amendment, replacing some words with the words `which have been raised during the hearings of Estimates Committees or which have arisen since those hearings', I am afraid that I cannot support that amendment because, to use the words of Senator Childs, it would almost bring us back to the status quo.
A matter was raised by Senator Puplick in relation to this amendment. The matter was covered on page 19 of the report where it says:

The reports of the Estimates Committees should include schedules of questions not answered at the time of reporting, with a recommendation to the effect that those questions are referred to the Senate for further consideration until they are answered. This would allow questions still unanswered at the time of the committee of the whole debate to be referred to at the time.

When that matter was first raised it was mentioned by one of the Ministers-I think it might have been Senator Robert Ray-that that would place strict discipline on departments to get their answers in on time, or strict discipline on Ministers to ensure that departments would get the answers in on time, because if the answers were in on time there would be no need to debate them at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't time to consider them, when 50 pages come on the same day as the report is due to be considered.
—I expect that that is the case.
—They often send the replies to one office when you are in the other. They send them to the electorate office when you are in Canberra, and vice versa.

—I find it difficult to support that particular amendment. The other amendment which I would not be able to support is that of Senator Watson. At this stage when we are looking at this matter on an experimental basis, we should try to see that standing committees are able to cover all legislation. I am concerned that if Senator Watson's amendment were passed it could mean an expansion of committees. Senator Teague very correctly pointed out that the legislative function of the legislative and general purpose committees has not been used as effectively as it could be. I would rather see legislation go to the legislative and general purpose committees rather than a select committee. If we need people with specific skills, there is no reason why we cannot appoint people with specific skills to legislative and general purpose committees just for a particular Bill. We have done that recently with one of the committees here. I prefer to see it going that way.
—Then you have to appoint equal numbers per side and make arrangements for third parties and Independents.

—One would still have to do that with a select committee. I think for the purpose of our experimental period it would be better for us to stay with our standing committees rather than going into a select committee. There is one other matter that I have not yet raised and that is Senator Reid's foreshadowed amendment, which I think is quite sensible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make some general comments. They relate to the amendment I propose to move. It is an amendment which I suspect, from the vibrations I have received in the short time that I have been in the chamber, does not have an enormous amount of appeal to the vast majority of my colleagues. My amendment proposes that where the words `five minutes' are read, they ought to be amended to read `10 minutes'; and where a maximum of `30 minutes' is provided, that ought to read `60 minutes'.
—Is that only on the third reading question?
—No, that relates to all matters. It is not just an archaic principle or because I am a reactionary to change. By and large, I accept, with some trepidation--
—Progress.
—Senator Puplick suggests progress. Change is not always progress, as we have seen in recent State elections.
—It was on Saturday.

—Let me tell those who, from time to time, bother to listen to the House of Representatives, that their standing orders provide five minutes. They provide five minutes, but they do not provide for constructive debate, they do not provide for persuasive debate, and they do not provide for detailed debate. They provide five minutes of absolute gabble of a rhetorical nature simply for the purpose of the airwaves. So many of us have not yet got used to the idea that at any one time there are probably 300 or 400 people listening in any capital city to the goings on and deliberations of this chamber.
—You can see why.
—You can see why. It is inevitable that with this Government, people are turned off and tune off. The truth of the matter is that nothing can be said in five minutes.
—The Lord's Prayer can be said in five minutes.

—I learnt the Hail Mary in about 15 1/2 seconds when I was in a Catholic school. On one occasion I got a prize for it. I then went to a Presbyterian college for my sins, having learnt how the other half lived. If we accept that it is not an archaic practice to debate in this chamber, if we accept that it is still a fundamental plank of democracy, if we believe it is an appropriate and proper forum for free expression of ideas and responses to ideas in terms of arguments and persuasion of arguments, then we ought to have an appropriate time. What one is really saying with the five minutes is. `We are giving you a chance to say something, but nothing of substance'.
—`Don't get too excited about it', that is what we are telling you.

—Senator Haines is quite right. Perhaps what she should be saying is, `Don't get serious about it; don't get detailed about it; don't say anything persuasive'. What this is is a token gesture under the Standing Orders which provides that there is no gag. It is simply a token opportunity to be heard. It would be much more honest to abolish the five-minute debate altogether and say that honourable senators cannot speak. If what a senator says is to be meaningful-I use that terrible expression-and something of substance, it cannot be said in five minutes. One has only to read the House of Representatives Hansard to see how meaningless a five-minute debate is.

SPEECH.PARA: I accept that the general thrust of the proposals is to speed up the process. It seems to me that the Committee has been confronted with two choices-either to sit longer, which I think was raised by Senator Robert Ray, or to find a process of expediting the general procedures of the Senate. This is seen as a way of accommodating the general thrust that we need to find a way to expedite matters. We must remember that the Australian Parliament, particularly the Senate, has a pretty good record for passing legislation. It is to the credit of the Government-perhaps it is more to the credit of the commonsense of those who have the numbers-that the guillotine has not been used too often. In 1987 we sat for 84 days and passed 184 pieces of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Appalling.

—Senator Stone says that it is too many; I agree. The art of government ought to be reducing legislation, not increasing it. We always feel contented when we can point to the number of Bills that are passed by this chamber. However, 184 Bills were passed in 1987 and the Senate sat for 84 days. In 1985 in Canada they sat for 175 days-more than double the number of days that we sat-and passed 55 Bills. In the United Kingdom--
—They are pretty long winded, aren't they?

—I think that they have truncated legislation. However, I do not seek to diminish my argument; they are the figures. In the United Kingdom, in 1986 the House of Lords sat for 156 days-slightly less than twice the number of days that we sat-and the House of Commons sat for 157 days, an equivalent number, and passed 66 pieces of legislation. In some cases we have passed 300 per cent more legislation than either of those chambers.
—That is what is so appalling.

—I agree. We ought to get a warm inner glow from the fact not that legislation is not passed, but that it is not introduced in the first place-except when we are introducing legislation to dismantle this legislative process. My amendment seeks to change the five-minute limit to 10 minutes.
—To which?
—Wherever one finds the words `five minutes'.
—In the two separate cases?

—Yes. Where a maximum of 30 minutes is referred to in each case, that would be replaced by an hour. That is on the top side. If the time limit is five minutes, speakers will speak for the full five minutes. No doubt it will be argued that when there is a limit of 10 minutes they will speak for 10 minutes.
—When they have an hour they usually speak for an hour.

—It is interesting that in more historic times the maximum was not used. When there was an unlimited time honourable senators did not speak for an enormous length of time. When there was a maximum of an hour, with two or three notable exceptions who probably made significant contributions for the 60 minutes in which they spoke, by and large the 60 minutes was not taken.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of speeches during second reading debates, there are some of us who have the infection, but there are many who speak for less than 30 minutes. It is just a ceiling; it is not a minimum. I argue that there is nothing unreasonable-I hope that Senator Ray will think about it carefully-in extending the limit to 60 minutes. In a 30-minute debate, a five-minute limit will mean that six speakers out of the whole of the 76 senators will get to speak. If senators spoke for only five minutes, obviously one would double the number of speakers in a 60-minute debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unless the Senate determines otherwise, which it could do.
—That is right. I trust that this proposal will be seen in the generous light in which it is intended.

SPEECH.PARA: Might I just talk about the general thrust of this proposal. Inevitably, a significant number of pieces of legislation will be sent off to committees. That will very much be negotiated. The Whips will, between themselves, horse-trade and decide what is in their best interests. I have no doubt that every piece of legislation which Senator Dunn and Senator Vallentine think they can thrash to death-legislation which touches upon nuclear energy, conservation or whatever the fashionable, topical subject of their camp followers is at the time-will be sent off to a committee. No doubt there will be those on the Opposition side who will wish committees to look at legislation which they think deserves greater scrutiny not only for the best reasons but also for political reasons. There will be pieces of legislation the Government will want sent off for its own reasons. So a significant number of pieces of legislation will be sent off to committees. My concern is that, given the limited person power-is that what they say these days?--

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—Okay. Perhaps I should use the language I understand. My concern is that, given the limited manpower available, we will find that general purpose references will be the sufferers. The whole range of issues dealt with by committees now in a very responsible and proper way, which ultimately, almost without exception, provide excellent reports or excellent minority reports, will be diminished. That function will not be able to continue simply because it will not be possible to do both. My concern is that the vital and important element of the functioning and the activity of the Senate will be lost for all time. With respect, that is an advantage, by and large, to the Government but a disadvantage to the Senate and a very real disadvantage to the wider community. Matters are very often dealt with by committees that are not dealt with in any other forum, not only of the Parliament but within society. This results in very valuable and, at the very least, useful information in terms of stimulating debate on a whole range of subjects.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine referred to the necessity to provide for the Australian Democrats and Independents to take a role in these committees. I am glad that Senator Haines is here because she knows that I am a generous person and I would not say anything indelicate. I hope that from now on we will not see the Democrats pursuing self-interest on these committees but playing and fulfilling roles that thus far have very much been the responsibility of the Liberal Party of Australia, the Government and the National Party of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is that supposed to mean?

—Let me give Senator Haines an example, since she has asked me. I am on the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, and all those other sexy subjects. We are presently inquiring into drugs in sport. The Democrats insisted on having a voice on that committee. That voice, deafening by its absence, is Senator Coulter's. To my knowledge he has been to two committee hearings.
—He is also on three other committees.
—If he gives them the same attention that he gives to that Committee, I can tell Senator Haines that he will not die of exhaustion.
—How many Democrat senators serve on Estimates committees?

—To my knowledge there are none, but I do not say that in the full knowledge of events. I hope that the Democrats will play their part and deal with legislation which does not give them a few cheap short term votes. I hope that the Independents, on the occasions when they are in Canberra, will do the same thing.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the amendment moved by Senator Durack and that proposed by Senator Harradine in respect of amendments to Estimates committee reports. However, I am frankly opposed to the whole concept. I accept that an argument can be put that there are those on the side of the Opposition, whoever the Opposition for the time being might be, who saw sawdust during the discussion in the Committee of the Whole and asked, if not rhetorical questions, then questions that they had asked previously but they had not been happy with the answers and they wanted to recycle the same proposition. There are, because of the constraints in terms of time, occasions that arise in respect of all of us where there are matters of interest to us, of concern to us and of importance to us. We cannot address them, firstly, because we are not on the committee and, secondly, because we are unable to attend the committee.

It can be argued that any honourable senator is eligible and entitled to go to an Estimates committee and ask questions, but it is not a comfortable position to be in. I was at an Estimates Committee A hearing recently as a non-appointed member of the Committee and after I had asked questions for 15 minutes I felt terribly uncomfortable, as if I were an interloper or an intruder really interfering with the main game.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not feel like that at Estimates Committee D when you asked questions for an hour and a half.

—Yes, I did. It was only the warm looks of my colleagues that gave me sufficient courage to continue to pursue the matters. Inevitably, there will be occasions when honourable senators are unable to attend the committee hearing but want to raise matters in the Committee of the Whole. They may be unable to do so because the matters will not be contained in the committee's report or in a minority report. I would prefer the situation to be as it is. I suppose it is not beyond the wit of any honourable senator if the amendment is passed-I think it is Senator Harradine's proposed amendment-to put up an all embracing dissenting report and then use that as a forum, as an opportunity, through which to debate the various matters raised.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two other things I wish to mention. There seems to be much made of the fact that a lot of legislation goes through the Senate upon which there are long debates but no amendments on the second reading or in the committee stage, as if that is some sort of sin, and as if it is a filibuster by the Opposition. Of course one should consider money Bills, but more importantly one should consider what might be described by some as a non-controversial Bill, such as a road funding Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is controversial.

—Senator Reynolds says it is controversial. She is certainly right-it is controversial at the moment. There is not a local government that is happy with the level of funding that it is receiving from the Government at the present time. But these are Bills about which very many people often feel strongly. They do not propose the amendment, in some cases because it is a money Bill and they are unable to do that, but they think it is important and incumbent upon them to put on the record their point of view, the point of view of their constituents and the point of view of their political party. Simply because there are long speeches without amendments, in my view, really means absolutely nothing when trying to draw some conclusion from those statistics.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by saying that I see that it is proposed that committees meet on Wednesdays. That is perhaps not something to be debated or contemplated tonight, but it never ceases to amaze me that the one day on which the Senate is broadcast, Wednesday, is the day we rise early. I have never been able to understand the logic of that, irrespective of whether anybody cares whether the Senate is broadcast. When we hear the emotion in the voices and the manner of delivery when the Senate is being broadcast--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is just self-deception, isn't it?

—Senator Ray is absolutely right. We all have the temptation to imagine that radios turn on all over Australia every time we get to our feet. In Western Australia, thanks to the wondrous changes in broadcasting, it is impossible for people living outside the Perth metropolitan area to hear the broadcast of Parliament.
—I might move there.

—There was a time when the most avid listeners in Western Australia, other than friends and relations, were farmers on their tractors who had nothing else to do except count the times they had been around the paddock and listen to the broadcasts of the Parliament.
—That's how you got Walshie here.
—For what reason?
—Because he listened to Parliament on his tractor.

—I think Senator Walsh sat too long on that tractor with a tail wind and got poisoned. What does carbon monoxide poisoning do? I am sure there is a very good reason for our not sitting on Wednesday nights, but with this proposal we intend to perpetuate it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of speakers have referred to the amendment circulated in my name. I now foreshadow that amendment, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (1), at the end of the motion, add: ``, subject to the following amendment of the order:
Leave out subparagraphs (2) (a) and (c), insert the following subparagraphs:

`(a) the Committee consist of the Government Whip and 2 other Senators nominated by the Leader of the Government, the Opposition Whip and two other Senators nominated by the Leader of the Opposition, and the Whips of any minority groups;
(c) the Chairman of the Committee be the Government Whip, and the Chairman appoint from time to time a Deputy-Chairman to act as Chairman when the Chairman is not present at a meeting;'.''

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the two amendments that relate to recommendation No. 5, that is, the manner in which debates should follow up the reporting of Estimates committees. As it stands, the proposal states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . debate on that bill in committee of the whole shall be confined to matters in respect of which reports of Estimates Committees, or reservations attached to reports, have made recommendations that the matters be further examined by the Senate.

I agree with Senator Durack and Senator Harradine that that is an unreasonable restraint and with the points made by them that many answers come later, too late to be included in the report. That creates some difficulties which are not adequately met by requiring or suggesting that the Committee will list those matters that are still outstanding so that they may be raised in the appropriations debate. Quite frankly, there are other matters which emerge out of the sum of the parts of the cross-examination, the questioning, that takes place in Estimates committees.

It may well be that members of the Senate who are not members of individual committees may have a real interest in particular items that have not been referred to in the committee report. They should not be forced to rely on the good will of colleagues to put into that report what they wish to discuss by making some general point that emerges from the cross-examination. Senator Harradine's foreshadowed amendment goes part of the way to meeting that objection. We have to recognise that it is not only members of individual committees who wish to debate the appropriations covered by that committee. I deliberately do not belong to any committee so that I can attend all of them. Some people are unkind enough to suggest that I make a nuisance of myself at all of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —It could be worse. The Black Death lasted twelve hundred years.

—At least Senator Ray could not accuse me of attending with excessive vigour. I have to stress that my performance in Senate Estimates committees in terms of time taken has been massively exceeded by some of those who I suggest were asking questions that did not have any political point. I suggest that the waste watch exercise demonstrated that there was quite an amount of political point in the great bulk of the questions asked. I noticed the sharp intake of breath by some public servants when I walked into Senate Estimates committees with bundles of papers under my arm with little yellow stickers on them.
—You know the difference between billions and million, too.

—Exactly. I know the difference between billions and millions. The problem that we have with questions on notice not being tabled in the appropriate time really underlines the need for there to be pretty much an open go in the appropriation debates.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, I do not want to speak at length about this matter. I think what Senator Puplick said was exactly right in this area. I hope that there is widespread support for freedom to debate matters to be given to ordinary members of the Senate and not simply to the members of individual committees. In the name of giving ordinary senators a fair go and making debates on the Appropriation Bills genuine examinations of the Appropriations, I think that the burden of benefit clearly lies in supporting the two amendments that have been foreshadowed-one by Senator Durack and the other by Senator Harradine.

In conclusion, it is great to try to speed up the proceedings of this chamber, and it is great to have an experiment such as this. In my view, as the legislative process gets more complicated, and as governments become more and more involved in what is happening, there is a need for greater examination, not less; for greater inquiry, not less; for more informed debate, not less. The proposal as it stands in recommendation No. 5 I believe unreasonably limits the power of the Senate properly to examine the expenditure proposals and the activities of the departments that cover multimillions-indeed billions-of dollars. I strongly support the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable senators for their contribution to the debate. It was fairly free of pomposity and self-interest, which I think is a tribute to the chamber. Mr Deputy President, I think that you put your finger on it, though: this is a very auspicious time in which to move these motions as we on this side of the House, at least for a fleeting moment, ponder the fact that we may not always be on this side, and those opposite are thinking, `Well, with fortunes favouring us we may just make it to the other side'. How will this affect us? Both the Opposition and the Government can look with a bit of lateral thinking as to how this will affect them either way. I think that this is the sort of timing that we needed.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me just deal with some of the speakers. I will not give a fulsome response. I refer to Senator Watson's amendment. We have a free vote on this side too, although people will also look for a bit of leadership on these issues. That is at least something that we on this side of the chamber can occasionally do. It is a pity that on that side when the leader leads no-one ever follows; but let us not get political. I can see some sense in Senator Watson's suggestion. I would also, at some stage, like to see a limit set on select committees so that we know how they can be rationed out during the year rather than just established willy-nilly. I can see some sense in there being specialist committees. Those opposite might want three or four frontbenchers on them because of the sensitivity or otherwise on that side. Because of the sensitivity of that particular issue we may like to pick our own team to go in and fight. I can see some sense in the point made by Senator Watson.

Senator Durack made one statement that did irritate me a little. He said that there was no legislation ready this session. Let me assure him that there was. If he looks at the Notice Paper he will see that on this occasion there was ample to get us through until the rest of the legislation got in. However, it has not always been the case in the past and I acknowledge that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the day we had to start the Privacy Bill? There was not another one ready.

—Yes, there was, Senator. There were two Bills. There was an electoral Bill and a social security Bill. Senator Puplick was not here to have carriage of the electoral Bill because he was absent for proper reasons. Senator Powell was not ready to go on the social security Bill. These two Bills would have taken days to debate and could have proceeded, but because we try to have reasonable arrangements in here we decided not to proceed to facilitate the operations of the chamber. As it happens, this session we have had plenty of Bills to call on. It has to be acknowledged that that was not always the case.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also point out that in these debates everyone asks to sit longer. In a rather pompous way it is said, `Oh, we should sit longer'. The moment we put out the program to indicate that we are sitting longer everyone comes and whinges to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —But--

—Senator Patterson is a very good troop on this. Before the honourable senator interjects I have to say that she never wants to sit here for long. She has been consistent on that because she realises the futility of sitting longer. People just fill up the time. However, we will have sat an extra 4 3/4 weeks to the end of this session and we are still not going to cover the legislative program.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the Canadian example, Canada does not carry its agricultural Bills every year. It is allowed to carry the Bills for five years at a time. Canada does not get the pig slaughter levy Bills coming up every year. The Opposition here had the opportunity two years ago to change that but it insisted that all the honey Bills, the apple and pear Bills, the goat fibre levy Bills and others that I cannot even pronounce come up time and time again to inflate the amount of legislation we consider.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are distorting the argument.

—Have a look at the Canadian legislation, Senator Crichton-Browne. I have had a good look at the immigration area and I would not wish the Canadian immigration Bill on my worst enemy. I am pleased they have it because if that is the soft end of the market we protect our own borders thanks to their laxity. You cannot compare one system with another to determine whether there should be more or less legislation. If the Opposition ever gets into office we will see by how much it reduces the legislation program. I can tell the Opposition that it will not be by one iota.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not be supporting Senator Durack's amendment. I believe it opens up the whole farce of Estimates committees. I do not blame anyone for that. If I blame anyone, it is on my side. I think it is time to draw the line over the ledger. From 1975 to 1983 people in my Party drove the then Liberal Government's Ministers mad at Estimates committees. I think the Opposition has almost squared it; maybe not, because we had a better facility for doing it than it has.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLaren has a lot to answer for.

—Senator McLaren and all of the other old veterans. Maybe a good referee would say that we are level on points and that it is time to start again on that particular subject. There are some disadvantages for the Opposition in this approach. No-one on this side has stood up and said, `Look, there could be some problems for government in this package'. Will Bills get tied up in committees and never get out? Will dissenting reports in Estimates committees just reintroduce the Committee of the Whole debate again? We on this side are not free from doubt; we will try it. We must be flexible to amend for the problems that will inevitably arise out of these sorts of reforms. There will be problems.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Puplick attacked the proposal on the quorum. The proposal for quorums is there for two reasons. When the Committee was moving the turkey around the plate between the Opposition side and the Government side, it found the Government side a little deficient and added a few vegetables-the quorum proposal-just to balance up the overall approach so that no side could be seen to be having a win. Senator Puplick is fairly scornful of the quorum approach, yet this chamber without debate changed the House of Representatives quorum requirement to a fifth at the end of the last session, but it will not change our own. The only reason we are seeking to change it is because of a change of geography in this House. Ministers have a three-minute walk to and from the chamber. I am not saying that quorum calling has been abused. I thought it was for the first session in this Parliament. Other than that it has not been onerous but it could be. The Opposition is saying to Ministers, `We do not want you to get on with your daily work; we want you wandering backwards and forwards to the chamber'. The counterargument to that is: what if Ministers misbehave in the chamber? Do honourable senators opposite want to punish them by calling quorums? I will tell those opposite how to punish them-by exempting them from coming and telling the back bench to come. The backbenchers will exert discipline over the Ministers much quicker than if the Ministers have to turn up. I really do not think that argument holds water. Up until 40 minutes ago I had always said that, if I go into opposition, my only present to an incoming government will be that I will move the quorum Bill from opposition. I will not any more, after Senator Puplick's comments. Fair go, I am not that big a mug. All I am asking the Opposition to do here is to support the change in principle.

I will give Opposition members an example of the problem. Some months ago I had a meeting with eight people who came over from Western Australia. I had only a one-hour timeslot to see them-between 12 and one. During that time three quorums were called, and the whole meeting was a disaster.

TALK.START.PARA: —You get a pair.

—The honourable senator says, `Get a pair'. Only five pairs are offered at any one time. I do not complain about that but we have these meetings all the time and we cannot be paired all the time. The reduction from 26 to 19 is also in recognition of the fact that we tend to have more Senate Ministers here. Honourable senators opposite may not agree with that; they may want us to go back to six Senate Ministers here. But one of the reasons we shifted to nine was the immense chamber duty load, the Estimates committee load, et cetera.
—Backroom deals.

—The honourable senator adduces other reasons. All sorts of reasons come into it. But they were some of the considerations-not the sole consideration, that is for certain. They were not excuses but considerations. I think the reduction of the quorum would serve a useful purpose.
—The motions do not seem to give effect to the reduction of a quorum.
—No. I would need to move, and I would move tomorrow--
—Therefore we should not be worrying about it.

—There are only two ways we can handle that. The first is by legislation, which I have had prepared for a year or so and which I will give notice of tomorrow. Frankly, I doubt whether we will debate that legislation this session because it is obvious that, with opposition, we cannot afford the time. Secondly, we could move an amendment to Standing Orders and it would not be ultra vires of the Constitution if we said that only one quorum could be called a day. At one stage that is what the House of Representatives contemplated. So those are the two ways of dealing with that problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine has moved one amendment that I certainly see sense in, and he foreshadowed another that I see no objection to. I do not think I should explore that matter much further. I have no objection to those amendments. Turning to Senator Crichton-Browne's contribution, I have dealt with the allusions he has made to other countries; I just do not think they are relevant. I take it that the Opposition's continual attacks on the performance of the House of Representatives is a no-confidence motion by the Opposition front bench. Maybe I am just being pretty obtuse in saying that.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is a purely objective assessment.
—It does have the same touch of arrogance that I have seen over there in terms of the treatment of the Senate. At times I wish we could get away from some of this chauvinism.
—They do what they do because the Government has the numbers and they can do what they want to do. It has got nothing to do with the best forms of the Parliament.

—Yes, but it is rare for the guillotine to come in until the last couple of weeks and, if anything, the guillotine has been enhanced by the cut-off date, which some honourable senators opposite are starting to recognise. The cut-off date is almost certainly making the guillotine inevitable. But there would be nothing wrong in both chambers having a different role-and for this chamber to be looking more intensely at the technical aspects of Bills, et cetera; I see nothing wrong with that.

SPEECH.PARA: That honourable senator's plea regarding five-minute speeches does not really hit a responsive chord with me. I think changes to Standing Orders are long overdue. One of the great reasons for changing Standing Orders is simply to take inordinate pressure off the Chair. To speak to a suspension of Standing Orders honourable senators have to go to the urgency of the matter. People are simply putting the content in there. It is a game of cat and mouse. No-one really wants to embarrass the Chair or take it on over it, but it is really causing inordinate pressure. It will make for some sparkling five-minute speeches but I do not see that as the end of the world. I think we can see that evolving in this chamber. These days it is fairly rare for a suspension of Standing Orders to be opposed.

On the question of the selection of Bills, some restriction had to be put on it, such as half an hour or five minutes. If that goes every day that is another two hours out of the program. By the way, this chamber has institutionalised reforms over the last seven or eight years. We spend a lot of time: half an hour a day debating papers, the General Business day, an hour for committee reports, et cetera. We are institutionalising a lot of those things. The only thing that we got rid of was that mindless reading of petitions which took 47 minutes on one day. So, from that point of view, I would still be minded to stick to five-minute speeches.

In conclusion, it is really a suck it and see exercise. This is a fairly finely balanced package which has part of the Opposition a bit worried around the edges and part of the Government a bit worried around the edges. It is a question of seeing how well it works and being flexible enough to change it. This procedure is not a standing order. It will operate for the first few months of next year or until there is an election next year. We can experience it and see how it operates. If the procedure operates badly, whichever government is in office will probably seek to dump it. If it works, this chamber will be far better because legislation will get far more scrutiny and the processes in this chamber will work more quickly. If it does not work, we go back into that anarchistic swamp where we are here until the day before Christmas or well into the winter and senators cannot take the trips that they plan. Senators would miss their fact-finding tours while the sun is still out in Europe, and that is a big tragedy that we all want to avoid.
Debate (on motion by Senator Jones) adjourned.

That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —David Selwyn Nelson died at the age of 54 early in November. He was one of our most distinguished immunologists. David Selwyn Nelson was a Bachelor of Science, Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery, Doctor of Philosophy (PhD), Doctor of Science, Fellow of the Royal College of Pathologists of Australia and Fellow of the Royal Australasian College of Physicians. Tomorrow in the non-denominational chapel of the Royal North Shore Hospital of Sydney the Reverend Keith Little will conduct an ecumenical memorial service for David Nelson.

SPEECH.PARA: The Royal North Shore Hospital was my hospital for 18 years. It was the place where I came to medical maturity, and I will be there tomorrow as part of the congregation. I wish to speak tonight, in a way I have never done before, to make an obituary statement about David Nelson and to contribute to what my colleagues will be doing tomorrow at St Leonards in Sydney. Tomorrow's ceremony will celebrate the life of an outstanding Australian scientist. I knew him from his school days-we were at the same school-and when he went to Sydney University he was one of that small group that left the medical course halfway through to take a Bachelor of Medical Science course. He so impressed the senior teachers that one of them, Emeritus Professor Patrick de Burgh, a noted yachtsman as well as a very good bacteriologist, took a special role in encouraging David's professional direction. I wish to set some of that out, using and drawing upon comments that were made on a previous occasion by my friend and colleague, Peter North.

After he finished his Bachelor of Science, David Nelson went to Yale as research assistant under a Dr Robert Nelson, who was no relative. He worked further with Dr Nelson in recent years. He then came back to Australia and finished his medical degree. But before doing his medical residency, which of course is a necessity to obtain registration, he returned to the United States where he was a visiting investigator at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute in Miami. In 1961, he went to the Australian National University and gained his Doctor of Philosophy, becoming expert in immunology and building up his reputation. While he was there, he met Margaret Martin-Smith, herself a distinguished medical investigator, whom he married. We have known her ever since as Peggy Nelson. Peggy then had her Master of Science, to which she later added a PhD. They then went off to St John's College, Cambridge, for two years. My wife Jenny and I had the opportunity to join him there socially on several occasions. David Nelson took up the Meres senior studentship in medical research, a position which he won against intense international competition, at St John's College in Cambridge.

He returned to Australia in 1965. He was immediately appointed senior lecturer in bacteriology at the University of Sydney. In 1966-that is, only eight years after my cohort graduated in medicine-he became a reader, and he held that position until 1974. During that period honour after honour was heaped upon him. He became a Fellow of the Royal College of Pathologists of Australia; he was appointed a member of the National Health and Medical Research Council committee on organ transplant and renal dialysis; he was appointed to the World Health Organisation expert panel on immunology; his major book Macrophages and Immunology was published; he was head of the World Health Organisation Immunological Research and Training Centre in Singapore; he became a Fellow of the Royal Australasian College of Physicians, of which there are two fellows in this Senate; and he was elected an honorary Fellow of the Philippines Society of Pathologists.

During this period he was also awarded, as Senator Dunn will know, the very senior degree from the University of Sydney of Doctor of Science, a degree which very few people attain, and it was awarded on the basis of his published work. He became visiting Professor in Microbiology at Yale University and he was a member of the Joint Specialist Advisory Committee on Immunology of the Royal College of Physicians in Australia and the Royal Australian College of Pathologists.

At this stage he was only 40 years old and had attained a very significant international reputation. The Royal North Shore Hospital-my hospital-had a vacancy occur in its own research institute, the Kolling Institute of Medical Research. That institute had been established by Dr Wilson Ingram, who died in 1974, and the hospital was looking for a successor. Ingram had had the vision to provide a refuge and home for a refugee from Europe, Dr Rudolf Lemberg, one of the world leaders in porphyrin chemistry. Lemberb had made the Kolling Institute known throughout the world. In 1974 the Royal North Shore Hospital had the very good sense to appoint David Nelson as the first full time director of the institute. At the time he was appointed I recall people in the hospital saying that we wanted a successor who would be a world leader in his field. David Nelson was certainly that. I am told that the President of France, at a scientific meeting in that country, once introduced Nelson to an audience of distinguished world specialists as `Mr Macrophage'. The macrophage is one of the cells in the blood which plays a central role in immunology. David Nelson took the Kolling Institute to a place of great eminence in Australian science, and he himself continued to achieve and work.

It is cruel that he was cut down this year by the non-smokers' lung cancer. He was a committed non-smoker. He was a sportsman of some note. He was a yachtsman; his yachts were all called `Macrophage', and at the time he died his yacht was `Macrophage IV'. There are some stories about sailing with his family across the Tasman. He fell overboard; his wife, who luckily had a line attached to her, also fell overboard; and their young daughter had to bring the boat about to save both her parents. There are many stories we can tell about David Nelson. He came from a very famous Sydney medical family. His father, Dr Selwyn Nelson, is well known to many Sydney graduates, and his mother, Dr Wilhelmina Nelson, known as Willa, is also well known. They are both alive and they will both be there tomorrow at the Royal North Shore Hospital.
I am reminded of some lines by Housman from A Shropshire Lad:
The troubles of our proud and angry dust
Are from eternity, and shall not fail.
Bear them we can, and if we can we must.
Shoulder the sky, my lad, and drink your ale

I am sure that Peggy Nelson would be aware of those lines and so would their daughter Victoria. Peggy is an eminent immunologist in her own right, and her daughter Victoria is a talented musician. This is a family that worked as a team and had some memorable experiences; but a memorable life has ended and there will be a memory of David Nelson which many of his colleagues and friends will not forget. It is a sad loss for Australia. He is dead, and I will be there tomorrow with, I think, a very large group at the Royal North Shore Hospital. His work lives on. We should mark his passing with respect and pride and with love and affection for the members of his family who have had to bear a very difficult time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to make a few remarks about the south-eastern forests of New South Wales and the forestry industry. On 11 December the report of the biological resources study into the south-east forests of New South Wales will be delivered to the New South Wales Minister for Resources, Ian Causley, and also to the Federal Minister for Resources, Senator Cook. The study was part of a compromise agreement between the State and Federal Ministers and it was made up of six scientists, three nominated by New South Wales and three nominated by the Federal Government. Without prejudging the report, it is hard to see it resolving the basic conflict over the use of the National Estate areas of these forests. Mr Causley has continued to make belligerent statements which have been answered with threats by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) to use the corporations power of the Constitution to protect the National Estate areas. These threats are somewhat hollow since the Government has put no legislation before Parliament to make the latent constitutional powers effective, and a great deal of forest could be cut down before such legislation passed both Houses of Parliament and became effective.

SPEECH.PARA: This year I have been working on legislation that would give the Federal Government the immediate power to regulate to protect the National Estate areas and I tabled a Bill to this effect in the Senate on 22 November. Although this is, I believe, temperate and realistic legislation, the Government has so far shown no interest in supporting it. But I believe it is likely to do so as conservation groups put more pressure on the Government in the lead-up to the Federal election.

However, we need more than just legal means to protect important natural assets. We need to rethink and restructure our resource use practices so that we can afford to preserve important natural areas while maintaining profitable and sustainable resource-based industries. Timber companies and timber worker unions portray the current dispute over logging in the south-east forests as one of a choice between jobs and the environment. They stress the relative poverty of the region and the paucity of jobs and employing industries. In contrast, conservationists are likely to refer to the local historical sequence of industries-the whaling and koala industries and other industries, including the skin trade, which are dependent on native mammals and which collapsed as the natural resources were over exploited.

I feel a considerable sympathy for the timber workers who have protesters bursting into their workplace and, at least implicitly, accusing them of despoiling our national heritage. Under the circumstances, most loggers have reacted with restraint but some people on both sides have wrongly personalised what is basically a political debate about the proper use of our resources. However, the choice is not really between jobs and the environment but between a few short term jobs within the existing unsustainable industry and a switch to a sustainable modern industry, offering just as many jobs. Government or industry support would be needed during a transition and establishment period but this need is a result of the past dereliction in reinvestment and planning by successive State and Federal governments. The latter choice also has the advantage of broadening the local industry base with the addition of a value added timber products industry and the preservation of a tourism resource.

The National Party shadow Minister for primary industry, Bruce Lloyd, visited the region in August and put out a press release in which he claimed that well-managed forests would last forever. However, the figures tell a different story. They tell us that the sawlogs will be cut out of the forests early next century, when the oldest of the regrowth timber will be only 40 years old and not large enough for economic sawmilling. At that point there will be a choice of closing down the industry for at least 20 years while the Forestry Commission still has to carry the costs of managing the forests, or pulping the natural regrowth, a process that will employ very few workers.

The recent history of forest industries in Australia shows a steady decline in the number of employees. Between 1970 and 1985 the numbers dropped by 25 per cent. In 1959-60 employment in timber extraction was 15,000, whereas in 1963-64 it was roughly 6,000. In this time total timber extraction from forests grew from 11 million cubic metres to 16.7 million cubic metres per annum. This occurred largely as a result of the closure of many small mills and increases in productivity. If the industry moves even further into pulp log cutting the number of jobs can be expected to decline further as this is the least labour intensive of all the forest industries. The other losses incurred by reducing most of the forestry regrowth are hard to estimate because, despite some excellent research done by researchers such as Dan Lunney from the National Parks and Wildlife Service of New South Wales, we have really only just started to investigate the ecology of these forests.

There is a lot of media emphasis upon the small cuddly creatures-the koalas, the potoroos and some of the bird species. We know that many of these will find it difficult to survive in forests that have been extensively logged, particularly after the second logging cycle occurs around the turn of the century. We also know very little about the invertebrates and the insects in the region or the non-commercial plant species. A eucalypt forest may offer much less variety than a rainforest but it nonetheless contains a rich diversity of plant and animal species and we do not know what we might find there until we look. Of course, conservationists also care about preserving plants and animals whether or not they offer an obvious utility for humans.

As the debate over the forests has developed, it has also become clear that we do not know enough about the commercial species that are currently being extracted. Although the Forestry Commission probably overestimates the regenerative capabilities of the forests and the life forms they contain, it does at least try to plan for the long term. Few other industries routinely look 40 years ahead. But even a cursory reading of the literature on forest management makes it clear that many vital questions on the best logging techniques for different types of timber on various soils, the control of erosion after logging and the reduction of wild fires are still unanswered. This is partly because timber growing is a long term project. An experiment in growing common species for sawlogging could last 80 to 100 years, and growing brushbox to maturity would take the best part of a millennium.

We have more information on fast growing eucalypts that would be suitable for woodchipping, although even here Australia probably lags behind other countries that have planted large areas of eucalypts. For example, Brazil has planted about 2.2 million hectares. The few experiments which have been done in Australia have revealed that trees grown under plantation conditions have characteristics different from natural growth trees. There are indications that some species initially thought unsuitable might perform well in plantations and that careful selection of particular genetic lines could produce even better results. Hardwood plantations-primarily for pulpwood-are the theme of the moment. Although there is some disagreement on the exact yield of hardwood plantations and the feasible extent of planting, it is agreed by all that such plantations are a good idea. However, the developed concept of plantations did not come from Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Ltd, nor from the New South Wales Government, nor even the Federal Government; they have come from the very underfunded conservation groups, which have used their limited resources to put forward some detailed suggestions on how hardwood plantations could reduce the woodchip cut in the natural growth forests.

A major contribution, as you, Mr President, may be aware, was made by the Australian Conservation Foundation's economic analysis of a conservation oriented forest industry strategy titled The Wood And the Trees, which was published in May 1988. This considered the future prospects of the whole Australian timber industry and offered detailed projections and recommendations. More specific recommendations on the south-east forests were made in papers produced by the South East Forest Alliance (SEFA) in June and again in November this year which paid particular attention to replacing the jobs that might be lost by the elimination of logging in National Estate areas. These papers suggested that extra jobs could come from greater efficiency in the use of waste for woodchipping and from the establishment of quite extensive plantations to supply future woodchip demand, and perhaps sawlogs. It also proposed the restructuring of the industry by introducing new technology, such as the glue lamination process, to make better use of timber resources and add value to local timber products.

Perhaps not all the quantities and estimates in these proposals are perfectly accurate-many projections have to be partly guesswork by their nature. The New South Wales Government commissioned a rebuttal of the first SEFA proposal from Professor Lindsay Pryor, who has participated in some small-scale plantation experiments in the south coast region. Professor Pryor criticised several aspects of the SEFA proposals, including prospective yields from plantations, the time scale for producing sawlogs from plantations and the availability of suitable land for plantations. But he did say that `the plantation scheme is to be commended as a long term development of merit' and recommended that the feasibility of introducing the gluelam and fingerjointing processes should be investigated.

Why did the conservation movement have to develop this scheme? It could be because the level of royalties paid for the south coast woodchip is so low that there is no incentive to develop plantations. Perhaps Harris-Daishowa expects to be able to pulp the whole regrowth of these forests after the sawloggers are driven out of business. I went to Harris-Daishowa not so long ago and I have seen the logs they pulp. I know that the size and superficial appearance of logs is not necessarily a good guide to the suitability of logs for the sawmill and officials of Harris-Daishowa told me that they allowed sawloggers into the mill to pick through the pulping stockpile. However, qualified observers have told me that timber that is pulped at Eden would be sawn elsewhere, such as at Armidale.

The Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, visited Japan earlier this year where he urged Japanese industry to help Australia to develop a secure and predictable resource for the future as well as further processing and value adding activities. It will be interesting to see whether his exhortations elicit any response or whether Harris-Daishowa merely continues with its resource mining attitude. But we cannot merely blame the company. It is the short-sightedness of successive Australian governments that has allowed our timber, and other resources, to be exploited for such meagre returns. Two months ago Senator Button described the woodchip industry as a `bastard' of an industry. However, neither governments nor the industry pay more than lip-service to the pressing need for a basic restructuring.

The recently released award restructuring report by the 1989 Tripartite Timber Industry Mission is a case in point. While there are some sensible recommendations in the report on training and award restructuring, a better employment structure alone will not save components of the industry that depend on an unsustainable resource base. The most interesting parts of this report are the graphs-used for decoration-that show the successes of the very efficient Swedish forest industries.

The south-east forest issue is only one of the local environmental crises around the country. There are other environmental losses that may end up costing far more jobs than are potentially under threat in southern New South Wales. Australia is not as badly off as many other countries that are daily suffering irretrievable losses. It is partly because our situation can be remedied that the need for us to change direction is so urgent. The larger atmospheric environmental problems are much more difficult. It is possible that prompt action by most nations can reduce the impact of the ozone layer depletion but it would need something like a miracle to provide a complete answer to the threat of the greenhouse effect.

Some people, including Senator Cook and the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, hope that tree planting can make a contribution by soaking up some of the greenhouse gases-specifically carbon dioxide-but to absorb even the 150 million tonnes of carbon that are released into the global environment by Australian domestic use and exports-only about 2 per cent of the global output-would need 300,000 square kilometres of healthy young forest. This is approximately 30 billion trees, and it is obvious that Mr Hawke's billion trees will make an insignificant contribution to the problem. Note that the 300,000 square kilometres of trees would only absorb the carbon dioxide from Australian resources that we are currently pumping into the atmosphere, and would make no contribution to the existing excess that is already driving the earth into a fever.

It is primarily governments that we expect to plan resource use for the long term. We also expect them to look some distance ahead in regional employment planning. Not only have governments failed to provide this basic service to their electors but their penchant for the quick fix and magic bullet that will seem to solve immediate problems-and get them re-elected-often makes things worse in the longer term. In the case of the south-east forests, the governments involved first have to stop squabbling and scoring cheap debating points off each other. They will have to either persuade, or coerce, companies like Harris-Daishowa into greater investment in resource renewing developments, or themselves fund the research and establishment costs of a plantation program. They may also have to fund feasibility studies and the establishment costs for value added forest industries.

These proposals would certainly include the flitch mill that is currently being investigated, possibly a pulp processing plant-although siting such a plant could present major problems-and certainly at least one of the advanced techniques for the more efficient use of smaller timber, like gluelam, fingerjointing and perhaps a hardwood-based product similar to Scrimber. Use of any of these techniques would require efficient kiln-drying plants.

All of these possible developments would provide added employment for the short and medium term but in the longer term plantations for pulpwood alone could lead to greater production efficiencies that would need less labour. These alternatives need to be critically assessed in the context of the region. Professor Pryor pointed out that some parts of the Eden management area are somewhat marginal in terms of soil types and annual rainfall but this only underlines the need not to ruthlessly overexploit the natural forests. Just as the protesters have intruded into the traditional domain of the loggers and interrupted the song of the chainsaw, so the politics of our rapidly depleting resources will intrude into all our lives. We will all have to involve ourselves in the decisions that will shape our future; as workers, consumers, investors, voters, and even as senators.

The growing awareness of the need to conserve and manage our natural assets is not the real threat to continuity of employment and job security. We are going through a time of enormous changes that are making the existing inequities in our nation even worse. Wealth is increasingly going into the hands of a minority who are in a position to take advantage of change and new technology is reducing the demand for labour in many industries. Make-work jobs are not the answer; pretend jobs as an alternative to unemployment will degrade workers and further run down our troubled economy, leaving us further behind the other developed nations of the world. The restructuring of our national resource and labour utilisation must begin now.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
